deciding which of these phenomena are consistently and pervasively relevant across settings is much harder, lots of free parameters

responses.comment: I'm not aware of any evidence that says that immigration has long-run domestic costs -- though it may impose short-term adjustment costs.

low skills and lack of language will make assimilation challenging, but by the end of the decade they will probably be net contributors

data.question: If the US significantly lowers the number of H-1B visas now, expected US tax revenues will rise materially over the next four years.

responses.comment: Basic economic theory. Cheaper factor expands output. Revenues increase not decrease.

Yes, H-1b is a flawed way to bring in skiledl immigrants (gives employer control over their immigration). But repeal w/o replace is dumb.

															-see background information here

responses.comment: The evidence is not clear. But no support for a strong effect.

Protectionism doesn't work

eventually perhaps some americans get hired, but seems more likely that there are shortages and activity moves in the short run

H-1B visa holders fill positions that are hard to fill domestically for structural reasons, such as skill mismatches.
Some production would move out of the US because of the scarcity of skilled workers.

data.question: Providing state and local subsidies to build stadiums for professional sports teams is likely to cost the relevant taxpayers more than any local economic benefits that are generated.

responses.comment: Tangible economic benefits are not large. Consumer satisfaction from having a local team is harder to quantify.
Hmm, Is this the most pressing economic issue of the moment? I wouldn't have thought so...
Sports teams generate value that they cannot capture thru tixs/tv----Chicagoans benefited from Cubs winning WS. Subsidies are compensation

data.question: US share prices have risen since Donald Trump’s election victory at least partly because the policies he seems poised to implement are likely to increase US after-tax corporate profits.

responses.comment: They are more likely to increase the corporate profits of listed firms than all firms, and also in the short/medium run rather than long run
The after-tax part is crucial.
Even if there is no impact on before-tax profits, stock market investors generally believe that corporate tax rates will drop a lot.
Changes in stock prices are largely unpredictable.  No real way to identify the increase in stock prices to Trump.
companies like tax cuts
Two forces in the universe are really hard to predict or understand: Trump and the stock market.
People, probably correctly, expect lower corporate taxes and fewer regulations. Go figure.
Pure Animal Spirits would seem to be the best explanation.
The rise in prices could be due to a reduction in uncertainty, not to a change in expectations.
Enthusiasm driven by the expectation of regulatory relief and concomitant investment, growth and profits.
Can't be proven one way or another, this is plausible but no way to know for sure
Trump + Republican Congress = lower tax rate on corporate profits.
Hard to separate the different causes. The impact of tax policies seems the most important reason, particularly the cut in business taxes.
There is too much uncertainty about his policies to know for sure, but they appear to auger well for corporate profits.
More precisely, most market participants believe Trump's policies are likely to increase corporate profits
Hard to imagine what else it could be.
Explaining any short term movement in stock prices is a fools game, but this explanation is a plausible one.
Corporate tax cuts and defense / some infrastructure spending may happen with a unified government.

data.question: US share prices have risen since Donald Trump’s election victory at least partly because the policies he seems poised to implement are likely to increase US real GDP growth.

responses.comment: They are much more likely to be disastrous for the economy and the US political system. The economic policies we know about are  shambles.
Some policies likely to boost growth, at least temporarily. Others likely to suppress it. Hard to say!
Uncertain because real winners and losers.

High income tax cuts aren't stimulative and infrastructure takes years
see above

I do not agree with the premise that his policies are likely to increase growth in the long run.
Again, regulatory relief expected to drive investment and growth.
also impossible to know and the horizon that matters for stocks is longer term growth and after tax earnings

Here, the Keynesian impact of tax cuts on output is partly offset by likely higher real interest rates.

Stock returns are poor predictors of future changes in output (see e.g. Stock and Watson 2003 Journal of Economic Literature)

It is hard to know what Trump's policies will be since he contradicts himself repeatedly, but he shows no signs of understanding economics.
In the short run, which dominates, fiscal stimulus or barriers to trade? The longer run looks bad for many reasons.

data.question: The Council of Economic Advisors is likely to give the US president better policy advice if the Chair and Members of the CEA have published peer-reviewed economics research.

responses.comment: At least familiarity with nature of econ evidence and recent research is a must. Nonacademics often underestimate uncertainty all evidence.
Alongside bad military advice, bad economic advice has harmed many nations, citizens and presidents. A CEA head should know some economics!
A capable committed consumer of research likely fine. It would be unusual to achieve that without an advanced degree.
A President needs lots of types of advice, and this is the way to get academic input.
The better economists, on average, are probably those publishing in peer refereed journals. But I don't have evidence for that to cite!
There is no scarcity of advisers who are not peer-reviewed economists.  NEC, Treasury, Commerce, etc. Academics have a valuable perspective.
...better for whom?
all industries have a blind spot for themselves. but familiarity w latest research is impt, if background is talking head or professor
I would conjecture yes. Your advice will be better if you can understand the latest thinking and this is more likely if you publish.
Economic policy-making at the White House level requires great analytical skill and deep economic knowledge.
Economics training and good economic judgment trump peer reviewed papers.
Junk arguments abound in economics.  Research experience helps prevent them getting to the President.

Jason Furman is a counterexample.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Would emphasize background in academic or similar institutions and participation in professional associations.
Peer reviewed research is not the only source of insight, but it is an essential input, and the CEA is the obvious place to provide it.
Publication demonstrates training and quality of mind; necessary but not sufficient conditions for good economic advice.
This question is uncomfortably self-serving
Publications neither necessary nor sufficient to be good CEA chair.  Jason Furman has few but has been excellent.

data.question: If all of the “Seven actions to protect American workers” in President-elect Trump’s 100-day plan (see link) are enacted, it will more likely than not improve the economic prospects of middle-class Americans over the next decade.

responses.comment: Even if we no longer import from and offshore to China and Mexico, manufacturing jobs won't come back. If they did, they would before robots

not even funny anymore

Too many dramatic changes and conflicting forces to have more than a hunch.

shutting down trade will be bad for most people, the jobs are not coming back, the infrastructure gains might be good

These 7 actions are symbolism (5, 6), actions with trivial immediate but disastrous long run consequences (7) or threats of trade war (1-4)

data.question: If all of the “Seven actions to protect American workers” in President-elect Trump’s 100-day plan are enacted, it will more likely than not improve the economic prospects of low-skilled Americans over the next decade.

responses.comment: Increased infrastructure spending could help construction, but the overall plan won't help workers & will likely reduce medium term growth.

oh, please

responses.comment: Cookies and ACs definitely not. But there might be a case for tariffs for TEMPORARY tariffs in the face of large shocks such as China.

stupid

probably not by much given the magnitude of the new flow vs size of existing stock but directionally, yes

data.question: Granting every American citizen over 21-years old a universal basic income of $13,000 a year — financed by eliminating all transfer programs (including Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, housing subsidies, household welfare payments, and farm and corporate subsidies) — would be a better policy than the status quo.

responses.comment: Current US status quo is horrible. A more efficient and generous social safety net is needed. But UBI is expensive and not generous enough

data.question: The ratio of the 90th to the 10th percentile of the US income distribution has been unaffected by the Federal Reserve's unconventional monetary policies since the financial crisis.

responses.comment: Perhaps top 1% share (especially in wealth). Because of the induced stock market boom, but this is uncertain. Certainly not 90-10.
Monetary policy affects asset prices -> redistributes wealth (if assets not held symmetrically).See e.g. "Redistribute monetary policy" 2012

A lot of low to mid income workers would have had no jobs absent the Fed's policy. This is a first order impact on the 90-10 income spread.
Monetary policy has distributional effects; it should however not be made on that basis.
compared to what? if the fed hadn't cut rates to 0+QE, the recession would have been deeper and that would have made inequality even worse
easy to tell stories of an effect and stories of no effect-- i'm unaware of meaningful evidence.

data.question:

In early 1998, before Glass-Steagall ended and before Citicorp merged with Travelers, they held 13.2% (an average of 3.3% each). Thirty years ago, before interstate branching was fully permitted, that combined share was around 8% (an average of 2% each).


Capping US banks’ size so that no single bank could be larger than 4% of the sector's domestic assets would lower systemic risk in the US.

responses.comment: Political connections and systemic effects of risktaking make concentration in  finance likely more pernicious than elsewhere. 4% a ?

depends how you did it but size alone isn't what's dangerous-it's interconnectedness. And you can't ignore non-bank financial institutions.
too many other factors matter such that question is challenging to answer confidently, e.g., what about capital holding requirements?

shadow banking risks would grow substantially if we go this route and we already saw that they were at the heart of the last crisis

data.question: The US financial system would contribute more to the average American's welfare if the size of US banks were capped so that none could be larger than 4% of the sector's domestic assets.

responses.comment: Against the benefits of lower systemic risk there is the loss of business to other financial centers. Global regulation would be better.

Size alone confers no benefits to consumers and arguably is one source of costs (those associated with financial instability).

we are missing decisive evidence on whether benefits of large banks exceed their costs
see A
There are benefits of large banks as well as costs. Regulation should include shadow banks and be more flexible than a cap on size.

data.question: By providing important measures of US economic performance — including employment, consumer prices, wages, job openings, time allocation in households, and productivity — the Bureau of Labor Statistics creates social benefits that exceed its annual cost of roughly $610 million.

responses.comment: BLS data are key to measurement of unemployment, wages, productivity, and labor force trends. It is also key for policy analysis.
The U.S. has lead the world in measuring and understanding its own economy. Willfully blinding ourselves would be a step towards darkness

Information is good.
Do not know exactly whether the money is spent well nor whether private sector alternatives could do better.
we badly under-invest in measuring what happens in the economy & it sometimes hampers policy decisions. see Bernanke's memoir for an example
The BLS and Census produce vital macro statistics and make anonymized micro data available for public policy-related research.
One cannot hope to make effective economic policy without reliable data.
BLS data is essential for the Fed at a minimum. $610 million is 0.003% of US GDP.
I believe strongly that better evidence generates better policy choices. But I don't have strong evidence to back up that belief.

data.question: Cuts in BLS spending would likely involve net social costs because potential declines in the quality of data, and thus their usefulness to researchers and decision makers, would exceed any budget savings.

responses.comment: The BLS has been underfunded for several years.  Key data products are at risk.
BLS data are at the heart of good policy in both the public and private sectors. It's a bargain relative to the public and private value.
Same answer as before.
I doubt we have too much information of excessive quality. Reallocation of resources may be desired, but not cuts.
Big data from the private sector is becoming more plentiful, but it cannot match the scope and representativeness of BLS data.
Just turn your headlights off at night on an icy country road to see what is involved in reducing the quality of economic statistics.
Economic policy is often imprecise, but abandoning the data and making policy blindly would be even worse.
Full disclosure: much of my research uses publicly available BLS data.

data.question: An important reason why many workers in Michigan and Ohio have lost jobs in recent years is because US presidential administrations over the past 30 years have not been tough enough in trade negotiations.

responses.comment: US trade with China caused large emp. declines. But the main mitigating policy should be worker adjustment programs, not trade negotiations.																						-see background information here
Trade has hurt blue collar workers in manufacturing in Mich, Ohio and elsewhere. But trade negotiations must balance competing interests.																						-see background information here
Growing competition from China and Mexico has cost many manufacturing jobs in Ohio and Michigan. Weak negotiations are not the cause.
-see background information here
The phrasing implies that any reduction in jobs is bad.  Some shifts in employment are valuable (e.g., fewer sweatshop jobs in the US).
"Tough enough" is not meaningful.  More restrictive US trade policy toward autos would have benefited autoworkers while hurting consumers.
V likely that any trade effect is from greater competitiveness of China/India/etc rather than tariffs. & recession is big cause of job loss
Job losses occur because of automation, energy prices, tastes, as well as trade. A tougher  policy could have been worse not better.
This question is a good but complicated one. I would like to be able to answer but a cursory explanation cannot do justice to the issue.
Many jobs went to the US South. Increases in productivity reduced jobs. New jobs were created due to access to foreign labor.
Technology, globalization, perhaps, unionization are the primary source of lost jobs in Michigan and Ohio.  Same is true in Western Europe
Lots of caveats re the benefits of trade, but failure to bargain hard enough is NOT very relevant.  We are protectionist in some cases too
"Enough" wrongly implies that policy should have been more protectionist. But freer trade did increase gross job destruction.																						-see background information here
Big drop in manu jobs in 2000s, but prob not due to trade deals.
Toughness in trade negotiations is considerably less important than factors such as skill-biased technical change in manufacturing.
Trade matters for job loss, but toughness in trade negotiations has a small effect on trade.
There is nothing in economics or psychology that suggests that being "tougher" gets more.  See ultimatum game.

data.question:
There is no perfect
voting system. That is, no voting system can ensure that the winner will be the
person who best represents voters’ wishes, including how intensely they favor
or disfavor each candidate.

responses.comment: Just another day's work for Ken Arrow
Condorcet paradox
-see background information here
This is a 1950 theorem of Kenneth Arrow.  "A Difficulty in the Concept of Social Welfare" Journal of Political Economy.
especially with lots of candidates
This is well worked out theoretically.  But it doesn't mean voting isn't better than the alternatives!  (Answer by Andrew B. Hall)
We know from Arrow's impossibility theorem that no voting system can aggregate preferences perfectly even if people vote honestly.
Ken Arrow actually has proved a theorem to this effect (that holds under pretty general conditions).
Arrow's theorem implies there is no perfect system using only ordinal preferences. Cardinal systems are strategically manipulable.
There is extensive research and impossibility results showing that there is no perfect voting system.
However alternatives that allow for multiple votes per person can achieve outcomes that better reflect intensity of opinions.																						-see background information here
The one exception is dictatorship, so there is only one voter.																						-see background information here
Arrow proved this. Like asking if 2+2=4.

data.question:
One clear defect of a winner-take-all election with 3 or more
candidates, and with each voter choosing only one candidate, is that a
candidate who is strongly disliked by a majority, but strongly liked by a
minority, can beat a candidate who is liked by a majority and disliked by
relatively few.

responses.comment: strategic voting behavior can help to reduce the problem.
The issue is discussed nicely in the popular article I link, even though the specific polling status of the candidates is now very dated!																						-see background information here
I would say "imperfection" not defect.  Compared to what, though is the question, as there is no perfect system ...
but isn't it fun to watch it happen?
Strategic voting should in principle help, but in practice coordination failures clearly do occur. This is one reason why runoffs are a good																						-see background information here
46% of people rank 3 candidates A,C,B. ( A first, B last.) 44% rank them B,C,A. 10% rank them C,B,A. Then A wins,but C may be better.
The words liked and disliked are too ambiguous but with my interpretation the answer is obvious.
Looks like that may be happening this year.
Nonetheless, this does not absolve the U.S. citizens if we elect Trump!
A defect, but alternatives that try to fix it like run-off elections or transferable voting, have drawbacks as well.
This is a well-known defect of plurality rule
Single transferable vote would overcome this problem.
Winner-take-all elections with multiple candidates are fertile ground for generating perverse results.
Assumes a one-round, plurality wins system.
I hesitate only because I'm not sure whether this is necessarily a defect.  The rest of the claim is true.
Yes, stuff can happen. Follows from question 1.

data.question:
Large movements in
monthly oil prices, either up or down, are driven primarily by speculators, as
opposed to changes in the current (and planned) supply or demand for oil.

responses.comment: Huge changes in demand and supply over the last several years (shale gas, Iran-Iraq and global slowdown) account for the bulk of changes.
There is some anecdotal (and perhaps other) evidence of a cobweb cycle; supply responds to prices with a lag
In the price movements there is a fundamental and a speculative component.
The term "speculator" is itself a bit fuzzy.  I note one paper that attempts to define the term and the issue, though there are others.																						-see background information here
Speculators just don't have enough capital to hold oil prices artificially high, or low, for months at a time.
Don't know how to answer this.  Are airlines buying forward contracts to lock in prices speculators or acting on planned demand for fuel?
funny how you never hear about speculators on the way down
i am unaware of any systematic evidence relating speculation to "large movements in monthly oil prices"
What is a speculator? Most asset markets are subject to high unexplained volatility. Lots of debate about its source.
Prices may move frequently as speculators try to anticipate the future, but without speculation the movement would be larger when it occurs.
Expectations about the future are critical and big monthly moves are not because of chance or "speculators" -- changing fundamentals matter.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Poorly worded. Prices are driven by asset demands, not flows. Term "speculators" is misleading although technically accurate.
The price appears to fluctuate more vigorously than can be explained simply by changes in fundamentals.
Supply and demand.

It may play a role, but supply, demand and expectations of their future trends seem to dominate.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here

data.question: If the UK opts to withdraw from the European Union, and assuming Scotland stays in the UK, the level of the UK's real per-capita income a decade later will be lower than if it remains part of the EU.

responses.comment: we will never know
Depending on implementation details, an exit would increase barriers and frictional costs for intra-European commerce.
leaving is awful. the euro zone prospects are awful. which is more awful? awfully hard to tell

The EU is Britain's most important trade partner. Trade barriers with the EU would rise and this will hurt Britain's investment and growth.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Depends on terms for staying. There are win-win terms.
Leaving a free trade region will reduce efficiency, as well as reduce economic opportunities for UK citizens in Europe.
big transition costs to renegotiate various treaties even if Scotland stays in UK. but Scotland wld likely leave UK => even worse for both.
A decade is long enough, and the economies complicated enough, that anything could happen.
But costs of immigration restrictions in UK and less access to single market would probably outweigh gains from deregulation and transfers
I am 100% sure I don't know the answer. EU could crash.  What deal does UK strike? There are many unknown unknowns.

data.question: If the UK exits the EU, then it substantially increases the chances that some other current region of the EU will also exit within the following decade.

responses.comment: Once unraveling begins, it decreases both the benefits of staying and costs of exiting for the next ambivalent country.
With much uncertainty on magnitudes, the value of remaining in the EU depends positively on the set of EU members, a complementarity effect.
if they establish rules on how it works to exit and what access exit countries get to the market, then definitely raises exit chances
The value of staying in will fall. Others will also be emboldened to jump for noneconomic,e.g., political and psychological, reasons.
Countries that had the same policy preferences as UK will have less power. UK might form an alternative free trade framework.
Scotland would be very likely to go and resolving the legal ambiguities will embolden separatists elsewhere such as Catalonia
UK situation perhaps a bit different than many others because of own currency, and historical ambivalence about being part of Europe.
Predicting political events a decade ahead is perilous, but a withdrawal from the EU by the UK can't help.
Once the mindset that exit must be prevented at all costs is broken, others will more readily follow.
If there are good economic arguments pro or con, they have not reached me.
Ah, there is always a key word in these. This time it is "substantially".  The sign seems right but no clue about the magnitude.

data.question: China’s growth model, specifically the unusually high investment rate and low consumption rate, is unsustainable.

responses.comment: In the long run. But the long run can be very long...
True because it's already happened! Growth is down. Consumption is up.
I'm not a fan of the "s word" (sustainable).  The structure of China's economy will have to change over time, no question. But sustainable?
must we relearn the same lesson in the same painful way again?
China's TREMENDOUS gains in living standards last 25 yrs is 1 of most impt events in history  likely unsustainable but long run comes slowly
"If it can't go on forever, it won't"
As China becomes richer it will resemble other rich countries: growth rates will fall;wages and consumption will rise;investment will fall.
Of course, it is unsustainable in the very long run, but near-to-mid term sustainability is at least plausible.
Like 20th century Japan, Germany, etc., they are catching up with other economies and will slow down as they approach US/EU productivity.
They've talked about rotating demand forever, looks like the markets have lost faith and are worried about bridges to nowhere, etc.

They won't get as much growth from capital-deepening (rising capital-labor ratio) in the future as in recent decades.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
China's growth numbers have long been suspect; it is remarkable that new evidence of their weakness has so much effect on world markets.
However countries that grow very rapidly eventually hit a wall. Successful ones (e.g. Korea)  return to growth after the stop.
Internal politics matters here and it is hard to be confident about future developments.
In the long run, growth has to slow as the process of structural change approaches completion. Consumption eventually converges near income.

data.question: An annual December spending surge on parties, gift-giving and personal travel delivers net social benefits.

responses.comment: Contributes to the obesity epidemic for sure.
There is a difference between saying the holiday season confers net social benefits and that all the spending does.
Don't be an econo/supervillain
who could be against the holiday season?........perhaps only the grinch!
Definitely for gifts. Doing a lot shopping at the same time is efficient. But congestion is a problem for travel and parties.
There  seems to be a social need for public celebrations and gifts. But some are forced to participate.The net benefit is unclear.
The holidays may make us more altruistic, mindful of social good. I believe this, actually, but gifts/travel/spending do not seem essential
Signaling effects, each trying to be the best giver, create waste. Most actions are freely chosen. Net effect is likely positive.
No obvious failures of the welfare theorems, people have leisure complementarities and some prices are actually lower for shoppers																						-see background information here
By revealed preference, not for Keynesian reasons.
It would be Scrooge-like to suggest otherwise.
Despite curmudgeonly economics articles, the revealed preference is that people derive gains from these activities.
Compared to no concentration?  Externalities of both signs; who knows the net?
Don't let an overly narrow view of benefits and costs ruin your holiday cheer.
There is social value to coordinating activities where there are complementarities. Arguably this is one of them.
Lots of gain from coordinated consumption... but with a great deal of inequality in the distribution of benefits

data.question: The Fed should raise its target interest rate when it meets in mid-December.

responses.comment: Persistent low interest create credit misallocation as in the runup to the global crisis. This has to be balanced against Keynesian factors.
Low labor force participation rate and inflation but uncertainty over when it will happen is bad.
The FOMC should raise, given no big interim adverse shocks, to mitigate inflation risk. The macro vital signs look healthy enough now.
This week's job data are enough to put me somewhat reluctantly in the agree column, though I would like to see more evidence of 2% inflation
dangerous & loosening world. still no US inflation. reversal in near future would damage credibility of already credibility-deficited fed
where are price pressures? still a lot of people missing from the labor market.  boogeyman of bubbles always lurks but where is she?																						-see background information here
The Fed has somewhat overstated the current level of the natural unemployment rate and fails to understand that it is falling.
I don't think so. The recovery is still weak and there are no serious signs of inflation. Also a little inflation may be good.
The Fed spends many 10^7 dollars annually on econ research. In mid-2008, the Fed did not think that a crisis was at hand. With my budget...
As Mike Mussa once famously said "if not now, when?".
Inflation has fallen below the Fed's 2% target for over three years running, and is forecast to remain below for at least awhile.																						-see background information here
Has more attention ever been paid to 25 basis points? We could amend the constitution with less fuss.
Current inflation remains far below the target level
The conventional wisdom is that the strong November jobs report clinches a rate increase, and I see no reason to disagree.
.25 bps doesn't matter much either way.  It is the slope that matters. Go slow I say.

data.question: The Fed should have raised interest rates sooner, rather than leaving them near zero for this long.

responses.comment: It's been a close call. That the tradeoffs favored an earlier exit was not clear. Inflation was too low. Job creation was moderately good.
no way
fiscal policy was absent after the stimulus (see link)  even today millions of potential workers are missing from the job market																						-see background information here
The Fed's job is to stabilize inflation, barring significant inflationary shocks, and inflation continues to run below any reasonable target
See answer to last question.
I cannot be more knowledgeable than the Fed.
Delay in raising may have inflated asset prices.
certainly would have voted to raise in september, there are always excuses to delay, time to put two way risk back into the bond market
Inflation was low and the recovery was weak---low interest rates seemed indicated.
Note that this does not allow for those who think should be later. Survey bias.
Inflation has been surprising dormant, so there appear to have been few adverse consequences of prolonged low rates.
But only two meetings ago, in October
Congress gave them no choice.  We should have been borrowing at negative r and building infrastructure. And no inflation in sight.

data.question: Letting publicly traded US firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.

responses.comment: Firms may well still choose to report quarterly. And a year is still a short horizon for investment projects.																						-see background information here
"Allow them to" would be more appropriate language than "lead them to."  At most a _very_modest positive.
There's almost no support for short-term-ism. And earnings numbers themselves are unimportant. The market values overall prospects.
I am in favor of letting firms do this but only if it is part of their charter or approved by shareholders. It should not be a blanket rule.
No firm evidence, just anecdotal. Not clear there is any better periodicity.
Smart investors are perfectly capable of evaluating firms using a combination of multiple quarterly reports.
This would increase the information difference between insiders and outsiders. Management would have more time to hide their mistakes.
Two countervailing effects -- perhaps less short-term, but less accountability.  The latter is a bigger problem than the former.
It would relieve short term pressure, but not clear that they would necessarily become patient long-term oriented.
-see background information here
Assume means requiring. Given all the pressures, unlikely that would be major change, so epsilon effect. They might report anyway.
A year is still too short of a horizon to be confident that executives would appropriately weight long-term issues, which may span decades.
This is almost trivially true, since there would be no quarter-to-quarter considerations.  But it is hard to imagine a big effect.
Recent working paper says yes. http://bit.ly/1HgC0lg

data.question: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders.

responses.comment: Tradeoffs for investors (less transparency for example).
Public markets need certified disclosure regimes. Businesses that are harmed by disclosure should be private.
For some firms it might be better, for others worse. This is not a case where one size fits all.
One year far too infrequent for well functioning markets.
It is difficult for someone to benefit from being forced to be less informed.  There is such a thing as free disposal.
Perhaps less short-term, but less accountability.  Less short-term a minor improvement if any; less accountability a bigger cost.
Very hard to know the net effects, for instance it would become easier to hide bad decisions for longer periods.
Firms would probably report anyway. If not, would lead to more uncertainty and possibly more volatility. In any case, small effect.
The modest push toward better weighting of long-term issues must be balanced against the attendant loss of information and accountability.
Perhaps a touch less short-termism but a lot less timely information.  Hard to see a net gain.
Quarterly earnings reports make it easier to monitor managers, even if earnings can be manipulated.
Again see http://bit.ly/1HgC0lg

data.question: Comparing their students’ average gains on standardized tests over the school year makes it easier to predict which teachers — all else equal — are more likely to improve their student’s long-term life outcomes.

responses.comment: Value-added evaluation is far from perfect. But given that teachers matter greatly, it's surely one of many indicators one should look at.
It's imperfect and can be refined, but there's no question this approach contains useful predictive info.
-see background information here
While in principle test scores are a useful input to teacher evaluation, the  work of Rothstein and Darling summarizes important caveats																						-see background information here
Although teaching-to-the-test is bad practice, I anticipate a positive correlation between teaching quality and test-score improvement.
I'm firmly in the some-testing-is-helpful camp, but tests are likely to be a noisy signal for "long-term" life outcomes.
yes but with lots of noise and unbservables
impt caveat:  you can "get what you pay for" - higher test scores but less fundamental learning. are there broader tests w/o this problem?
An heavily fact-related issue in an area I'm not well informed about.
Research by Chetty et al. suggests this is so and I take that seriously. But this is a complex issue and it is early to reach conclusions.
If I could answer a well-worded question re: modern value-added methods, I would say "strongly agree" but this question is too badly worded.
I suspect that most situations do not satisfy the "all else equal" condition.
I think that is what Chetty and others find, though "easier" is in the eye of the beholder																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Recent large-scale empirical work seems to back up this assertion.
hvjhv																						-see background information here
But testing is just one of many measures, and is a noisy measure, and can induce distortions in behavior.
See Chetty et al. American Economic Review 2014
Plausible, but ...
Likely more informative in some schools than others.
Imperfect but useful tool.
Score gains have some information. But the proper weight is unknown, and "all else equal" is very difficult to arrange.

data.question:
The association between health and economic growth in poor
countries primarily involves faster growth generating better health, rather
than the other way around.

responses.comment: Some estimates suggest effects from health to GDP, but the magnitudes are small. Considerable evidence exists on income to health channel
This is ill posed.I would guess that the likely reason for correlation  is a third variable, like effective governance, which affects both
Historically one often sees first child mortality going down, before growth really picks up.
I suspect this is the primary channel, but there is some evidence the other way.																						-see background information here
There is literature both ways on this.
China is the obvious counterexample.
Yes, that seems right, but perhaps the answer changes for pre-historic societies.
I'm voting on the basis of the "primarily," since both directions are important.
this seems right on average but negative externalities like air pollution mean the relationship is not straightforward																						-see background information here
Thanks to products from advanced countries, poor countries have had huge improvements in longevity without much income growth.
Better health can surely increase productivity and hence growth but it is hard to believe that the causation mainly goes this way.
seems plausible that other factors ("institutions") could be driving both
-see background information here
In some cases, health outcomes have improved without significant income growth, and it is difficult to say that the causality runs one way.
There is some evidence that the relationship goes in both directions.  Unclear which effect is stronger.
Both directions of casualty operate, but the weight of evidence is that income to health has a stronger effect.

data.question: The decline in the fraction of people with incomes under, say, $1 per day is a good measure of whether well-being is improving among low-income populations.

responses.comment: $1 a day is an arbitrary measure. It is informative about the bottom, but not about living standards among low middle income households.
It's an okay start, but one could do much better! Why use a binary measure?
As population grows a declining fraction does not automatically imply a decline in number of people. Also, one has to correct for PPP and ..
I agree more than I disagree, but there are limitations to this measure.
It is too incomplete, and too badly measured.
There's more to the issue, but under the Inada condition, we care desperately about people whose log consumption is close to minus infinity.
It is probably not a great measure unless it incorporates the prices of local goods. Also it misses out on non-traded goods and services.
If this were $1 of consumption and not income, yes. Also if we mean "income" inferred from consumption, yes. But cash income is poor measure
The reduction in poverty worldwide so measured is a great success story over the last 35 years.
-see background information here
There are many other measures that should also be used, but this measure is informative.
Obviously not a perfect measure, but intuitive and should capture major trends.
It is a good measure, but it is flawed and it is not the only measure.
As usual, the key word here is "good".
"Good" may be too strong. Income is incomplete, difficult to define and measure, hard to compare across populations... But it's something.

data.question: Expanding health insurance to more people through the ACA’s public subsidies and Medicaid expansion will reduce total healthcare spending in the economy.

responses.comment: First result from Oregon study: People with health insurance use more healthcare
It is unlikely to reduce healthcare spending, but I am not aware of a full assessment.																						-see background information here
The timing is really important here.  Long term can be very different from short term; costs more likely to fall in the long term.
It's hard to believe that spending per person receiving services will go down enough to offset the number of people getting health care.
More insurance could lead to more usage and more spending. The countervailing hope is cost containment or prevention of expensive treatment.
Many countervailing factors, though I am weakly inclined toward the agree side of uncertain.
Basic economic theory (demand curves slope down)  + tons empirical evidence - RAND HIE + Oregon HIE + many quasi-experimental studies
The ACA caved to demands for excessively broad coverage.
It could fall as people get more preventative care; or rise as people use doctors more. Some evidence suggests the latter but it's early.
When you increase availability, you get more demand.  In our institutional environment, very hard to see how costs do not go up.
Certain kinds of acute-care spending may fall due to better preventative care. But an overall fall in spending seems unlikely
Health care insurance should provide care more efficiently than the current lack of insurance coupled with reliance on emergency services.
A big switch from reliance on emergency rooms to prevention could do this, but this does not seem likely.
Obviously could go either way.
Demand curves usually slope down. Evidence is that this is true for health care. Cost savings measures will mitigate but not outweigh this.

data.question: Expanding health insurance to more people through the ACA’s public subsidies and Medicaid expansion will generate gains in the health and well-being of the newly insured that exceed the costs.

responses.comment: A lot of uncertainty, and ACA has a lot of problems (esp. to rein in costs and tackle distortions). Probably still benefits outweigh costs.
That's just a prior. No evidence yet
Likely yes, though there are substantial uncertainties.
The resulting gains include better health for newly covered, and fewer preventable high-cost diseases to treat. The total should be enough.
i think yes but ultimately involves thorny issues of valuing improvements in health and reductions in consumption risk
The expansion of coverage was mainly intended to bring in healthy people whose payments would exceed their medical costs.
ACA allows ill people to see doctors and provides peace of mind. Both would be negotiated behind the veil of ignorance. Net benefit>0.
The experiments in Oregon suggest the benefits are modest and the costs higher.  But, there is stiil much uncertainty.
Basic medical care, especially preventative care, brings gains that are large compared to the costs.
This is, of course, the rationale for the program, and it is not implausible.
Very difficult question. Counting cost properly is hard enough; valuing the benefits even more challenging.

data.question: If the federal minimum wage is raised gradually to $15-per-hour by 2020, the employment rate for low-wage US workers will be substantially lower than it would be under the status quo.

responses.comment: Low levels of minimum wage do not have significant negative employment effects, but the effects likely increase for higher levels.
$15.00 will be high enough in the productivity distribution of workers in 2020 to substantially reduce jobs for the less skilled.
I don't think the evidence supports the bold prediction that employment will be substantially lower. Not impossible, but no strong evidence.
On the margin Card & Krueger show that minimum wages have little impact. In contrast, in France the minimum wage eliminates labor segment.
Empirical studies disagree on the sign of the effect.  Few of those concluding in favor of negative are consistent with "substantially."
Depends on how many exceptions are allowed. Most $15 city min wages exempt union members, for example.
I worry that it will be but we don't know enough. Firms may raise prices and the Fed may accommodate some inflation. But the change is large
Some will move to uncovered sectors and the underground economy, reducing (not reversing) the impact on actual employment.
A $15 minimum wage rise makes entry level / low wage jobs very expensive.  It would move the U.S. to be more like France, Italy, etc.
In rural areas this will have a significant effect, but in many cities it would not matter much.  Teenager employment likely to drop too.
The total increase is so big that I'm not sure previous studies tell us very much.
Evidence is that it would be lower by perhaps 1 - 2 %. Lots of margins for adjustments.
Our elasticity estimates provide only local information about labor demand functions, giving little insight into such a large increase.
Certainly in states where the median wage is close to $15. Smaller increases would impact employment much less.																						-see background information here
Lower, probably; substantially lower, not clear at all.
Assuming inflation stays low. There is substantial evidence that labor demand slopes down, at least in the long run
Empirical evidence suggests the effects on employment would be modest.
Lower, yes. "Substantially"? Not clear. For small changes in min wage, there are small changes in employment. But this is a big change.

data.question: Increasing the federal minimum wage gradually to $15-per-hour by 2020 would substantially increase aggregate output in the US economy.

responses.comment: If it had any net positive effect, it would likely be very modest.
It would generate extra demand provided that low-skilled citizen still find jobs and remain integrated in the society.
Because of labor market frictions and given the high propensity of low-income workers to consume, the effect is uncertain to me..
Small demand-side effects and uncertain supply-side effects make it hard to conclude in favor of "substantially" higher.
Does anybody have a mechanism in mind that would raise output? Stigler's argument that a min wage might not harm employment does not support
If employment not much affected and redistribution to workers demand could rise. But if sizable unemployment opposite could occur.
France, Italy, etc. have done this -- making it expensive to hire entry level workers -- contributing to low growth and high unemployment.
Given ambiguous employment effects and the aggregate share of people getting raises, I doubt you get "substantially" more output.
Aggregate demand should be bolstered, but the wage increase is so big that it's hard to predict what would happen with much confidence
Probably slight lowering of potential output, but < 1%.
Not a plausible stimulus package.
Again, any effects are likely to be small.

data.question:
The median Greek citizen will be
better off if there is a “yes” vote in the July 5 referendum on whether to
accept the terms of the bailout package offered by Greece's creditors.

responses.comment: Greece may be better off without, the euro but political risks, especially with current government, would be great, so a no is very risky
I think that a exchange rate change may generate a more sustainable direction for the greek economy
Not my area but I have found Meghir and Kashyap persuasive on this.
YES (lowering the chance of a needed devaluation) and NO (greater economic chaos and less structural reform) are both very bad for Greeks.
In fact package is no longer on offer.  A yes however creates hope of negotiating a better package w debt relief. No opens the door to chaos
There are so many possible scenarios in either case of a "yes" or "no" vote, no one has any idea of what can happen.
Lather. Rinse. Repeat.
Even better would be an immediate debt writeoff coupled with a new relation to the eurosystem that blocked further access to credit.
Yes means more of the same for Greece. No means a very uncertain  future. But the Euro was a bad idea and should end as soon as possible.
Neither option is great.  see my blog post for more complete analysis																						-see background information here
-see background information here
The bailout package means austerity---which is bad for the median citizen. But the uncertainty from a "no" vote could be worse.
Hard to know because involves primarily whether current incompetent government will survive, and whether new one can do better.
Voting no as a bargaining chip is not promising.  There should be mutual gains from keeping Greece in the euro, if the will can be found.
No good choice. If Yes Greece left with unsustainable debt burden. If No, Greece left with Tsipras-Varoufakis and possibly unplanned Grexit.
More likely than not, I think, but far from certain.
A yes vote leads Greece down a painful path. A no vote will lead down a much worse one, likely Grexit, legal battles, isolation, etc.
Both options are completely unspecified, and neither looks attractive.  Both sides could use some negotiations training.

data.question: Economic analysis can identify whether countries are using their exchange rates to benefit their own people at the expense of their trading partners’ welfare.

responses.comment: Its hard to know whether the net effect of the manipulation is to benefit the average citizen, just some interest group or indeed no one.
Yes, but it seems rare in practice that conditions support both detection of the strategy and effectiveness of the strategy by the "abuser".																						-see background information here
"though twilight may be long, there is a difference between day and night"
Optimal tariff theory says that countries should raise their prices. So policies to lower prices by devaluing must be harmful.
The answer depends on whether prices are flexible or sticky,the importance of foreign inputs in domestic goods. So hard to assess welfare.
Like the Volcker rule, the devil is in the details and most of the time it is very difficult to determine; rule very, very hard to write.
-see background information here
Have no idea of what this question means.
This is a difficult inference problem.
Exchange rate policy matters because of nominal rigidities and affects on global supply and demand. Identifying these situations is tricky.

data.question: Bank of Japan monetary policies that result in a weaker yen make Americans generally worse off.

responses.comment: Americans benefit from cheaper Japanese goods and would not benefit from Japan in depression.
America's cost in lower domestic output may have been recovered through better or cheaper substitutes from Japan.
Most Americans benefit because of lower prices of imports. Some lose because they are employed in industries competing with the devaluer.
Again it depends on whether prices are flexible or sticky. Also Americans benefit from cheaper Japanese goods. So hard to say.
Some may lose, but a cheaper yen will benefit buyers of Japanese goods. Japan trades with many nations. Japanese gains do not imply US loss.
Will be good for us if japan grows and avoids a crisis.  loose monetary policy one example of why a rule is so difficult
A  weaker yen means a terms of trade *improvement* for the U.S.
No macro effect if US offsets with mon policy, and will help stabilize world economy. So no if cooperative policies.
The weak yen gives rise to winners and losers in the US; it is not clear that the net effect (even if we could measure it) is negative.
Even if effective, BoJ policies to weaken yen would help some Americans while hurting others.
As usual, there are winners and losers from such policies

data.question: Behavior in many complex and seemingly intractable strategic settings can be understood more clearly by working out what each party in the game will choose to do if they realize that the other parties will be solving the same problem. This insight has helped us understand behavior as diverse as military conflicts, price setting by competing firms and penalty kicking in soccer.

responses.comment: Many ambiguous predictions, but broad insights of game theory are relevant to infinite # of domains.
Individuals are only boundedly rational, as the famous Keynes' Beauty Contest Experiments shows. Nevertheless strategic thinking improves.
This conclusion is supported by 65 years of research and many significant concrete applications. Of course, any theory is imperfect.
You know this and you know that I know that you know this.
Just being aware that others are solving similar problems doesn't lead to the successes economists have had. Rather it is Nash equilibrium.
Nash equilibrium is enormously useful. But people can be less rational than the theory supposes and so the predictions may be misleading.
Thank you, John Nash!
Nash created a whole new way to look at many problems, not always perfect, but a great starting point and benchmark
-see background information here
But one must be careful not to apply such equilibrium analysis in setting where it is not warranted.
Even a confirmed behavioralist has to admit that this analysis is often informative, if not always definitive.
As with much of rational choice theory, Nash equilibrium defines a benchmark to which behavior can be compared.  No theory, no anomalies.
As with any tool, game theory can be misused. But it can provide surprising and useful insights.																						-see background information here

data.question: The 9% cumulative increase in real US median household income since 1980 substantially understates how much better off people in the median American household are now economically, compared with 35 years ago.

responses.comment: But the same is true for the pre-1980 growth. So this number does NOT understate that growth of median income has declined after mid-1970s.
Over the 1980-2014 period CPI probably does not fully account for quality improvements or for the value of new goods (e.g., the smartphone.)																						-see background information here
I think it's more likely than not given secular improvements in healthcare, longevity, technology, and air quality.
There are gains in health etc. not measured in earnings but also psychological costs of growing inequality and a sense of disappointment.
Have to factor in changes in transfers, changes in household size, changes in labor force participation and CPI bias.
Likely true, but it not hard to construct arguments that contradict it. For many groups, health is getting worse.
Other relevant factors would be:  time spent commuting, increase in % of 25-53 employed, hours worked, hours connected to work email at home
"Understates" yes, "substantially" I revert to uncertain.
so much of our day is spent doing things that didn't exist back then that it's hard to believe the #s fully account for new products
CPI bias is important even w that in mind, 9% seems a small gain over 35 years  & i THINK median family is working many more hours
Lots of real growth in the top deciles and the bottom deciles. Not so clear at the median.
Iphones weren't available then suggesting understatement. But both partners often work, which is stressful. This suggests overstatement.
Depends how "better off" defined. Technology (eg smartphones), medical services,  lower crime, etc have increased quality of life broadly.
No one I know would rather face the 1980 bundle of goods (at 1980 prices) than current bundle, at anywhere near the same incomes.
The rise in life expectancy alone is worth on the order of 1% per year.																						-see background information here
Difficult question, but life expectancy is up from 74 to 79 years - seems like a substantial gain not reflected in real median income.
Due to measurement issues e.g. prices, family composition, measures of income, prob understates by >1% py. Add to that price quality bias.																						-see background information here
Yes, because it misses many innovations, but at the same time the upper end of the income distribution is extraordinarily better off.
Burkhauser et al. (2011) show faster growth in median post-tax, post-transfer size-adjusted household income including health ins. benefits.
The official indices and deflators undervalue quality change and new goods.  A small annual bias makes a big difference over 30+ years.
CPI has improved but is imperfect. Capital income matters, especially for retirees.  Mean household size has shrunk from around 3.3 to 2.6.
Define substantial. Agree that CPI overstates inflation.
-see background information here

data.question: Californians would be better off on average if all final users in the state paid the same price for water — adjusted for quality, place and time — even if, as a result, some food prices rose sharply and some farms failed.

responses.comment: The geographic price adjustments should reflect cost differences.  Distributional effects need to be addressed in the transition.
Does not have to bankrupt farmers: they can be given water rights to resell. Coase Theorem applies.
-see background information here
Depends on who levies the taxes, but there are obvious gains to be had.
Price-based allocation usually works, absent externalities. I'm no expert on water, so open minded to learning what the externalities are.
Subject to usual caveats: SR dislocations have costs that disipate in LR; lump sum redistribution may require compensation.
reform shld remove restrictions on intra- & inter-state trading, clarifying property rights & investments in monitoring water withdrawals																						-see background information here
There would be winners and losers. A better policy would engineer a roughly Pareto improving change. Bu probably better than nothing.
Equal prices imply that all final users will value the last gallon they use the same, which ensures efficiency. Consumer rationing does not.
Law of 1 price would generate enormous gains (from trade)--much more than enough to compensate family farms hurt in transition to sanity.
The marginal value of water differs greatly across uses. Change in food output will be small; farm use would not decline by much.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Basic economics would equate marginal prices for substitute users, but not at all clear if we're taking about average prices.
Moving to market-based system will be painful but particularly important given stresses to come.
"On average" hides some serious adverse consequences for some people, but rationalizing water prices would be a great step forward.
Disclosure: I am a member of the Board of Cosan Limited which is engaged in sugar and bioethanol production in Brazil.
There would be losers and serious adjustment costs, not all economic, so it is hard to be confident about "on average".
The only question is what "on average" means. One water price would make most Californians better off.
I may use this as one of the core examples for introduction to microeconomics: a simple example of misallocation and gains from trade.

data.question: The Fed should wait until its preferred measure of inflation (Core PCE) is clearly rising — and not just forecast to rise — before it begins hiking interest rates.

responses.comment: I am worried about misallocation of capital & the wrong type of risk-taking resulting from extended periods of very very low interest rates.
Tight labor markets raise many boats. Don't let the tide out prematurely.
As Gretzky said, "skate to where the puck will be." Inflation normally takes time to form, often 2 years or more. The Fed can judge timing.
Go look at their forecasts for the last 6 years. thank god they didn't act based on those.
i THINK risks of too little growth outweigh the risks of overshooting inflation target.  judgment call bc little evidence is available
Confusion here between rates of change and levels. The Fed should tighten when expected inflation is above target, not just when rising.
The recovery is anemic and I am more concerned that it will fizzle than I am worried about inflation. The Fed should not be too  cautious.
The statement would appear to be inconsistent with the empirical evidence of past inflation episodes.
Models focusing on uncertainty about labor mkt slack and the real rate might imply this; financial stability concerns can cut the other way																						-see background information here
The Fed has been and should be forward-looking.																						-see background information here
Imprecisely worded but gets the basic idea. Major point is that Fed should make sure US is not at a low nominal rate equilibrium.
Other factors, such as unemployment and participation rates, should also enter the Fed's decision.
The Fed should raise rates when forecast inflation is above target. Now the hard question: what forecast is better than current inflation?
Cost of waiting too long < cost of shooting too soon. Those predicting imminent inflation have been wrong for years.

data.question: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a city or state typically generates local benefits that outweigh the costs to the city and/or state providing the incentives.

responses.comment: If it was not to the benefit of the local government, why would they do it?
The competition is fierce and the benefits uncertain.  Winners curse is likely.
If it's done carefully--the firms can't get the tax benefits and then leave--this can pay off for a city or state.
It is difficult to believe that taxation decisions are consistent with cost-benefit analysis.
Of cours deals differ but usually the taxpayers get fleeced for a limited number of jobs that get relocated
It has local benefits, but the costs can outweigh them (e.g., if far enough beyond the peak of the Laffer Curve).																						-see background information here
Benefits are wildly exaggerated in the popular press, and we lack definitive scientific evidence either way.
Well documented that subsidies to sport stadiums yield negative returns and no reason to believe that it is better for other industries
I doubt it but don't recall seeing anything rigorous on this.
See Greenstone, Hornbeck, and Moretti (JPE 2010) for some evidence of large positive spillovers
I don't see how anyone can have an opinion about this without data.  A $1 tax break is worth it.  $100B not.  In between?

data.question: The US as a whole benefits when cities or states compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.

responses.comment: Such competition helps for local political economy reasons but may shift too much otherwise-public resources towards footloose companies.
I would agree if I were certain that governors had their states' long term interests in mind when cutting tax deals. Not sure that's true.
On its face, this sort of competition is useful. I can imagine that experts on this issue may suggest some unintended related distortions.
There is no social benefit to the US as a whole unless the firms would have located abroad. There is a social loss from lower tax receipts.
This is almost entirely zero sum, with the companies gaining and the taxpayers losing.
It could help if tax rates tend to be too high for political economy reasons.																						-see background information here
Generally a waste of revenues in negative-sum game.
Such competitive does enhance allocative efficiency, but its primary effect is to transfer surplus from other taxpayers to firms.
Would agree if cities compete with uniform lower taxes for all firms.
Unless the firm would otherwise locate abroad, the only net effect is less tax revenue.  The EU bans state aid for this reason.
There is a clear zero-sum aspect to tax competition. But nothing else can restrain the leviathan. The balance is unclear.
Again data would be nice.  Competition is good but unraveling is bad.  Which is this?  Transparency would help.

data.question: Declining to be vaccinated against contagious diseases such as measles imposes costs on other people, which is a negative externality.

responses.comment: The vaccine is not infallible, and some people cannot be covered.
The word " contagion" and the adverse consequence of disease directly imply the  result, logically.
Even those vaccinated can get the disease so there is an external cost both to the vaccinated and the non vaccinated.
The science seems absolutely clear. If you are not vaccincated others are more likely to catch the disease ( as well as you).
This is "first principles" in economics.
Costs grow as the number declining rises which the doubters do not seem to appreciate
This is one of the periodic questions designed to see whether respondents are awake.  True by definition.

data.question: Considering the costs of restricting free choice, and the share of people in the US who choose not to vaccinate their children for measles, the social benefit of mandating measles vaccines for all Americans (except those with compelling medical reasons) would exceed the social cost.

responses.comment: New infections keep coming in as people travel. Why allow parents to hurt their children
I am not qualified to opine on any specific disease but in general mandatory vaccine programs solve the free rider issue.
Strictly speaking, social choice in this setting is not obvious. Here, many benefit significantly at hopefully a small cost by fewer.
Another way to internalize the externality is to make those who don't get vaccinated pay a fine. But a mandate is adminstratively easier.
This question requires one to impose a social welfare function which is something an economist should NEVER do. No one made us God.
Measels had been eliminated, it is a shame that it is back.  But we should be careful about mandates in general.
-see background information here
Goes beyond economics. Many precedents on each side. If measles for children, why not mandatory flu vaccines for adults?
But it would be quite reasonable to limit the negative externality imposed by the unvaccinated by, e.g., excluding them from public schools.
Children are not choosing for themselves here; this would just add to the set of harmful choices that parents are not allowed to make.
Costs increase with the opt out rate.  It would be possible to increase the vaccination rate short of a mandate by making opting out harder.
Depends on the epidemiology of measles which I don't know (as well as the (low) cost of mandates and (high) cost of the disease).																						-see background information here

data.question: In 10 years, per capita purchasing power in Greece will be higher if — rather than continuing to service its debts over the next decade and complying with the budget rules currently in place — it refuses to accept a continuation of its current troika program and explicitly defaults on its debt held by the official sector.

responses.comment: Greece's problems are political not just macroeconomic. Unclear whether default will help. Syriza's approach so far goes in wrong direction
The debt overhang is very costly.  Domestic demand is also a problem. And the government is busy fire-fighting rather than making policy.
One has to find the right/sustainable balance btw structural reforms that ultimately benefit the common man and some creative debt relief .
Very hard to know.																						-see background information here
Impossible to predict all the consequences and their effect on Greece.
It's a tough tradeoff. A fresh start would help after some forced restructuring of labor markets, the civil service, and tax collection.
Depends mainly on ancillary policies under the two scenarios which are now not possible to foresee.
Too many possible effects to know the net effect.
They're in a hopeless situation now. But would they manage themselves better if they got out of the Euro than they did before they got in?
Greece seems incapable of running a big enough primary surplus to satisfy Germany, and it is probably harmful to try. Autarky is better.
For Greece: default is a plus,exclusion from the EU banking system is a minus- it could lead to bank runs and political chaos. Net unclear.
They will never repay all that is promised anyway & at some point the pain of avoiding default is too much. Exit will be awful in the SR.
Greek government debt held by non-Greeks (mostly the EU) is more than Greece's annual GDP.
It all depends on how financial markets react---and this is hard to predict
Too much uncertainty about response, whether leaves Eurozone, and impacts to have clear reading.
Greek economic institutions are notoriously ineffective; the troika program may provide the commitment needed to build working institutions.
So much would seem to depend on the difficult-to-predict reactions of various strategic players with diverse interests and agendas.
If Greece continues to service its debt, outcomes are reasonably forecastable. If it defaults, many different outcomes can happen.

data.question: Changing federal income tax rates, or the income bases to which those rates apply, can affect federal tax revenues partly by altering people’s behavior, and thus their actual or reported incomes.

responses.comment: Well duh!
The behavioral response might be small for certain tax code changes, though.
duh
The only possible question is the magnitude.
Consider an increase of income tax rates to 100%. Reported income would be close to zero after this.
Lots of evidence for this in a number of papers.
some tax changes more salient than others, but people do respond when the stakes are important
-see background information here
Not always predictably, of course.
This is a very weak statement!
Of course this is right.  But magnitudes matter a lot.

data.question: To the extent that a given tax change might affect revenues partly by affecting national-income growth, existing research provides enough guidance to generate informative bounds on the size of any growth-driven revenue effect.

responses.comment: More is know about static effects on labor supply, labor demand and investment than on productivity growth, which is key to long term growth
We're still debating the impact of TFRA 86 on economic growth. Clearly, our confidence intervals are infinite for these predictions.
The bounds might be wide, though.
"Enough" is the issue.  We have models which provide estimates.  There is a large cloud of uncertainty around these estimates.

Dynamic scoring: A back-of-the-envelope guide,
N. Gregory Mankiw, Matthew Weinzierl, J. Pub. Econ. 2006
go read it. it does no such thing
Taxes affect level of economic activity in long run But evidence doesn't exist for meaningful revenue predictions esp in near or medium term
A lot depends on the response of monetary policy, and there is no agreement on how much policy should or does respond to output changes.
I doubt that we know enough. There are disagreements about the response of labor supply to moderate changes in income tax rates.
That work does not try to model the true economy. E.g., no model of corp inc tax uses a valid price of risk. Economists prefer ignorance.
don't think we know for many types of changes
Maybe in some cases. Seems like a hard problem in general.
It's always difficult to turn qualitative predictions into precise estimates, but existing research can surely be helpful.
The bounds likely rule out some outcomes but may be very wide
In most cases we know very little. Chetty et al Danish study finds tax effects explain 1% of saving, design 99%.

data.question: For large proposed changes in tax rates or the tax base, official revenue forecasts provided to Congress would probably be more accurate if the CBO and JCT tried to estimate fully how the proposed tax changes would affect growth-driven revenue.

responses.comment: I worry about increased scope for political influences on the forecasts.
I feel that this type of projection is unwise: first-order impacts on policy but almost zero reliability. And it invites gaming.
In theory they could provide many estimates under different scenarios.  But picking one number or a likely range would introduce politics.
I thought they had already done this at CBO. If not, the research indicates they should give it a try. The stakes are relatively large.
it would open the process up to political shenanigans of the worst kind
poor state of literature would open the door to "judgment" which seems likely to devolve to political wrangling and lots of uncertainty
Again, the response of other elements of policy, monetary and fiscal, needs to be factored in, and there is great uncertainty.
The estimates would not be perfect but they would be better than assuming no response.
It's wrong of them not to TRY because then they are knowingly getting things wrong. However, they could easily make a mess of it.
It certainly would not be worse. Unfortunately, this is the kind of research that NSF kills.
We know the direction and for certain types of changes might have some decent estimates. But politics could corrupt the process too
Possibly. They might also be less transparent and/or easy to criticize.
The difficulties are that (a) knowledge of these has wide bounds and (b) communicating uncertainty bounds is virtually impossible.
Behavioral responses will be most important for large changes, but the effects of large changes are particularly difficult to estimate.
It depends on which estimates they used.
If done honestly, maybe, but the temptation to tilt would be strong.  It is the rare tax cut that increases tax revenues.

data.question: Most college professors who assign textbooks would not be able to guess, within 10% of the actual figure, the retail price that their students pay for new copies of those books.

responses.comment: Faculty will know what their university book store charges but will not know about foreign editions
I have not seen a recent survey. I am reminded to list the price of the texts on my syllabus by the person in charge of HEOA compliance.																						-see background information here
Just a guess, based on my own experience.
I'd run a survey if I wanted to know
My guess is that most pick what they think is the best book (or, of course, their own book) without regard to price.
I am not aware of any data on this question so I would just be guessing.
Based on asking a few people what they thought a basic principles book costs.  Most shocked to learn it is well over $200
Seems right to me, but only based on my own experience.
Need data to answer.
Since we have begun putting prices on our syllabi, it's become more likely that we would pass this test.

data.question: Since students can resell college textbooks or rent electronic versions, the net burden on students is substantially lower than retail prices for new textbook purchases would suggest.

responses.comment:
Yes, of course the fact that one can (often) sell the new book back helps, but many students skip buying the textbook.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Depending on the meaning, seems either trivially true, or just unclear what is being held constant.
Most of the students I see seem to have new copies. Stanford may not be the norm.
maybe.  it depends on several factors, including how active these markets are and the costs of reselling/renting
...to a person who was unaware of the resale market (not me!)
This seems rather self-evident, although perhaps not all students can do this. Some people no doubt also photo-copy parts of books.
It is costly to change a textbook much with each edition so students can use much cheaper past editions with little intellectual loss.
The resale market helps but does not change the net burden by much,
These factors help, but some students would like to be able to keep their books and that cost is much higher now
But new editions undermine this.																						-see background information here
The net burden is lower than the retail price, but still scandalously high.
"Substantially" depends on those markets having few frictions, and I have no idea if that is the case.
It would be useful to know what fraction of books are rented or resold.
See Chevalier, Judith, and Austan Goolsbee. "Are durable goods consumers forward-looking? Evidence from college textbooks."																						-see background information here

data.question: Even though the professors who select textbooks are different form the people who pay for them, the price of new edition college textbooks reflect classic forces of supply and demand.

responses.comment: Only if you include agency problems among the "standard forces" of supply and demand.
Professors only partially consider price when choosing textbooks. And consider test banks and other perks.BUT students are P elastic.
More than just classic supply and demand, though.
In some sense, this MUST be true. What else could it be?
Author-publisher search costs are high. Then, second-hand market aside, the publisher has a monopoly on the title, implying pricing power.
Question too broad
Chevalier/Goolsbee research suggests demand is price elastic so not divorced from S & D but agency problem surely creates distortions
Provided one takes a broad view of supply and demand--printed books are a sunset product, and thus pricey.
In some fields there will be a prominent book with few competitors. The author has some monopoly power; the equilibrium price may be high.
There is an agency problem (instructors=agents, students=principals) but not severe owing to used books and student evaluations.
Product differentiation and lack of incentives for professors to make efficient choices make this unlikely.
I don't have a good story for where the market failure or market power comes from, but the relative price has gone way up.
Text prices include bundled ancillaries which students pay for but are benefits for teachers.
There are too many imperfections and frictions in this market to model it simply in terms of demand and supply.
Surely the prices reflect supply and demand, but not nearly so well as they would without the agency issues identified in the question.
But demand may be quite inelastic, since once a book is selected for a course, there are no substitutes.
When the chooser is not the user then bad outcomes are common.  My views are captured here: http://bit.ly/1Cql4mR
Difficult to interpret this question.

data.question:
The recent decline in oil prices will promote higher real GDP in the US
over the next couple of years.

responses.comment: There will be a negative effect on the now sizable US energy sector, but the positive impact on the rest of the economy should dominate.
A decline in oil prices leads to redistribution of wealth within the US, which favors (sub)sectors with impaired balance sheet constraints.
Obviously, there are losers as well as winners, but the US economy benefits on net.
We are still net importers, right. But there could be second round effects, especially political, that could moderate or even reverse it.
