Oil production investment is a negative, but reducing the cost of a raw input nets to positive, unless oil exports heavily dominate imports.
U.S. is a large net importer.  Increased oil prices in the past have slowed GDP growth.
Costs would go down, Fed may keep rates low. But negative effects on oil exploration, production and potential future oil exports.
but not as much as in the old days because the economy is more energy efficient now and because we have become a significant producer of oil
The 1986 decline had little effect on real GDP. Oil prices don't shift production functions. Real income rises, but not real output.
There are potentially confounding general equilibrium effects but the US as a net importer of oil should benefit from increased fracking.
The U.S. econom remains strongly anti-cyclical in oil prices. Some industries suffer from lower prices, but they are dominated by winners.
For the average household this will be a like a tax cut, of course oil producing states suffer a bit, but overall this good news for the US
Ceteris paribus.  And because the U.S is still a net importer.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Both because of quasi-fiscal stimulus and lower measured inflation.
The decline in price is less significant than the technological progress in resource extraction it reflects, which should promote growth.
But if drop is result of correct forecast of weaker world economic activity, it will be hard to identify the net benefit ex-post.
The US is still a net energy importer and the shock is largely a supply shock. But this will cause some reallocation away from shale
We have almost balanced trade in energy; the net effect will be very small (although there will be distributional effects).

data.question: A US city hosting a big convention will enjoy a higher boost to incremental spending — holding the number of visitors and their average incomes fixed — if those visitors are auto dealers rather than economists.

responses.comment: Not a lot of impulse spending among economists by my observation. You can charge them a lot for WiFi however.
Never been to their convention. My response assumes they spend less time than we do inside our hotel rooms interviewing job canditates.
Economists spend all of their time in the hotel doing interviews.
I have a strong prior, but it is pure prejudice and there is a high probability of it being wrong.
Sorry -- I'm not familiar with the spending habits of auto dealers!
Although economists are known to economize and some think tipping as tourists irrational, in truth, who knows?
Agree, except for Orley Ashenfelter's wine brigade.
Economists are known for parties and blowing money. The original AEA motto was 'Cras Ignorare' (FORGET TOMORROW)
Those dealers know how to have fun...
Dealers have high-powered incentives. Winners may celebrate a lot and losers drown their sorrows. Low variance makes economists staid.
Deep Q: By being dismal (scientists), do economists exert a negative gen eqm effect on the natives, thereby actually depressing consumption?
Businessmen supposedly have larger spending accounts. According to one "survey", ladies of the evening leave town when economists arrive.
we are lengendary cheap skates.  this is why we can't hold the aea convention on a weekend in las veags -- we don't spend enough!
-see background information here
Economists are famous cheapskates.
Based on sample of experts (n=1)
We hate to be called the dismal science, but I fear we can be a dismal lot - or perhaps we work so hard there is no time to spend money.
Economists rarely try to impress each other with how much money they can spend.  Auto dealers, by reputation, do this fairly often.
Only safe prediction is that those who make money via tips fear the AEA.  Economists known to be bad tippers.
.. because, basically, we're boring.

data.question: A typical country can increase its citizens’ welfare by enacting policies that would increase its trade surplus (or decrease its trade deficit).

responses.comment: Consumption and investment smoothing is good. But often CA deficits support consumption booms that are unsustainable.
Perhaps in the very short run, but not in equilibrium.
There is no reason to think the relation is causal
Depends on circumstances. To return to steady state, export growth model worked well for China, Asian Tigers and Germany after WW II.
There is no conceptual or empirical support for this.  It depends on dynamics and discount rates.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Focusing on trade is basically mercantilism. I take a global perspective, where trade always nets to zero, so this focus is meaningless.
A trade surplus means a country is saving, a trade deficit that it is dis-saving. As with people each can  make sense at different times.
Depends on circustances. For small open economies and emerging economies an essential element of policy.
1st principles: neither surplus nor deficit necessarily welfare-enhance. SOME welfare-enhancing policies would raise surplus, however.
The best way to increase welfare is to engage in good policies, not go after some mercantilist ideal.
crazy assertion but plenty of people seem to believe this. to see the fallacy, note that banning imports would do it and would crush welfare
Mercantilism!																						-see background information here
In some cases, yes, for at least some citizens.
Trade surplus is symptom, not measure of welfare.
A surplus is often taken to indicate a healthy economy, but it is not obvious how producing more than it consume makes a country better off.
Seems like the right answer to this question is: it depends.
There may be policies that reduce trade deficits and increase welfare, but most policies *designed* to reduce deficits will reduce welfare.

data.question: Lowering the effective marginal tax rate on US corporations’ repatriated profits for a year would boost US capital investment significantly.

responses.comment: Significantly unclear. Increase likely, but given limited SR opportunities, much might go to M&A or purchases/inflation of existing assets.
there's already $1t sitting domestically on corporate balance sheets not being invested. How would a tax cut to bring back even more help?
Outside my expertise. I generally favor territorial taxation.
The effects are hard to predict.  US corporations might simply repatriate the profits and increase dividends or buy back shares.
tax benefits would occur but this may not change real economic activity
A temporary change would produce far more investment in accounting methods for exploiting this than in real capital.
Might pull a little spending forward, but doubt it would genuinely increase it.
-see background information here
I suppose it's possible but the companies with the most overseas profits don't seem cash-constrained.
"Significantly" is always a difficult word.
The evidence on 04 tax holiday indicates no increase in domestic investment, R&D or jobs  (Dharmapala, Foley and Forbes, J. of Finance 2011)
Hard to see how a one-year blip in domestic cash would cause a significant change in capital budgets
Skeptical that we would see much given how much cash companies are already holding.

data.question: Permanently lowering the effective marginal tax rate on US corporations’ repatriated profits, such as by moving to a territorial-based tax system, would boost US capital investment significantly.

responses.comment: This would also divert investment abroad in a distortionary fashion. Lower corporate taxes would be more powerful.
lots of evidence both ways on this one. not sure.
see abve
US corporations might invest more abroad rather than at home. But comanies might issue equity rather than borrowing, which would be good.
Corporations find ways to bring money home without repatriation. Hodrick, SIEPR, July 2013, "Are U.S. firms really holding too much cash?"
not aware of any definitive evidence on this.
Even better would be to have no corporate income tax and to have a sufficiently progressive consumption tax, but that's wishful thinking.
Not sure about substantial, although domestic and foreign investments are probably complements (Desai et al. AEJ 2009)
Depends critically on your model of investment behavior.  I don't have one in which I am particularly confident.
Again, don't see why this would happen.

data.question: By lowering bargaining costs, fast-track negotiating authority for the president makes it more likely that the U.S. can conclude major trade deals.

responses.comment: Fast track limits the power of special interest groups.
obvious
Complicated question outside my expertise
If one party can make a take-it-or- leave-it offer to another party, a deal is often more likely than if bargaining occurs. But not always.
If president is pro-trade, the answer is yes. However, giving an anti-trade president greater powers could reduce quality of trade agreemts
-see background information here
Without something like fast track, trade deals are notoriously difficult.
Fast track reduces the number of groups that must agree to the trade pact

data.question: Past major trade deals have benefited most Americans.

responses.comment: We underestimate the costs of trade through employment (e.g. with low-wage countries in  manufacturing), net benefits still likely to be +.
Trade made certain, especially lower quality, goods cheaper but also transferred some jobs.
V likely more Americans have benefited but losses for some are substantial.  Social welfare calculations are complicated.
Wrong question-should be world welfare, not US welfare. I view policy as a citizen of the world. Trade is generally beneficial to the world.
Trade deals typically reduce barriers to trade which is likely to produce net gains to the U.S. ( although there can be winners and losers).
Most (though not all) Americans gain b/c consumption & productivity benefits outweigh loss of industry/occupation-specific human capital.
Employment adjustments may hurt some, but good policy can limit those losses in terms of duration and extent.
Trade deals are about expanding consumption choices not about jobs.  Ross Perot's giant sucking sound is a myth
-see background information here
Unfortunately, benefitting most still leaves ample room for adverse effects for some.
However we could have done more to compensate the loosers
Positive aggregate benefits does not imply that most Americans benefit, but it seems likely in this case.
The problem is that those who have been hurt have typically not been compensated.

data.question: Amazon has monopsony power in the market for books that is significantly reducing the supply of books.

responses.comment: Amazon has some monopsony power but its platform is probably making author access easier.
In general, Amazon is not using its monopsony to reduce supply. But in the case of Hachette books, it certainly is.
It seems likely that Amazon is on net raising author income in the part of the distribution where the supply restriction would be.
Seems like a matter of public record!
Amazon might instead use its market power to reduce its costs, or to limit entry by other suppliers. I need to know more to be confident.
-see background information here
Complicated issue. The main bone of contention so far has been its policy of low pricing for ebooks. Not sure of the effects on authors.
Classic monopsonists reduce supply; final prices rise. This doesn't describe Amazon.I don't know evidence that book supply is lower.
There appears to be no soundly derived empirical evidence for this claim.  I read every article related to this and its just not there.
Too many alternatives, too much potential entry.
This follows from standard textbook analysis.
Unclear what counterfactual is. Without Amazon? Or with Amazon and no market power?
Compared to no electronic market, Amazon has probably increased supply.  Compared to a "competitive electronic market," probably not.
Amazon's policies are probably reducing the supply of ebooks.
Some monopsony power, sure; significant impact on supply, possible but not especially likely.
Maybe in the future, certainly not now.
Amazon greatly increases the availability of most books, esp academic books, but is making it hard to get some books.  So how to answer?
Amazon has some monopsony power, but weak. And lower transaction costs of books on balance positive.																						-see background information here

data.question: Amazon has sufficient monopsony power that regulatory intervention is likely to make consumers of books better off, taking into account implementation costs and the effect of intervention on incentives.

responses.comment: Intervention is costly and premature. So far, book consumers have probably benefited.
Intervention could be as simple as a stern warning. At present, Amazon is heading towards a market position that is anti-competitive.
Strategic delayed shipping of books from certain publishing houses and other measures can hurt consumers.
Currently I cannot identify a specific practice that it would be sensible to address with a regulatory intervention.
Who knows what would happen, but seems unlikely to end well.
Maybe publishers and authors are those to most benefit from regulatory protection. I would need more information in order to better guess.
I don't see evidence that consumers and authors are suffering. The market is fast-moving. Regulators should monitor but be cautious.
There is evidence of higher diversity & price elasticity in online book retail so there would need to be serious evidence to offset  this.
Monopsony power helps lower Amazon's costs, enabling then to set lower consumer prices.
Unclear question. If regulation = antitrust, yes. Otherwise, probably not but unclear what that might be.
Electronic markets are full of network externalities, which should be recognized as a form of natural monopoly.
Just because there's monopsony (or monopoly) power doesn't mean there is a regulatory fix, and I don't see one here.
The press reports I have seen have not yet identified any conduct by Amazon that appears to be an antitrust violation.
Too vague to answer.  What sort of regulation?  By whom?

data.question: The most powerful force pushing towards greater wealth inequality in the US since the 1970s is the gap between the after-tax return on capital and the economic growth rate.

responses.comment: Theoretically and empirically the case that r-g is a major determinant of inequality or even top inequality is weak.																						-see background information here
Not clear yet if wealth inequality has risen in U.S: different data sources give different answers. Premature to identify cause of non-fact!
There are certainly a host of other factors related to technical change,  other government policies and globalization.
Many other factors affect inequality including technological change, globalization, increasing returns to education, and others.
MAYBE IN THE FUTURE, BUT RIGHT NOW IT IS HIGH INCOMES THAT IS INCREASING WEALTH INEQUALITY.
Don't find r-g a partiularly useful summary of anything (doesn't really capture role of technology, training, tax policy)
lower taxes on K surely play a role.  i disagree based on "most powerful" phrase.  more research is necessary
A glance at the biographies of the truly rich shows most came from upper middle class families. Good luck and some skill produced the wealth
I would imagine there are many factors: labor-saving technology, globalization,the decline of unions,lower tax rates.

Argument has poor theory & negligible empirics.  Read pp7-9 of Acemoglu & Robinson. You need not even buy into their institutional arguments																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Technology has been the primary driver.
Argument nicely destroyed by Justin Wolfers (and many others).  Too bad for the t-shirt makers																						-see background information here

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Saez-Zucman: wealth inequality shot up post 1986. Big cause: savings creates 0.4% annual wealth growth for bottom 90%, 3.4% for top 1%.																						-see background information here
Interest and growth rates are equlibrium phenomena--so even if they are important, there must be something deeper at work.
Is this an inside joke? BEA estimates show little change in rate of return.
Income and savings inequality increases are now fueling US wealth inequality. Down the road r-g will be central as predicted by Piketty
Many forces at work, both economic, social and political, making it difficult to identify one as most important.
The rapid rise in very high labor incomes seems to be much more important in the US.
Perhaps technological change, globalization, and fiscal policy matter quite a bit?!
Trends in U.S. wealth inequality are accounted for by trends in income inequality.  See Section 3 of Krugman's review of Piketty.																						-see background information here
A bug in the system prevents me from stating that I am 100% sure that I don't know the answer to this question.
Difficult claim to evaluate, because both the return and the growth rate depend on savings, and on the distribution of wealth.																						-see background information here

data.question: Letting car services such as Uber or Lyft compete with taxi firms on equal footing regarding genuine safety and insurance requirements, but without restrictions on prices or routes, raises consumer welfare.

responses.comment: Ensuring competition between various providers like Uber, Lyft, etc. is essential besides insurance and background checks for drivers.
Pretty much the same as removing the cap on the number of medallions.
Competition on quality and price helps consumers. We also have some evidence from revealed preference. Uber was popular right away.

yes. yes. a thousand times yes. 
Instead, try calling for a cab on Saturday night from the south side of Chicago and see what happens.
yes.  part of the gain in consumer welfare though comes from undermining property rights of taxi medallion owners.
Disclosure: My economist son serves in Uber's economics department.
I don't see any externalities. According to standard economics, competition enhances welfare and I believe that would be true here.
Qualification: foreigners, who tend to assume fares are regulated, can be taken advantage of without any price caps. No problem with Uber.
New technology / information more than offset any net benefits of regulation.
They innovate: e.g.knowing the rating of the driver who will come and haivng an easy way to find a lost phone after you take the ride.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Consumer welfare may rise (though difficult to measure), but it will not be a Pareto improvement for consumers, making evaluation difficult.
This is in comparison to banning these services or regulating their price to equal the price of taxis.
But Uber needs to be careful about surge pricing in emergencies,  people care about fairness as much as efficiency.
One can imagine circumstances in which this would not be true, but this is a situation in which the simple economics are very persuasive.

data.question: Although there are many issues for Scotland’s voters to consider, one consequence of separating from the rest of the UK would be greater macroeconomic instability for Scotland for many years.

responses.comment: more instabilty may be a price worth paying for independence
It depends on the exact institutional details of the separation.
Yes, but greater long-run macro instability could be merely due, as for many small countries, to less size-related diversification.
Many reasons to be uncertain, but lack of established CB institutions and the drawbacks of the euro & sterilization are reasons to agree.
no one knows
Small English-speaking countries have excellent records for macro stability.
The main uncertainty concerns whether Scotland retains the pound (bad idea) and stays in Europe( good idea). Once resolved things may be OK.
We should be uncertain. Short-term uncertainty would be high, yes, but "many years" depend on choosing sound policies for real growth.
Similar case as the EU. Shared currency is a constraint.
One major challenge would be how to handle the volatility in oil revenues.
Instability high initially, but could force left-leaning government to govern more effectively.  In medium run, may be better for Scotland.
Splitting = extreme economic pain: sharp budget adjustment needed, big monetary challenges, big financial risks, they're "better together".
This is unclear - pegging the Scottish to the English pound might essentially replicate the current state of affairs.
Macro instability will result if announced policies (currency board, nationalizations) are followed.
Scotland would be poor when their oil runs out in a few years, but stability would seem to depend on currency, EU, other uncertainties.
Change creates the potential for instability, but a floating currency with good governance could be stabilizing
Not obvious why fluctuations would be greater.  It depends also on what happens to the currency and what happens with the EU.
I suppose this is right, but there is some much uncertainty about how things would play out that I have no confidence in any predictions.

data.question: Because the US has underspent on new projects, maintenance, or both, the federal government has an opportunity to increase average incomes by spending more on roads, railways, bridges and airports. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on May 23, 2013. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: How do we know that the US has underspent? Investment will probably raise incomes for Keynesian reasons but will it promote growth?
Public infrastructure is valuable, and the premise of underspending in this area seems correct. Hence, the conclusion.
public goods matter if chosen well
seems likely  but spending not determined by costs and benefits  see innovative proposal below lots of efficiency gains w pricing policies																						-see background information here

I would say increase average welfare rather than income. There are surely many potential projects where the social benefit exceeds
cost.
In the long run.
I interpret "underspending" to mean that spending more would increase economic productivity. So, yes.
-see background information here
I would rather this be about all kinds, not just physical.
It would increase welfare; income is more difficult to assess.
Better regulation and congestion pricing would also help.
This is a no-brainer as regards roads and bridges, but the federal government doesn't do railroads and rarely if ever does airports.

data.question: Past experience of public spending and political economy suggests that if the government spent more on roads, railways, bridges and airports, many of the projects would have low or negative returns. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on May 23, 2013. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: Past evidence suggests that there will be waste and corruption (a lot of corruption!). But this does not imply that average NPV is negative.
Both public and private sector investments are risky. Some infrastructure projects will fail even when most have high social returns.
Many does not have to mean most, and on average returns may be quite positive. We just don't know enough right now.
The accounting return to the government would be low, but the total returns, include positive social spillovers, could be moderately good.
Many projects would no doubt be mistakes, but many is far from most.  Most would probably be good investments.
hard to argue with the reality that some money will end up in powerful districts without much need for it when congress controls
currently infra spending does not aim to maximize returns. c. winston research says returns are declining but more research is critical
Perhaps sometimes true in the past but I don't think it's inevitable. Projects like the interstate highways are notable exceptions.
The same is true of many investments in the private sector. Hard to imagine the government having a better record than the private sector.
Just consider the high speed rail system in California.
Depends on what many means, but the perpetual repaving of roads in Chicago is not that atypical of many public projects.
-see background information here
Poorly worded. Surely "many" out of 50K miles, but probably not "most."
I could agree with "some," but "many" is not obvious.  Also, railroads are privately funded.
Same is true for private sector!

data.question: By discounting pension liabilities at high interest rates under government accounting standards, many U.S. state and local governments understate their pension liabilities and the costs of providing pensions to public-sector workers. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on October 1, 2012. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: -see background information here
Many plans are defined benefit. These promise certain benefits, which should be discounted at the riskless interest rate not a higher rate.
see Novy Marx and Rauh for a very clear explanation of the problems																						-see background information here
Unfortunately, current spending appears to trump properly funded pensions when it comes to seeking reelection.
I understand that many state & local pensions are underfunded, but I am very uncertain as to how this was/is done.
True for some states, I don't know if it is true for "many" states.

data.question: During the next two decades some U.S. states, unless they substantially increase taxes, cut spending, and/or change public-sector pensions, will require a combination of severe austerity budgets, a federal bailout, and/or default. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on October 1, 2012. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: -see background information here
i just know too little about US finances
Likely. The need to reform depends to a large extent on economic growth in the next decade(s).
Especially if one includes health costs.
The excess liabilities are large! See the work of Josh Rauh. Something must yield: lower promises, or higher taxes, or both.
'waiting for money from tooth fairy' wasn't included on the list
Probably right. They should shift to defined contribution plans.
I don't like vague words like "severe."
Illinois is doing its best to be the first to have to face these choices.
Hope springs eternal, but the alternatives look bleak.
Clearly there is a problem, but I'm not confident that it is generally (outside of Illinois) as serious as the language implies.
Illinois is an obvious example for which this is true.

data.question: New technology for fracking natural gas, by lowering energy costs in the United States, will make US industrial firms more cost competitive and thus significantly stimulate the growth of US merchandise exports. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on May 23, 2012. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: Two caveats. How significant this effect will be is uncertain. It might have negative side effects by discouraging switch to cleaner energy.
The effect on the world price of energy is probably small and would be partly balanced by a rise in the dollar as US imports drop.
Transportation costs for natural gas are sufficient to imply that the US will face prices below the world price of energy.
The part I am uncertain about is whether lower energy costs are likely to have a significant effect on the competitiveness of U.S. exports.
Lower an input cost and produce at a lower total cost. The statement does not consider the environmental costs, which may be significant.
In a global market for energy, US and foreign manufacturing firms will ultimately face the same energy costs.
at least while our extraction technology is better than everyone else's (we're not the only ones with shale reserves)
unlikely to be significant & extent depends on export restrictions.  Welfare likely maximized with no restrictions. see below reference.																						-see background information here
I agree that energy cost should fall, which will increase U.S. competitiveness. The effects on growth are more subtle, and harder to predict
Fuel prices are largely set on a world market so the supply in any one country does not reduce its producers' input costs markedly.
I have learned that this energy source will mainly produce local gains & US manufacturers probably will benefit.  Magnitudes still uncertain
-see background information here
Definitely agree on direction, less confident about magnitudes.
Clearly will make more competitive in some sectors, but unlikely to make major impact on aggregate.
Absent frictions, prices would fall world wide.  We can expect US firms to gain from some frictions, though the magnitude is hard to assess.
Not sure about "significantly". Cost advantage will  diminish as LNG transportation infrastructure develops and export restrictions drop.
Natural gas prices are NOT determined in a world market.  Prices in the US will be cheaper than those in most nations for a long time.
Fracking will reduce energy imports and hence reduce net exports of other goods. This doesn't mean that fracking is a bad idea!
Isn't oil a global commodity?
At best a short-run and insignificant effect; prices are set in a global market.

data.question: Because of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without the stimulus bill. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on February 15, 2012. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: Can never be certain, but evidence suggests that ARRA was effective in preventing the Great Recession from being even more calamitous.
Usually, when an activity is subsidized, it increases.  Inefficiency feedback effects would need to be strong to defeat the direct effect.
There is pretty convincing empirical literature in support  Plus the budget cutting since ARRA seems related to the slow employment recovery
Given that wages/prices are sticky Keynesian-type stimulus will increase economic activity if the economy is not at full employment.
This is a very low bar
Caveat: The Fed may have pursued less unconventional stimulus (than it otherwise would have) because of the Fiscal Stimulus package.
Evidence for Keynesian channels of expansionary fiscal stimulus are weak, but the multiplier should still be positive

data.question: Taking into account all of the ARRA’s economic consequences — including the economic costs of raising taxes to pay for the spending, its effects on future spending, and any other likely future effects — the benefits of the stimulus will end up exceeding its costs. (The experts panel previously voted on this question on February 15, 2012. Those earlier results can be found here.)

responses.comment: Stimulus of this type was potentially valuable.  But I don't know much about the mechanics and efficiency of this particular program.
My results suggest that it is about a wash.  See the URL.																						-see background information here
Cumulative gap between potential & actual output much larger w/o ARRA.  But would harmful budget cutting have happened w/o ARRA?  Prob yes.																						-see background information here
Given that infrastructure expenditure was needed this was a good time to do it and so the benefits exceeded any costs.
Probably was worth it, but the political economy costs of the poor marketing and the fact that is was poorly designed have dogged it.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
This is too complicated a cost-benefit problem to assess.  I think the ARRA was a good idea, but this reflects faith rather than analysis.
Cost benefit analysis is tricky here. There were winners and losers. Still it would have been difficult to do nothing

data.question: Legislation introduced in Congress would require the Federal Reserve to "submit to the appropriate congressional committees…a Directive Policy Rule", which shall "describe the strategy or rule of the Federal Open Market Committee for the systematic quantitative adjustment of the Policy Instrument Target to respond to a change in the Intermediate Policy Inputs." Should the Fed deviate from the rule, the Fed Chair would have to "testify before the appropriate congressional committees as to why the [rule]…is not in compliance." Enacting this provision would improve monetary policy outcomes in the U.S.

responses.comment: Given the increasingly important and discretionary role the Fed plays, supervision is essential. Congress may not be the right body to do it
Preserving the Fed's autonomy is valuable. Imagine if Congress had been running the Fed during the Financial Crisis --- certain disaster!
Rules are very useful, but one has to be careful not undermine central bank's independence, which untie central banks from political cycle.
The Fed's track record in economic policy-making, while imperfect, is vastly superior to that of Congress.
Such a policy would undermine the independence of the Federal Reserve.
A quantitative formula is not flexible in the face of structural changes, and reduces Fed independence too much. Clear goals are enough.
Monetary policy should be based on a target for inflation and unemployment (such as difference between the two) not on an instrument rule																						-see background information here
No rules would have allowed the Fed to act appropriately in the recent crisis. Better to choose governors well and give them discretion.
Would not have stopped Nixon-Burns inflation. Greenspan had infinite ability to obfuscate. Do we want Congress defining deviations?
Data revisions alone cast doubt on this.  Instead let's raise the qualifications and pay of who we appoint.  Read this bill, very quirky.																						-see background information here
Too narrow and likely to compromise Fed independence.  Something like Norway's Central Bank reports (see p.18-19) could be more useful.																						-see background information here
Such legislation seems likely to compromise the Fed's political independence.
Has tendency to politicize monetary policy and to promote inflexibility.
The essence of the Fed is to be independent.  Congressional meddling is not a set forward.
Not a hard call.
The Fed has served Americans very well over many decades; meddling by politicians would worsen the performance of the Fed and the economy.
Under current Fed leadership, the statement is likely to be false. Under future leadership, accountability might be justifiable.
A central bank should be independent.  Look at Argentina as an example of where political oversight leads.
I can't think of any agency in government that would work better with greater supervision from Congress

data.question: All else equal, Patent Assertion Entities — which specialize in acquiring and asserting patents and are popularly known as “patent trolls" — promote innovation in the U.S.

responses.comment: It creates incentives for many spurious patents that might actually block innovation.
Allowing more competition for patent rights is good, but frictions in that market might suggest barring trolls. I'm uncertain.
No definitive evidence but available evidence points negative.  See references																						-see background information here
If  patents are correctly  granted trolls can encourage innovation.  if patents are incorrectly granted trolls can impede innovation.
This may just be rent seeking but how can this activity be prevented without destroying the transferability of patents, a form of property?
-see background information here
Conclusive evidence is difficult to come by, but there appears to be no evidence that they have a positive effect.
Not simple.  Probably encourages independent inventors & small firms, but their weak-basis lawsuits are a tax on other innovators.
Patent trolls pay for patents, which encourages innovation, but they obviously also suppress future innovation
In some fields they seem to impede innovation.  I applaud Tesla's recent decision to release all their patents.

data.question: Within the software industry, the US patent system makes consumers better off than they would be in the absence of patents.

responses.comment: A lot of the open source software has been hugely influential.
The usual incentive-for-innovation justification for patent protection seems to apply here, as in many other markets.
There is a lot of room for improvement of the current system, but without any patents at all, there would be no incentives to innovate.
-see background information here
Patents can encourage innovation. But many trivial software patents seem to be granted, which can discourage innovation and hurt consumers.
Example: Economists oppose software development in economics. Innovation would be further reduced if there were no financial returns.
-see background information here
Open source is at least a viable alternative.  Patents have advantages, but their net effect is unclear.
A sensible system for software patens would clearly be better than nothing.  The current system?  Not so clear.
Very much a quantitative question.
This is the domain in which the patent system seems to be in most need of reform.

data.question: There is a social value to having institutions that issue liquid liabilities that are backed by illiquid assets.

responses.comment: To do this well requires sufficient risk absorbing capital.
Of course, but not if they make the whole system riskier. I dont know how to judge this at this level of generality.
The creation of credit-based money in this form facilitates payments, serving markets in a basic way that would be hard to replace.
depends on alternatives considered in the question.
Maturity transformation has its place; the devil is in the details.
I understand "liquid" here to mean safe more than low transaction cost.
Consumers want liquid and safe securities. Firms' assets are often illiquid. Both sides can benefit if firms issue shares and senior debt.
"Social value" is odd wording.  However, such institutions are likely to make markets more efficient by relaxing undue liquidity constraints

That is why narrow banking is a mistake. If we ban this, it will move to the shadow banking system.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
-see background information here
Such institutions can also impose social costs.  If done well, the benefits outweigh the costs.  The trick is to ensure this is the case.
Gains from trade. Yes, I am assuming such institutions are suitably regulated.
Captured very nicely by the Diamond-Dybvig (1983) model and others																						-see background information here
Bills of exchange and other "liquid asset" go back many centuries.

data.question: Employers that discriminate in hiring will be at a competitive disadvantage, if their customers do not care about their mix of employees, compared with firms that do not discriminate.

responses.comment: The only caveat is that if other employees have a taste for discrimination, they may take costly actions against the hiring of minorities.
Discriminating firms pay higher wages and draw from a smaller labor pool, raising labor costs. See Becker, The Economics of Discrimination
This outcome requires more than a lack of concern by customers.
I believe it in theory but I'm aware of no direct evidence after all these years.
Unless there are workers who will prefer to be at a firm that is dominated by their ethnic group
Though, as a number of authors have shown, prejudice can indeed survive in the labor market in the long run.																						-see background information here
It depends on who they discriminate against.  The disadvantage could be  de minimus.  Or, it could be an advantage in some cases.
One can think of special circumstances where this conclusion, due to passing on best workers, does not follow, but they're not general.
Depends on some subtle issues. Discrimination may results mainly in segregation under some conditions.
They would earm more if they did not discriminate unless their other workers are prejudiced. But they may survive anyway if they earn rents.
One can imagine cases where employees care and discriminate. It could (unfortunately) benefit the firm, since customers don't care.
You want to employ the best workers to maximize profits.
-see background information here
Presumably yes if discrimination lowers wages of the discriminated group to levels below what equally productive workers make.																						-see background information here
It is an empirical question whether this disadvantage will overcome taste for discrimination, and whether markets will eliminate such firms.
This disadvantage will be smaller if workers are also prejudiced.
Seems to depend on the circumstances.  For example, the preferences of the incumbent workforce would seem to matter to the employer.
See The Economics of Discrimination; Gary S. Becker; Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1957.
But only suffer if there are enough non-discriminating firms.

data.question: Rising market wages are an important reason — over and above any changes in medical technology, social norms or preferences — why family sizes have fallen over the past century in rich countries.

responses.comment: I would have emhasized rising women's employment opportunities
So says the literature in economic history.
Probably, but not clear how much is causal.
turns out that it takes a lot of time to raise a kid these days
Certainly this is not a theorem--it depends on preferences and technology-- income versus substitution effects.
Ths substitution effect goes this way, but the income effect can go in the opposite direction: with more income you can afford more children
This is an ill-posed question as I told the organizers. No good economist should answer it.  Should have been in productivity not wages.
We do not have strong evidence on this. Rising FEMALE wages matter. Also rising costs of education, housing.
-see background information here
I get the theory, but I don't know how one can support a judgment about importance.
See "On the Interaction between the Quantity and Quality of Children." Gary S. Becker and H. Gregg Lewis; JPE, 1973, 81.
Might be U shaped

data.question: Considering both distributional effects and changes in efficiency, it is a good idea to let companies that send video or other content to consumers pay more to Internet service providers for the right to send that traffic using faster or higher quality service.

responses.comment: High bandwidth traffic imposes externalities on other users.
Net neutrality is a fiction. Hire Akamai (et al.) to mirror your servers worldwide to speed content to your users. One user: Healthcare.gov!																						-see background information here
I worry it will crowd out the public goods that make the internet uniquely valuable unless bandwidth gets so cheap that it doesn't matter.
This might lead to better allocation but also opens the room for price discrimination. The implications for the consumers are not obvious.
Regs have to address vertical price squeeze motivated price discrimination.
The broadband industry does not seem to be very competitive, so allowing it to charge more to content providers may not improve the market.
If all qualities sell at the same price, markets cannot allocate quality efficiently. Works for soap, wine, and haircuts; why not Internet?
Faster service is valuable and this is one way we may get it but adverse effects are also possible.
did any else notice how slippery this hill we are camping on seems?
there is an obvious potential efficiency gain but there is also potential for a harmful "vertical price squeeze".  net effect is unclear.
This is a total side issue. The central issue is the perennial last-mile problem--the market power of the cable and phone companies.
Letting price vary with quality is good if there is enough competition. I don't know if that's true here. If not the answer is less clear.
Answer obvious on efficiency grounds. On distribution, use other means to redistribute to poor--not covert internet cross subsidization.
Clear gain to providing faster service at higher costs. Uncertain comes from potential GE effects in reducing access for those unable to pay
Presumably creates strong incentives for vertical integration.  Not clear if that is good or not.
-see background information here
This would be a great idea if the market for service provision was competitive, but is less obvious with our current market.
In the absence of robust competition in broadband, regulation is needed to help new applications, services and content.
It is not generally good policy to restrict firms' product offerings, but there seem to be other considerations.
Clearly winners and losers from this policy and clearly the market is imperfect.  This is a hard call
Seems like those who cause congestion should pay more. I know some worry that ISPs will play favorites, but that should be preventable.
Net neutrality has worked well, and likely maximizes welfare in the short-run. Longer-term investment incentives are the counter-argument.																						-see background information here

data.question: The recent oversubscribed debt issues of Greece and Portugal suggest that sovereign default by any euro area country is unlikely in the foreseeable future.

responses.comment: These are small countries. Its not too likely but not impossible that a bigger country will hit some political shocks. Then all bets are off
Uncertainties in emerging markets helped European bond issuancesy. Many unforeseen events can can easily worsen the current situation.
There is increased demand for many sorts of weak debt. Peripheral EUR sovereigns are in the long run still exposed to structural weaknesses.
The ECB seems to have organized a good equilibrium--see the paper by Krishnamurthy, Nagel, and Vissing-Jorgensen																						-see background information here
These econonomies still in bad shape. Bond yields high, but Investors may be exuberant and overestimating chance of future bailouts.
Greece's debt is still unsustainable & Europe's banks are undercapitalized.  Until that changes risks remain.																						-see background information here
Sovereign bond yields and credit default spreads imply that default is a nontrivial possibility, but the more likely outcome is no default.																						-see background information here
Reduced from 2-3 years ago, but  still a fragile system.
Markets may believe default unlikely over the term of the bonds. That does not mean it is unlikely forever: Greek debt is still huge.
Default looks less likely, but structural problems in the euro zone remain, and much has yet to transpire before default is truly unlikely.
Low rates also reflect expectations of an ECB QE.
Not my field, but this seems to be basing a strong conclusion on a weak evidentiary foundation.
Encouraging but I am wary of generalizing to all Euro area countries.
It's hard to argue that markets are mis-pricing Euro area bonds, but I'm surprised by how strongly the price has recovered
The ECB seems committed to averting defaults.
I thought we had learned the lesson that low interest rates do not assure low risk.

data.question: If the NCAA let colleges pay athletes with more than scholarships (which currently may cover tuition, books, room and board), then top colleges in men’s basketball and football would pay most athletes substantial sums beyond full scholarships.

responses.comment: If colleges commit when the student joins (bidding on transfers not allowed) the earnings effect will be small. Too much uncertainty at 17
The million dollar (and often multi million dollar) salaries of top basketball coaches in NCAA basketball testify to the value of winning.
Most atheletes, or superstar atheletes?
the best athletes at the best D-1 schools would obviously be paid a lot
& would be a series of distributional issues affecting non-revenue men's and women's sports who have largely benefited from cross subsidies
Star basketball and football players, for sure. Historically, this has been happening through alumni off-campus deals and the like.
Since the stakes are high, the incentive to pay top athletes a lot is strong. Preserving equity among students is a small mitigating force.
Athletes will receive more money but it is not clear that there can be big gaps between the money sports and other sports.
Players get few rents now.  That would change for sure
-see background information here
Schools are not afraid to spend money to win at football & basketball - look at coaching salaries.
"Most" probably wrong, but likely see the superstar compensation phenomenon, with some million dollar athletes.
One would surely expect the athletes to capture some of surplus, just as baseball players did when the reserve clause was eliminated.
Some schools would clearly pay some athletes a good deal more, but I have a hard time with "most."
There is a great deal of evidence that individual colleges would pay athletes more if allowed.
Some would get paid substantial salaries. Unclear if  median athlete would be helped. There are probably some cross subsidies today.
Presumably this is the definition of "top colleges in ... ."
Pay would go up for stars, unless the schools could collude, as they do now. More interesting question: should the athletes be paid? Yes
There is a regular parade of recruiting violations in the face of potentially harsh penalties. The only question is if it would be "most".

data.question: Past experience suggests that economic sanctions do little to deter the target countries from their course of action.

responses.comment: This is true for limited sanctions being imposed on Russia. Much more comprehensive sanctions as in South Africa or Iran would be effective.
Not a good experiment, but sanctions appear effective sometimes, e.g., Iran, South Africa.
I think a part of what made Iran come to bargaining table has to do with the sanctions, though I have no way to  prove this.
Sanctions bite often only with a long delay and the effectiveness depends on the circumanstances. (South Africa and Iran vs. North Korea)
I waver between uncertain and agree. Much depends on the form of the sanctions, the behavior they're designed to deter, etc.
often do little, but can deter if significant and applied effectively
"Course of action" is vague. Sanctions & their threat alter the calculus by raising costs & thus affect decisions.   but not a cure all
Not acquainted with the evidence.
My sense is that economic sanctions were important in ending apartheid in South Africa, and are leading Iran to negotiate with the West.
Depends on country, its trade, its politics. Also, sanctions that are initially apparently ineffective can gradually undermine a regime.
Sanctions are signals. Putin would be surprised if NATO said nothing about Crimea, and might read it as a green light to be more aggressive.
Hard to design & sustain in a way that ends up only harming the offender.  Better to boycott the world cup in Russia +embarass FIFA too!
It surely works sometimes (e.g. against the Apartheid regime).  Restrictions on Odious Debt could also help, though NA for Russia today.																						-see background information here
I'm no expert on this, but Int. Relations literature seems to conclude sanctions often don't work that well.																						-see background information here
Referring to economic or political sanctions.
We have evidence both ways - sanctions of Myanmar and North Korea have accomplished little, while sanctions on Iran may be useful.
I'm sure there are exceptions, but not many.
Effectiveness must depend on the openness of the target economy and the uniformity of the application of sanctions
I don't trust my memory to run a mental regression with sanctions on the right hand side.  In principle, there should be sanctions that work
The evidence is that sanctions can be effective, particularly when the goal is limited.																						-see background information here

data.question: A market that allows payment for human kidneys should be established on a trial basis to help extend the lives of patients with kidney disease.

responses.comment: Not enough info to answer. Not in favor of a kidney market that sells to highest bidder. Other ideas maybe. Question is not actionable.
That would mean valuing people's lives by their incomes.  We already do that but moving further in that direction seems wrong.
It is important that the market is "well regulated" in order to avoid abuse and exploitation of the vulnerables.
This certainly may have unintended consequences but it is hard to fault attempting to create more supply.
Under strong governance that mitigates exploitation, this market may save lives on mutually consenting terms.
Dangerous ground, but a well-regulated experiment could be beneficial.  Payments to fill out donor cards might increase supply, for example
A market with or without subsidies for low income patients?
Hard to know because we don't have much of an understanding of why people make organ gifts.
I'd like to see it but I'm not sure the public is ready. Also would insurance cover this? Would people be able to top up (presumably)?
Would improve allocative efficiency but means- and health-conditioned vouchers would presumably have to be used to address ethical concerns.
There is no reason to block this voluntary exchange. There may be unique challenges in applying laws against fraud, but nothing too hard.
Perhaps experiments in different regimes better idea.
We need to rationalize our organ allocation mechanism, but a market is not the only way, and is not obviously the best way.
How to deal with donors who don't understand risks, increased incentives to steal & import, perceived inequities...?  Not simple.
Experiments seem valuable here, using health outcomes as our metric. Matching donors and recipients based in part on payment may be helpful.
The biggest impact would be to increase kidney supply, so few obvious losers from this policy
It would surely save lives of those with kidney disease.  It would probably have unintended consequences as well.
How should we incorporate the fact that nearly all non-economists hate this idea?  Do we declare them wrong and proceed?

As an economist, I strongly agree that there would be tremendous gains. But I'm uncertain of the appropriate bounds on market transactions.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here

data.question: Advancing automation has not historically reduced employment in the United States.

responses.comment: Temporarily yes. Over the long run, no. Labor force participation has risen throughout most of the 20th century.
It is not easy to find evidence one way or the other that it did not shift the aggregate labor demand curve down.
new employment opportunities opened up e.g. in the service sector.
Over the long run, that is true
There has been temporary displacement but displaced workers have found jobs elsewhere, as theory might predict
Hard to be certain b/c a GE issue, but little econ history supports mechanization having reduced employment.
Productivity increases options. Employment becomes more beneficial, but it is irrelevant if people choose to work less.
Automation has increased greatly over last 100 years.  Employment has increased.  Labor participation rates have varied.
To a first order approximation.																						-see background information here
Really would say unemployment. Otherwise need to incorporate income effects.
Automation can cause significant displacement and can require costly adjustments, but has not reduced long-run employment.
Automation has  not reduced net employment, but some workers have lost their jobs due to automation
If this had been true over the last two centuries, almost no one would be working anymore.
Mixed effects across the distribution of skills																						-see background information here

data.question: Information technology and automation are a central reason why median wages have been stagnant in the US over the past decade, despite rising productivity.

responses.comment: Technology and trade/globalization are probably two largest factors. Would also include deunionization.
There are so many other factors including trade (including in services).
Winner-takes-it-all technologies are more prevelant than only in IT. Moreover, globalization (containers), ... are also important factors.
Rising health care costs may actually be more important for the median worker.
They are A reason, among others.  And a reason is not the same as a result; there could have been offsetting policy/policies.
Question is too broad.
Stagnant education levels and the financial crisis are almost certainly culprits.  Work on assigning shares will go on for a long time.
Unskilled jobs have been lost which may well be a factor, although not the only one, behind stagant median income and increasing inequality
Skill biased tech probably a cause of flat median wages,but there are MANY other causes. GE problems like this cannot be sorted definitively
It may have a short-run impact but there is no reason to believe that it is permanent.
IT and automation have helped the "top 1%."  Not clear what that has done to median relative to financial crisis, government policy, etc.
-see background information here
Many other factors going on.
Trade is likely also important for median wages.
The wage distribution has expanded and compressed over long periods. Technology is probably, involved, but it is unclear exactly how.

data.question: Future innovations worldwide will not be transformational enough to promote sustained per-capita economic growth rates in the U.S. and western Europe over the next century as high as those over the past 150 years.

responses.comment: The right answer is "uncertain". But "disagree" emphasizes that the view that we are running out of ideas, which has little basis.
Technical innovation will continue to be rapid, but resource and environmental constraints in a crowded world will hinder per capita growth.
That's a ridiculously high bar to cross, since no other period in human history has ever seen anything like the last 150 years!
The average per capita growth rate over the last 150 years only 1.7-1.8% which would not need to transformative innovations to happen.
genomics, robotic, communication.... Emerging economies will increasingly contribute to global R&D spending with positive spillover effects.
The answer is certainly uncertain
The long term declining is very worrying. But it also might be that we are not measuring quality or new goods well.
Hard to predict 100 years ahead.
i'm unaware of any serious evidence that would help one formulate a reliable opinion.
The cone of dispersion for productivity forecasts is so wide that no such statement has any support. Che sera, sera.
Economists are bad at predicting the far future. Technological advances have been amazing in the last few years and anything is possible.
I am certain that anyone sensible should be uncertain. If one can predict innovation well, one should not be an economist but an inventor.
Innovation need not slow. The vast changes in what we consume and how we work make "income" a poor measure of wellbeing over a century.
Last 150 years have seen huge increases in living standards.  Similar future increases an even bet given IT revolution and human ingenuity.
We would have never forecast most the past breakthroughs, no reason to think we are any better at doing so now.  No way this is knowable.
-see background information here
Wow - tough question. Maybe if the answer is a clear no, we can reconvene the panel in 150 years to discuss.
Who knows?
Uncertaint = unpredicatable. The unpredictability of fundamental invention is amply demonstrated from theory and history.
Unimagined innovations have revolutionized life in the past, and I suspect they will continue to do so.
The surprises of the last 150 years should make clear the folly of trying to forecast the next 150.
History suggests optimism, but 150 years is a mighty long time.
Very hard to predict this far in the future.
Views on this are pure speculation.  There is no economic theory or empirical evidence to inform the issue.
I don't know how anyone could have any confidence in this sort of prediction.  Good that no one can be proven wrong.
Billions of people escaping poverty unleashes billions of minds for innovation. Hence my optimism. But tempered with much uncertainty.

data.question:
Informed postmortems of Ben Bernanke’s Fed chairmanship will
judge favorably the Fed's creative and aggressive policy initiatives
from autumn 2008 through early 2009.

responses.comment: This is hearsay because I don't "do" monetary policy. But everything I've read says that Ben was extraordinarily creative and effective.
He had to find creative ways to get around a number of institutional constraints to do the  needful and he did
The ultimate judgement will depend on the exit strategy and how easily the fed will return to a more rule-based policy.
I don't like the "informed postmortems" part.  There is little agreement in macro.
Strong action as a lender of last resort was essential. This is what central banks do. In this instance, innovation by the Fed was crucial.
Future views of the past are hard to predict with precision.  That said, things would probably have been much worse without the Feds actions
Fed could have been even more aggressive.  Could have recognized problems in shadow banking system earlier.  But hindsight is 20/20.
Let's see how the unwinding works.  Also, some of the policies had bad income-distribution consequences and some were fiscal policies.
No Ben, no avoiding depression. Full stop.
The counterfactual state of the world with muted, Fed responses is an ugly one.
Generally true. Some doubts about whether it would have been possible to impose haircuts on debtholders rather than use public funds.
A policy where the Fed let financial institutions go bankrupt or helped home-owners directly might have been better, but we will never know
In retrospect, some responses seem prescient, others misguided or based on false premises.  Phil Swagel's paper is a great read on this.																						-see background information here
It is hard to have confidence on this opinion. It is difficult to predict how history will play out; this is not just "economic" predictions
The financial crisis was a solvency crisis.  The Bernanke (and Paulson) actions were instrumental in keeping the financial sector solvent.
Public may not appreciate this, but Bernanke's Fed helped stave off Depression 2.0.  Record before and after will be more controversial.
-see background information here
We'll never know the counterfactual, but there is reason to believe that Ben Bernanke helped avert disaster, despite an ineffective Congress
Important not to forget how dire the situation was at that time.
More subjective than most questions. Likely that economists will disagree about this in the future. But I judge Bernanke's actions favorably
Bernanke understood very well the policy errors of the Fed during the Great Depression and had the courage to avoid repeating them.
Hard to predict what hindsight will suggest, but it think he did well in extremely difficult times.

data.question: Using surge pricing to allocate transportation services — such as Uber does with its cars — raises consumer welfare through various potential channels, such as increasing the supply of those services, allocating them to people who desire them the most, and reducing search and queuing costs.

responses.comment: Price responses to predictable surges (New Years) make sense.
Amazing that more things aren't price this way -- they should be.
Answer depends on particular market. Competition might be too limited on days with low supply and customers might be "taken for a ride."
Welfare-reducing price discrimination outcomes are feasible, but the increase in supply in this example clearly enhances consumer welfare.
Mostly agree, but watch out for increasing the prices of subways and buses at times when lots of people want to ride them.
Efficiency is NOT the same as welfare! This is probably a good policy, but some people will lose.
This is basic microeconomics. Pricing different services differently improves the allocation of services, assuming no serious externalities.
I know it pisses people off but it is true
It is critical that the prices are transparent.  Possible that redistribution goals are harmed but it is inefficient means to redistribute
Real-time market clearing pricing is gaining ground, over fierce opposition from all but a small band of economists and entrepreneurs.
Consumer plus producer surplus should rise but in the absence of competition consumer surplus may not. With competition consumers will gain.
I have first hand experience.  Faced with long airport taxi lines late in the evening, the extra amount to use Uber is a bargain.
The alternative is standing in the rain or waiting forever at rush hour, sometimes paying the premium is just much better
As long as it doesn't make them angry.																						-see background information here
Allocation efficiency improves but there are gainers and losers and a "welfare" assessment depends on how one weights individual outcomes.
Surge pricing enhances efficiency, for the reasons listed.  Efficiency is not the only goal; anti-gouging laws reflect other worthy goals.
Uber is making a market, so this question just asks whether having price change to balance supply and demand is a good thing.
Uber's ability to increase supply in the short run appears small so price increase may be mostly a transfer to Uber.
Designed to get us in trouble with non-economist family and friends! It's not as simple as we teach in Intro; but claim is mostly true.

data.question: Giving specific presents as holiday gifts is inefficient, because recipients could satisfy their preferences much better with cash.

responses.comment: the choice of the gift giver is a signal of intensity of search effiort
Cash is more efficient in a narrow sense, but holiday gift exchanges are about interpersonal relationships.
Clearly true if one ignores the pleasure one may get in choosing or receiving specific gifts.  Only in some cases are these factors minimal.
Are you serious? Presents serve multiple interpersonal purposes. Revealed preference indicates that income transfer is not the primary one.
Depends on goal: may have goal (like create emotional connection through item - as if economists had emotions!) not achievable with cash.
Giving a present gives one an occssion to think about the recipient. The effort one puts into buying can be an important signal as well.
it's the thought (identifying the right present) that matters! In addition money lacks the surprise element.
Of course does not consider receiver's joy of giving, etc:
Gifts serve many functions such as signalling regard and demonstrating social ties with the recipient.  Cash transfers don't do this as well
I don't want to be a scrooge!
This is the sort of narrow view that rightly gives economics  bad name.
A large benefit is the pleasure of choosing something special for the receiver. Maybe one's hand-knit socks are more fun to give than cash!
"It is the thought that counts" has more truth than some allow.  Gifts are more than things.
Implications of a specific gift (signal it sends, behavioral impact) may give additional utility to either the giver or receiver.
The act of giving or receiving gifts can add value to the gifts.
Instead of proposing to your wife w/diamond ring, you offer a gift card of equal value. Efficient--if you don't count your hospital bills.
generally agree but exposes neoclassical econ limitations bc it excludes utility from gift giver or recipient choosing/receiving a gift.
Giver informs receiver of novel experience. And (John Solow) giver can't enjoy directly, but only with participation of receiver (jewelry)																						-see background information here
An assistant might prefer cash. For a friend a present that shows that you have thought about what matters to them might mean much more.
Recipients often want to know that the giver spent time thinking about the gift and acquiring it. Giving cash is too easy in their eyes.
In some cases, non-pecuniary values are important, but in general, the statement is true.
Motivation for the present has to be non-monetary -- but try giving your spouse cash!
I know the argument (see link), but a costly signal can be worthwhile.																						-see background information here
Only an economist could think like this.
Disagree because the value is the thought behind selecting the present, not the cash involved. So true for thoughtless presents.
The judgment would seem to depend on the giver's motivation.
Gift giving is a form of communication.  Comparing the gift to what the recepient would purchase with cash misses the esssence of gifts.
Generally, of course.  But shopping takes time, and some gifts you would never have shopped for turn out to satisfy unsuspected preferences.
Balderdash. This narrow notion of "efficiency" -- and what life is about -- gives economists a bad name.  Here's to the winter solstice.
Many reasons why gifts may be better than cash. Signaling thoughtfulness. Specialized knowledge of giver. Gifts from travels...
For many (most?) gifts, "efficiency" is not the point.
Is this a trivial price theory quiz or an interesting behavioral question.? To test price theory, try a cash gift next Valentine's day.
Bah, humbug.  Such a claim takes an oversimplified model too seriously. Gifts can serve many purposes.

data.question:
The average US citizen would be better off if a
larger number of low-skilled foreign workers were legally allowed to enter the
US each year.

responses.comment: Real income of avg the American would rise, but social strains and inequality would also increase.
The median US worker (which is how I interpret the word average) is high skill by global standards
It depends on whether one takes a long or short-term horizon.
I think it matters a lot whether or not they are granted citizenship which we are not told.
Labor is a valuable factor input. My answer presumes that many of these new workers would be employed. But I'm not confident of that.
This would drive down the cost of a variety of services.
"Average US citizen?" What does this mean.  Unskilled natives likely to be worse off, skilled native better off. Who's average?
If only workers are admitted, we come out ahead because of tax revenue. But it's not so obvious if they bring their families and relatives.
On average citizens would be better off--by classical gains from trade . A countervailing effect : welfare payments to unemployed immigrants
I am sure that I am uncertain. A certain answer would require a knowledge of general eqm effects on which we've only a partial grasp.
Free trade is as good as migration for traded goods. The impact on nongraded goods is unclear, as are the burdens on social programs.
But the gains to immigrants would be large.																						-see background information here
Card's Ely lecture argues wage effects are small. Pro-immigration arguments partly about welfare of immigrants, rather than residents.																						-see background information here
This response is based on the idea that it will increase inequality, which is already too great.
There will be gains and losses of various types to various people; it is difficult to reduce these to a net effect on an average citizen.
Very unclear how to think about the "average" citizen when there would likely be winners and losers.
Substituting legal immigration for illegal immigration would enhance efficiency and equity.
For low skill workers, the main adverse effects are through wages. For high skill, through fiscal costs. Both costs could be small
The evidence is that complementarities would make most Americans better off.  The data is not decisive, though.

data.question:
Unless they were compensated by others, many
low-skilled American workers would be substantially worse off if a larger
number of low-skilled foreign workers were legally allowed to enter the US each
year.

responses.comment: I agree that the effect would be negative, but believe that it would be modest, not substantial.
It all turns on what fraction of low skilled US workers don't have an option that they clearly prefer to these mostly dead end low paid jobs
A higher number of workers of the same type seeking jobs would lower their average wages or employment rate, other things equal.
Those who compete with low skill immigrants will be hurt by extra competition.
"substantially" is probably too strong.
My understanding is that the Mariel question is still up in the air in terms of serious research.
There can be winners and losers. Similarly skilled workers will face greater competition for jobs and their wages may fall.
Low-skilled workers would probably be worse off but positive gen eqm effects might offset negative direct effects.
It is hard to see how they would benefit, and they would lose from the competition in the labor market.
I believe the evidence show that some low-skilled natives suffer, but whether many suffer substantially not clear given what I know on this
-see background information here
Again, Card's work suggests this is not obvious, although one might expect increased labor market competition.
"Substantially" is a vague term, but on the whole it would probably lower incomes at the bottom.
These are the most likely candidates for people who will be adversely affected.
Substituting legal for illegal immigration could provide benefits to low-skilled workers generally, for both economic and political reasons.
Evidence that immigration pushes down low skill wages is mixed
No way to answer this without knowing the definition of "many" and "substantially" plus some facts.
The "many" is the problem: some would certainly be hurt (unless compensated).   But "many"?

data.question: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by choosing a well-diversified, low-cost index fund than by picking a few stocks.

responses.comment: Stock picker bears a lot of idiosyncratic risk
"Better" is delightfully vague.
Sounds like a trick question! This one is obvious: diversification is a big benefit, even putting aside fee savings.
The typical investor is certainly best off buying a low-cost indexed fund.  That said, money may be makable without inside information.
(DUH)
In equilibrium the typical investor cannot beat the market. Thus a well-diversified buy and hold strategy is best for such an investor
There is ample empirical evidence for this claim.
Almost everyone should be investing in this way and ignoring tips from friends and experts on particular stocks.
Keepi the expense ratio down!																						-see background information here
Key words here are "in general" - most people are unlikely to replicate Warren Buffett's performance.
Literally, "expected" return may be higher than for diversfied basket, despite higher variance. Does "do better" include pain of variance?
Picking a few stocks makes sense only if one has better information than the market, which is unlikely without inside information.
Not a great question: "a few stocks" might hit it big, "do better than" and "in general" are not well-defined.
Diversification rocks.  Perhaps there are some exceptions for some investors, e.g., based on a tax angle.
Aggregate stock returns have some forecastibility, but this is a question about individual stocks
You could do the diversification and periodic rebalancing yourself, and perhaps save a few dollars in transaction costs, but why bother?
The annual test to see whether panelists are awake.
Unless, of course, you *like* the thrill of gambling.

data.question: Enactment of the Senate bill to subject the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and discount window decisions to an audit by the Comptroller General of the U.S. would improve the Fed's legitimacy without hurting its decision making.

responses.comment: The bill will reduce the policy independence of the Fed.
It is important for the Fed to be able to operate with a minimum of political interference.
This depends on whether the audit is used to reduce the discretion of the Fed when acting within its mandate. I would need some specifics.
Um, have you seen how it has worked in countries with political oversight of monetary policy decisions?
The existing system of an independent Fed acting with finality has worked well. There's nothing to be gained from such an audit.
This looks like an attempt at facilitating more political interference with Fed policy.
The point of this bill is to dial back central independence.  Abundant evidence suggests worse monetary policy will follow if it is enacted.
This could work in principle, but generally more Central Bank independence has led to better decisions.																						-see background information here
Don't know enough about the bill to have a particularly strong view.
Hard to see any effect on its legitimacy or effectiveness.
Central bank independence is important.
It seems like a dangerous reduction in fed autonomy.

data.question: The Fed should not reduce its purchases of mortgage-backed securities and treasurys until there is clearer evidence of strong and sustained employment growth.

responses.comment: Quantitative easing has had to substitute for fiscal stimulus in this recovery, so it should not be ended while it is still needed.
Judging when the marginal cost of "exit" risks exceeds the marginal stimulative benefits is difficult with only the data available to me.
The economy isn't strong yet.
5 years of growth at 2%, unemployment around or above 7.5% and core inflation well below the target says DO NOT TIGHTEN.
Risk w Fed's strategy but we are far below potential output  Effect on int rates of tapering culd be large, see May-June int rate increase
The Fed has responsibility for controlling inflation. Though quite unlikely, the Fed might need to contract if inflation surged.
Benefits of more QE now seems small.  QE won't cause inflation, but the forward guidance cum QE is creating some financial stability risk.																						-see background information here
But I am worried about it may be coming at the cost of misallocation.																						-see background information here
Caveat: how big an effect these purchases are actually having on employment is not that clear to me.
I interpret this as saying that should continue until are on trajectory that would lead to high employment in 2-3 years.
The question is somewhat vague: clearer than what?  Consistency in policy is important, so continuing is probably useful.

data.question: Allowing Internet service providers to charge content companies for access to the ISPs' customers would provide net benefits to consumers.
