responses.comment: There is theory that goes both ways on this.  Vertical price squeeze for integrated sellers a potential concern.																						-see background information here
Another one of these questions that appears to refer to average effects only
could easily lead to high transaction costs particularly for small players and confusion among consumers about what they get access to.
If distribution gains market power, toll takers on the Internet could Balkanize it (w/large aggregate welfare loss)
-see background information here
Internet transport charges are negotiated bilaterally, so such charges already occur, along with many other factors that affect prices
curious to see what the IO mavens say about this.
-see background information here
Haven't gotten into the details of this debate, but given carrier concentration, not obvious that consumers would benefit.
The additional incentive to provide bandwidth would be a plus, but the static misallocation from this type of monopoly pricing may be larger																						-see background information here

data.question: If the United States fails to make scheduled interest or principal payments on government debt securities, even as an unintended consequence of political brinksmanship, US families and businesses are likely to suffer severe economic harm.

responses.comment: Treasury markets  are directly affected, raising US and other borrowing costs.  Recipients of federal payments impaired,  with a multiplier
Hard to know consequences of something this unprecedented
"Severe" is uncertain, but "harm" will be significant. Extent of financial disruptions are hard to predict. Length of default will matter.
Unlikely, if they pay a week later.
This is unknown, of course, but there seems to be decent probabilities on bad stuff happening.  It would be a self-inflicted wound.
Poor question. The federal govt could make its interest payments on current debt even if the debt ceiling were not raised.
Don't know the effect on the market's long-run trust in the US. It may tolerate a few defaults, but don't know how many. Default is risky.
this would put our status as reserve currency in play; there would probably be forced selling. All bad.
-see background information here
Financial turmoil and a higher interest rate on the huge debt will harm everyone.
Giving away the status of "risk free" to make a political point is the height of stupidity.

data.question: With or without a default, current uncertainty over future taxing and spending policies of the US government is likely to depress private investment and hiring by enough to reduce GDP growth by at least a quarter of a percentage point over the next 12 months.

responses.comment: I don't have a way to estimate the magnitude of the loss. It is significant, but could be on either side of the indicated amount.
Stock market has not gone down, so it seems that people are not too worried yet.
I'm confident that the uncertainty is not increasing GDP but the magnitude of the loss is very very difficult to estimate.
Odd q! Paying for entitlement prgm liabilities over LT a big problem for econ grwth but ST effects of ST uncertainty not easily quantified.
magnitude is unsure but the direction is surely correct and my guess is that the magnitude is above 0.25.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Close call about how much, but 1/4 point seems a reasonable central guess assuming debt limit resolved before D-day and shutdown < 2 weeks
The sign is clear, but the magnitude is a much harder call.
A comprehensive tax/entitlement reform, one that would fix US fiscal problems for the next forty years, would be a great "stimulus package."
Ain't got no tea leaves.

data.question: Experience over the past 30 years shows that for the typical emerging market nation facing rapid capital outflows, spending foreign currency reserves to defend its currency is a better policy for its citizens than not doing so.

responses.comment: Better to allow to devaluation of the currency, promoting exports and not wasting valuable FX reserves, as defense is not likely to succeed.
Whether intervention is wise depends on why capital is flowing out (bad policies or unfounded panic). In the first case it's hopeless.
Really tough question. Outside.my expertise.
Do not know broad evidence. Short time intervention could stem speculation. Long - term wasteful
The right answer depends on the circumstances, especially whether permanent or temporary events account for outflows.  Usually:  disagree.
Efforts to maintain an overvalued currency will likely exhaust those reserves before they stop the outflows.
Depends on the particulars, but it is usually better to fix the problem that is causing the reversal.
Reserve management has not prevented "Sudden Stops" from being a major source of emerging market business cycles.																						-see background information here
One should use reserves to defnd the financial system (notably banks with USD liabilities), not the "currency" (exchange rate) per se.

data.question: Conventional economic reasoning suggests that it would be a good policy to enact the recent Senate  bill that would let undergraduate students borrow through the government Stafford program at interest rates equivalent to the primary credit rates offered to banks through the Federal Reserve's discount window.

responses.comment: Federal student loands should be tied to a longer term rate such as 10 year t-bill rate plus a premium, not a very short term rate.
College remains an excellent investment for most students, and the federal government is the appropriate lender for most borrowers.
Education creates externalities, justifying subsidies. But there are problematic institutions who may be abusing the programs.
Provides modest subsidies to students but still stabilizes cost of the program (since cost of loans to govt exceeds govt cost of borrowing).
Unclear what you mean by "conventional", but the evidence suggests inadequate college attendance because of price.
Why are we being asked about "conventional economic opinion" instead of substance? Makes it a test.
The discount-window rate represents a subsidy to education. The case for this: (1) credit frictions, and (2)  knowledge externalities.
Main q is whether marginal return to college exceeds the cost.  If it does, std reasoning says we should encourage more college degrees
This has already been done but with a cap on the total rate.  Also, the rate is locked in for the loan period.  The Q did not state this.
better skills for the workforce helps not just the workers themselves but the wider economy, too.
What do we assume about externalities?  If no externalities, then this int rate is too low bc doesn't reflect riskiness of student loans.
There are so many things wrong with the student loan program that changing the interest rate is down the list.
Something needs to be done to return the student loan program to what it was earlier this year.
Discount window loans are secured and only made to solvent banks.  Student loans historically have high default rates.  Very bad idea!
I can see the case for subsidizing college, but not pushing the borrowing rate below the risk free rate plus default risk.
Haven't had a chance to get informed on this one.
Conventional reasoning may rationalize a subsidy, but it is not clear what the alternative is or why this formula might be optimal.
Guessing what conventional economic reasoning suggests is not in my wheel house. Social returns to student loans is probably high.

data.question: An effective way to increase savings rates of employees whose firms have defined contribution plans is to combine automatic enrollment in those plans and periodic automatic increases in their contributions (with the ability to opt out of either).

responses.comment: No question that this is effective. Whether it's Pareto improving is open to debate.
Of course, as stated, if the SOLE goal were increasing saving, then even the opt-outs are contrary to the goal.
The effort to opt out raises participation. Is that good? Thats a separate issue.
for lots of ppl, the evidence backs this one up well
Strong evidence that true inside firm savings plan.  Less clear abt overall savings.  Danish evidence is impt
An age-contingent default might be even better.
The research is quite unambiguous on this point.  I have not seen any contrary findings (although savvy savers are unaffected by defaults).
This might be effective in the short run but I have doubts about the long run
-see background information here
-see background information here

Evidence on defaults seems pretty overwhelming. Not as familiar with the evidence on automatic increases, except Thaler & Benarzi (2004).																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
															-see background information here
See Thaler and Sunstein's "Nudge."
Finally a question which I am qualified to answer.
There is strong evidence that such "nudges" are effective in raising savings. The welfare consequences are less certain.

data.question: Sustained tax and spending policies that boost consumption in ways that reduce the saving rate are likely to lower long-run living standards.

responses.comment: LONG run and sustained...
It depends what the spending is for.
Boosting the short run implies a tradeoff, and a distortion in market incentives for long run efficient savings.
lower long run savings is likely to lower long run living standards regardless of source.  likely, not certain.
I would give a different answer depending on whether we were talking about Brazil or China.
Important question with an answer that depends on too many factors for a flippant response on my part.
if we are talking long-run
Only an unlikely exotic economy could over come the basic principle that more now means less later.
Artificial depression of saving, which is the (unintentional) effect of many govt policies, reduces welfare unless itoffsets some distortion
Not everywhere and always, but probably here and now for most such policies.																						-see background information here
Poorly worded and loaded question.
Unclear what is meant by a "spending policy that boosts consumption."

data.question:
Slavery in the United States was eradicated because of social and political events, not because it
was an unprofitable institution for slaveholders.

responses.comment: It is unusual to fight hard (and die) to preserve an unprofitable institution.
This was clearly Fogel's main thesis, but it is not uncontroversial.
We will miss Fogel here at Chicago.
I would have said "Slavery was abolished because it was morally deeply wrong, not because it was in the owners' interest to free slaves"
I read & do not research this topic, but this is my take-away from much reading.  I would defer to greater experts, however.
Time on a Cross was very convincing -- and so disturbing to my sister-in-law that she decided not to be an econ major after reading it!
-see background information here
Bob Fogel, who was an exemplary scholar, a courteous colleague, and a warm, kind person.  He will be greatly missed.
Fogel and Engerman make a convincing case.

data.question: Restricting US exports of liquefied natural gas would have adverse effects on the US economy.

responses.comment: This would primarily be a transfer from gas producers to U.S. industries and consumers. Welfare losses would probably be second order.
Restrictions are bad. But they may not turn out to be very important as shale gas extraction technologies disseminate internationally.																						-see background information here
Adverse is a weird word, but should allow.
This sort of restriction distorts prices and allocations from their efficient levels. I see no efficiency offsetting gain.
My answer presumes the typical narrow views of what constitutes an adverse effect on the economy.
If U.S. has market power in the energy market, there could be favorable terms of trade effects, but this is likely to be second order.
true. But ppl should understand that a world mkt for LNG means erasing the US's benefit from having lower energy Ps than others
might limit US access to forgn natural resources (e.g.,what about Chinese rare earth materials?).  Interesting analysis below																						-see background information here
Totally basic economics--gains from trade
Energy prices are set by world mkt.Restrictions are thus difficult to justify except for national security & especial fragile local environm
Restrictions on free trade seldom benefit the US, and I see no special facts here to make this an exception.
Yes, but export opportunities may be short-lived.																						-see background information here
Not highly informed on this topic. NERA report for US gov't says LNG exports would have positive impact on GDP, no effect on employment.																						-see background information here
Overall gains but unclear impact on distribution of income.
Presumption should favor free trade.

data.question:
Because the US has
underspent on new projects, maintenance, or both, the federal government has an
opportunity to increase average incomes by spending more on roads, railways,
bridges and airports.

responses.comment: One needs to know how the projects will be financed.
18 different kinds of coffee but every way to get to them has a pothole
yes but possible there are relatively few places w infrastructure deficit  (innovative proposal below)  lots of opp's eff gains w pricing																						-see background information here
Serious overspending currently on  rail. Roads and bridges need user charges. Not many true public goods that call for higher spending.
The best evidence with anything like a CAUSAL character suggests that this is untrue.  There is lots of junk correlational evidence: ignore.
Repairing bridges & roads would have been good to do over the last 5 years; the problem is nothing is really shovel ready so it takes time
-see background information here
Many roads and bridges need repair.
Borrowing at negative interest rates and high unemployement rates to stop bridges from collapsing is as close as we get to a no brainer.
Both of these statements, of course, can be true. The opportunity can be squandered.

data.question:
Past experience of public spending and political economy suggests
that if the government spent more on roads, railways, bridges and
airports, many of the projects would have low or negative returns.

responses.comment: Average return is likely to be because of underspending in many activities, but many will be adopted because of politics and have <0 returns
There will be some bad projects, but current infrastructure needs are very large.
Some will have low returns, of course. But the mean and median rate of return will likely be favorable.
"Many" will have low returns, because the political process doesn't always do a great job picking projects.  But some will be very positive.
"Some" for sure,  but many sounds like a majority.
Some of the returns may be lower than those in the private sector, but it may hard be get needed infrastructure but for the government.
Have you been to John Murtha airport?
currently infra spending does not aim to maximize returns. c. winston research suggests returns are declining but more research is critical
True for rail. For other infrastructure, the main problem is not the spending, but rather the failure to impose appropriate user charges.
Best credibly CAUSAL evidence suggests this statement is, broadly speaking, correct.  Of course, there are exceptions.
Depends on what "many" means, but dollar weighted we do overpay too often.  See Calif high speed train
-see background information here
interests rates are very low---suggesting that returns from public investment might well be good
Depends importantly on whether earmarks play a significant role.
In the past both good and bad projects have been funded. The proportion of each? Hard to say without more careful study.
All depends on what you mean by many.  Any portfolio of projects will included duds, in both private and public sector. Change many to some.

"Many" would surely have low returns.  There are difficult empirical problems, but it seems historical experience on average has been good.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here

data.question: Reducing the income-tax deductibility of charitable gifts is a less distortionary way to raise new revenue than raising the same amount of revenue through a proportional increase in all marginal tax rates.

responses.comment: Taxpayers subsidize too much non-meritorious activity through the tax writeoff. Tax liability should not fall 1-for-1 with charitable giving
The wording implies that distortion is bad, but the point of the charitable deduction is to encourage charity, ie to "distort" behavior.
This is true with no externalities; there are many externalities to charitable giving.
If minimizing distortion is your target, though seems like a very odd one.
Less distortion, yes, but that is an efficiency issue to be traded off against the distributional effects. I would keep the deduction.
Arguably charity involves an externality and so should be subsidized...the giver feels good (or wouldn't do it) and the recipient benefits.
If other distortions lead to underfunding organizations receiving charitable giving as a result of tax treatment then the answer may differ.
There is a free rider problem with regard to (good) charities.  Removing the deduction could be more distortionary.
Deductions/exemptions overall, yes. But charitable alone? Not clear.
this is only half of the equation. possible that charitable deduction is most efficient way to achieve other important social goals
Some but hardly all charitable giving generates public goods and thus relieves distortions. We should keep the good deductions only.
Poorly conceived question. This is a tax expenditure. Why not compare to sequester as non-distortionary way to raise revenues.
Of course,the tax distortion aspect alone doesn't take account of possible social benefits from charitable giving. It is a narrow criterion.
Altruism is one motive for charity, and standard conclusions about "distorting" effects of taxes may not apply in settings with altruism.
The current system stinks. Why subsidize contribtions mostly of rich home-owners?  Either kill it or make it a % credit that applies to all.

data.question: A bitcoin's value derives solely from the belief that others will want to use it for trade, which implies that its purchasing power is likely to fluctuate over time to a degree that will limit its usefulness.

responses.comment: Unlike government issued fiat money, there is no guarantee it can be used to pay taxes or settle other obligations.
Bitcoin usefulness is limited mainly by other factors. Currencies can be useful for trade in large part because they are accepted for trade.
It is likely to fluctuate in value in the future for the reasons it has fluctuated in the past, whatever those are.
Hahahaha.  ROTFL.
In principle, production cost puts a ceiling on its value, but there is no floor. No protection from competition, unlike the dollar.
First part is right: value derives frm belief others want to use it for trade. Second part is not obvious: beliefs could stabilize or not.
It is already trading like a speculative asset and no reason why that will cease.
Fiat currencies depend on belief others will use it, but national currencies can be used for taxes and can depend on some gov. support.
This is a very new animal; hard to be confident about it.
As is true for any fiat money---and also for any commodity money.

data.question: Countries that let their debt loads get high risk losing control of their own fiscal sustainability, through an adverse feedback loop in which doubts by lenders lead to higher government bond rates, which in turn make debt problems more severe.

responses.comment: This is generically true, but we don't the threshold where it matters. And not clearly true for countries that borrow in their own currency.
"Risk" is the operative word here; it is hard to forecast ex ante at what point the negative feedback loop will become problematic.																						-see background information here
Lots of particulars matter, including who it is owed to and whether the country has its own currency.
In perfect transparent markets, the market clears at an appropriate yield in one step. In actuality, price discovery involves feedback.
Does gravity make bricks fall when dropped?
Much depends on other factors like growth of the denominator of the debt/GDP ratio, which will vary  with policies & circumstances.
Tough question is definition of "high".  See Rogoff/Reinhardt for best evidence.  Does "high" differ for country w global currency, like US?
Simple math...interesting that it has not happened to Japan, however.
The debt load may be a factor in reputation but the US has experienced great increases in debt in the past without suffering these problems.
The only question is when the tipping point kicks in.  Japan will face trouble after Europe is sorted out, as might the UK and maybe then US																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Yes, but clearly conditions vary - right now US can borrow easily with high debt, but some euro countries cannot.
Government vulnerability will depend on the maturity of its debt (more short term debt means more exposure) and the size of its deficit.																						-see background information here
With debt/GDP around unity, a substantial risk premium can be the difference between the debt load being "sustainable" and "unsustainable."
Yes I suppose so, but what of it?

data.question: Refusing to liberalize trade unless partner countries adopt new labor or environmental rules is a bad policy, because even if the new standards would reduce distortions on some dimensions, such a policy involves threatening to maintain large distortions in the form of restricted trade.

responses.comment: Not clear that increasing carbon-intensive imports from, say, China would be a step closer to a less distorted allocation.
When countries adopt beggar-thy-neighbor trade/currency policies, bilateral trade agreements are a powerful tool for disciplining behavior
Measuring the social cost of the environmental distortion and the social cost of the trade distortion is hard to do definitively.
Theory is clear that we cannot make such statements outside of the first best.
I see the point, but it seems impossible not to want to reserve judgment on a case by case basis.
Such a broad proclamation seems overstated.  Relatedly, are the trade restraints on Iran bad on balance because of distortions?
Theory of the Second Best suggests strongly that "it depends."
Depends on how big the distortion is in the status quo
Yes but new research sez benefits of trade smaller than old view  Greenhouse gases impt exception b/c global impact of climate change.
Policymakers seem to think that granting the right to export to the US is a valuable privilege that comes at some cost to the US.
If there a true distortion (e.g. environmental) that needs correction, it should be addressed directly, not through distorting trade.
These arguments are often used by protectionists who use these issues to block freer trade.
OK to threaten it, but losing a deal over this would be bad policy; this reasoning seems to make it much harder to reach deals.
Income growth and technology transfer through free trade could actually improve environmental and labor standards.																						-see background information here
If the labor or environmental practices are bad enough, they should have primacy.
In many, perhaps most cases I would agree, but I don't see how one can argue that the trade distortion is always more important.
This question is to broad/vague to be meaningful.  Specific instances would probably lead to different answers.
Poor question. Trade deals are negotiated. The word "refusing" is an odd choice.

data.question: Using government funds to guarantee preschool education for four-year olds would yield a much lower social return than the ones achieved by the most highly touted targeted preschool initiatives.

responses.comment: More public investment in pre-school educated is warranted, but good targetted programs cost less and crowd out less parental invest.
Contemporary research has not reproduced the miracles seen in Perry, Abecedarian and Early Learning.
Returns are highest for quality programs for disadvantaged children, many of whom are already being served through Head Start & state progs.
I suspect this is true, but one shouldn't overstate selection relative to learning about how to do it better over time.
The most highly touted have higher returns than average. That does not mean that universal per school is a bad idea.
The evidence on preschool initiatives has been very mixed.
Of course the average is lower than the max.  But that does not mean the nation should not go that route.
If we used the gov funds to propagate the most highly touted programs, wouldn't we get a good result? But I don't have any expertise here.
The Nordic experience speaks strongly against this view.
Bad Q!. Univ preK is wasteful b/c much is pure transfer to upper-inc families. However social returns to highly touted prgms very uncertain!
Question is fuzzy. Also, the real question is whether the social return is high enough to justify the costs.
Too far from my expertise to say.
-see background information here
Question is a bit confusing. Presumably lower than very high-end estimates of Perry program, but I'd have wide confidence interval.																						-see background information here
Recent reserach suggests that the large gains from expanding preschool will come if funds are targeted toward disadvantaged families.																						-see background information here
If the question is whether the average is less than the max, then not interesting.  And no idea how to interpret "much". Right Q: is NPV>0
There is solid evidence that good preschool education has a high return. Implementation is a challenge but ingredients for success are known																						-see background information here

data.question:
Raising the federal
minimum wage to $9 per hour would make it noticeably harder for low-skilled
workers to find employment.

responses.comment: The weight of the evidence is that a modest increase in the minimum will have a small negative effect on employment of low skill workers.
I'm not aware of any strong evidence demonstrating this result.
Even among hourly paid workers with less than a high school diploma, only about 11% earn the Fed min wage or less.																						-see background information here
Past minimum wage increases have not had large disemployment effects, but we are still suffering high unemploment so effects may be worse.
The "noticeably" made me pause.  A bit harder yes, but not sure how noticeably.
Some
The empirical evidence now pretty decisively shows no employment effect, even a few years later.  See Dube, Lester and Reich in the REStat
I'm aware that some fairly clean natural experiments have not found effects.
Unemployment among low-skilled workers is already high by historic standards, indicating that wages are already too high for market-clearing
For some it will definitely reduce opportunities, but in other places it will not even be binding  Net effect is hard to tell
-see background information here
There would surely be some effect, but "noticeably" seems a reach.
Yes, I know the Econ 101 answer but the evidence suggests the effect on employment is between small and 0,.
There is little evidence that small changes in minimum wage cause employment falls, but this is larger.

data.question:
The distortionary costs of raising
the federal minimum wage to $9 per hour and indexing it to inflation are
sufficiently small compared with the benefits to low-skilled
workers who can find employment that this would be a desirable
policy.

responses.comment: Expected earnings of low skill workers will rise because higher wages/hours will more than offset reduced employment.
Decades of research on the minimum wage in the U.S. find that the distortionary effects are quite small.
Important to compare to alternatives like EITC.
About half min wage workers are under 25.   About a quarter of min wage workers are working fewer than 35 hours per week.																						-see background information here
Given that we have a minimum wage, indexing it would make a lot of sense.
The evidence is pretty clear that employment effects are small and benefits to workers are first order.
Depends what your social welfare function looks like
The benefits go to the somewhat more skilled at the expense of the lowest, which does not seem to be desirable policy.
Workers most likely to benefit are those with medium skills. Workers most likely to lose (be unemployed) are those with the lowest skills.
Total effects are hard to tell, plus there are other policies like the EITC that might be more effective.
I think the EITC is better (targeted, not as distortionary).																						-see background information here
Not the easiest call, but the minimum wage has been higher in real terms in the past, so this would not move us into uncharted waters.
All methods of helping the poor cause distortions.  This one not bad.
But there are better alternative policies, most obviously increasing the EITC.

data.question: The average US citizen would be better off if a larger number of highly educated foreign workers were legally allowed to immigrate to the US each year.

responses.comment: See Mankiw's NY Times column for a good discussion.
If the supply of high-skilled labor is constrained as now, productivity is harmed and the average person pays more for goods and services.
duh
-see background information here
The big issue in immigration is the families of the workers. Almost any worker is a benefit, but the other family members may be costly.
As a matter of economics,question does not have a simple answer.There are trade-offs.Canada's immigration suggests positive overall effects.
-see background information here
Economic growth and fiscal benefits, and wage reductions for comparable domestic workers, all seem hard to measure.																						-see background information here
Some highly educated natives would likely lose, but I expect there would be net gains overall.  Hard to be very confident, though.
This is a no brainer.  You can't be serious about "job creators" without supporting reform here.
The overall benefits of increased migration of this kind are enormous. The distribution of these benefits is less well-understood.																						-see background information here

data.question: The persistent deflation in Japan since 1997 could have been avoided had the Bank of Japan followed different monetary policies.

responses.comment: Sufficiently extreme monetary policies could have created inflation. The point is whether that would have helped much. Perhaps.
The experts disagree on the role of the Bank of Japan.
Central banks lose control of the price level at the zero lower bound, when their reserves become close substitutes for government debt.
Fed actions prove that hitting the zero bound on rates need not imply deflation.  BoJ could have stopped this and should be held accountable																						-see background information here
If alternative = sufficiently unconventional and committed.																						-see background information here
Lower interest rates, purchases of long-term assets, and higher inflation target could have raises output and prices.
Must be directionally right, but recent US experience does not inspire certainty.
A QE policy would likely have prevented the deflation.

data.question: Because all federal spending and taxes must be approved by both houses of Congress and the executive branch, a separate debt ceiling that has to be increased periodically creates unneeded uncertainty and can potentially lead to worse fiscal outcomes.

responses.comment: The question contains its own answer.
It does indeed provide some brake on long-term spending, but there has to be a better way.
This is a second chance to gridlock. A budget passed by Congress already authorizes the necessary funding.
OBVIOUSly
This is a question about the behavior of members of Congress. I don't see how an economist could have any expertise on this.
In the past, it was not acceptable for legislators to create the disruption from blocking a debt increase. Even RR disapproved.
Deciding whether or not to pay the debts incurred to fund the previously approved tax and spending is nuts.

It sure looks like it's been adding uncertainty lately (e.g. 2011).  But it could conceivably be a force for good.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Might not have given the same answer two years ago, but at this point, seems hard to disagree.
Just read the paper.
The debt ceiling is a dumb idea with no benefits and potentially catestrophic costs if ever used.
It can also lead to potential better outcomes

data.question: The federal government would make the average U.S. citizen better off by using policies that directly focus more on increasing small business growth than growth of economic output overall.

responses.comment: Targeted sectoral subsidies almost always a special interest boondoggle. And why does small business helps average citizen more than large?
On its face, "small" need not be better. To prioritize implies a loss relative to the unprioritized optimum, barring more information.
Small business is held back by the burden of its undiversified idiosyncratic risk.  But I don't think the gov can do much about it.																						-see background information here
Government can and should stimulate small business growth with general tax policies. How much and at the exclusiion of what is uncertain.
Generally, the government is not in a good position to pick winners/losers in the private sector, and I do not see a clear externality here.
Many "average" Americans work for large businesses. What is the point if this does not improve economic growth?
Small biz create and destroy lots of jobs, there is no reason to favor them at the expense of others																						-see background information here
This could well be true, but I don't think we know.  Meanwhile, favoring small businesses for job creation seems to be doubly misguided.																						-see background information here
Maybe I am missing something but I see no particular reason why this sector should be favored.

data.question: The annual indexing of Social Security benefits to increases in the consumer price index for urban wage earners and clerical workers (the CPI-W) leads to higher benefits than would be required to compensate recipients for genuine cost-of-living increases.

responses.comment: CPI-W probably overstates inflation for the general population, but may understate it for the elderly health costs are for this group.																						-see background information here
Not certain that inflation faced by elderly corresponds perfectly to inflation faced by urban wage earners and clerical workers.
There is both an upward and downward bias in CPI-w. Chaining and capturing elderly consumption would be an improvement
I don't recall the latest research on this.
Neither the curret CPI or an indexed version of it has weights appropriate for the Social Security population, so the claim has no basis.
I am not aware of the evidence.
not to get too deep into price index theory but suffice it to say that this is definitely true
The NIPA PCE index, taken by many to be more accurate, turns out to underweight housing, so it's hard to tell.
The chained CPI C-CPI-U gets conditional COLI approx right because it allows bundle of goods to adjust. CPI-W is an upper bound on COLI.																						-see background information here
Is the urban rate of inflation is greater than elsewhere? "Urban" covers 87% of the population; see website below.																						-see background information here
Directionally almost has to be true, but the magnitude is uncertain.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
Poorly conceived question. CPI-W overstates cost of living for all, but not clear for 65+. Two effects seem close to offsetting.
Most agree that the CPI over-states inflation, but it is less clear that the over-statement is substantial.
Hard to say without knowing about healthcare costs.

data.question: The Brookings Institution recently described a US carbon tax of $20 per ton, increasing at 4% per year, which would raise an estimated $150 billion per year in federal revenues over the next decade.  Given the negative externalities created by carbon dioxide emissions, a federal carbon tax at this rate would involve fewer harmful net distortions to the US economy than a tax increase that generated the same revenue by raising marginal tax rates on labor income across the board.

responses.comment: -see background information here
Taxing negative externalities reduces economic distortions; taxing labor creates them. This is the tax equivalent of a free lunch!
Since carbon is a worldwide pollutant, leakage of production to other jurisdictions remains a concern.
Pollution is a negative externality. It is hard to argue the same for employment! If $150b per year isn't way too much tax, this is obvious.
but partly b/c statement intentionally doesn't consider distributional or implementation issues with carbon taxes.

The $20 tax is v close to U.S. government's estimate of the social cost of carbon of about $21 per ton.   See links below for more details.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
There's reasonable evidence that carbon emissions raise the temp, but it is less clear that the net effects of warming are negative.
Agree at a high level, but implementation of such a tax could create many new distortions and loopholes.
The likely outcome, though the answer depends on relevant elasticities.
Great on effiency but not on progressivity so you have to get that right elsewhere.
The details matter, and CO2 reduction is a global public good, so this policy is not sufficient.  But it's a step forward.

data.question: Because federal spending on Medicare and Medicaid will continue to grow under current policy beyond the 10-year window of most political budget debates, it is easy for a politician to devise a budget plan that would reduce federal deficits over the next decade without really making the U.S. fiscally sustainable.

responses.comment: "Easy" is too strong, but the growth rate of medical costs and adverse demographic trends pose long term problems
With or w/o Medicare, it's hard to do a budget that fixes federal deficits over 10 yrs. But ignoring Med makes it easier than it should be!
It might be easy for technocrats to devise a plan, but it seems very difficult to get politicians to do so.
Nothing is easy about deficit reduction.
you think a significant 10 yr deficit cut would be 'easy'? welcome to earth, friend.
Disagree w word "easy" but agree that the budget problem for the next 10 years differs from the one over longer terms.
Health spending spending will rise a lot in 10 years, so a plan that limited the deficit for that period of time would be a good step
-see background information here
Easier, yes, but CBO says even eliminating deficits over ten years means noticeable spending cuts and/or tax increases.																						-see background information here
Controlling US health care costs is necessary (and not only for fiscal sustainability). But other fiscal issues also need addressing.
arithmetic
"Easy" might not be the right word.

data.question:
Comparing two plans that would reduce federal budget deficits by identical amounts in each of the next
10 years, one that did so partly by reducing significantly the long-term growth rate of Medicare and Medicaid spending would do more to make the U.S. budget fiscally sustainable than one that did not lower the growth of these spending programs.

responses.comment: Alternative could be as sound if it reduced growth rate of Social Security (e.g. by means testing) and reduced inefficient tax deductions.
Rising health care costs are the greatest threat to U.S. fiscal solvency (that we know of) looking over multiple decades.
Health care costs are driving the growth in the deficit.
An important caveat though:  It can be difficult to know today, what will lower long term growth more than 10 years out.
Depends what the alternative is.
if it meant the lower growth rate would continue, then yes, clearly
True but more revenues need to be part of solution.  We are collecting low levels of revenue by historical stds and population is aging.
Rationalizing Medicare and bringing contributions for higher-income families into line with benefits would be a good idea on its own.
Medicare and Medicaid are (along with growth) the key factors for long term sustainability.  We never paid for the Bush plan, let alone ACA.
Hard to disagree, but question seems too hypothetical - fiscal situation also would look better with 5%/ yr GDP growth!
ditto.  Real issue should be to abolish the 10 year window and especially misleading attempts to disguise things via "temporary" tax cuts.

data.question: Taking into account all of the economic consequences — including the incentives of banks to ensure their own liquidity and solvency in the future — the benefits of bailing out U.S. banks in 2008 will end up exceeding the costs.

responses.comment: Long term unemployed workers are costly; many collect SSDI. Aiding GM was likely a cost effective welfare/employment program, all else aside
On net I agree, but the future costs are difficult to measure.
Absent those bailouts, a depression was much more likely. The moral hazard is now being reduced by new rules, such as for capital.
The past bailout, by itself, won't ensure the next one, nor would a refusal to bail firms out set a binding precedent.
"Bailing out the banks" is not a very precise characterization of the policies of 2008-9.
Too many possibilities, and hard to measure costs and benefits.
The consequenses (economic and social) of a potential financial collapse would have been immense.
may not cost $ but was still an outrage we got to that point
Yes.  Credit markets were frozen and that was having a terrible impact on the economy.  Check out a graph of the TED spread.
Not compared to an ideal policy of an orderly reorganization imposing losses on creditors according to seniority. But better than chaotic.
Bankruptcy and liquidation would have been worse, but could have nationalized a couple of the weakest ones, especially Citi.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Many details could have been improved but you could do nothing.

data.question: Because GM and Chrysler were bailed out in 2008-09, the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would it have been if Congress and the executive branch had not intervened.

responses.comment: Putting costs aside, this is almost certainly true since many displaced workers would not have found reemployment by now in bad economy.
To answer this would require a reliable and detailed quantitative macroeconomic model, or at least expert empirical knowledge.
While I agree, I would have preferred seeing the gov stand behind warantees and provide debtor in possession finance only.
Probably yes, but a very small effect.
In the short run, it seems uncontroversial.
as with banks, even if true, outrageous we ever got to that position
the strongest argument is US auto manufacturing would be better off in the long run, which may or may not be true, but v doubtful by 2010
Again, it would have been better to reorganize with suitable losses on the junior creditors. This would not have resulted in higher unemp.
But traditional bankruptcy and restructuring was an option too. Challenges for financial and non-financial firms are totally different.																						-see background information here
There was no private money available.

data.question: Taking into account all of the economic consequences — including effects on corporate managers' incentives and on creditors' expectations of how their claims will be treated in future bankruptcies — the benefits of bailing out GM and Chrysler will end up exceeding the costs.

responses.comment: The bankruptcy law was circumvented. Absent  unstated exigent (e.g. systemic) reasons, upsetting creditor rights is inefficient.
Incentive effects are real.  Incentive effects from a decision to bail out are overstated.
Again, hard to measure costs and benefits.
See previous answer
Costs will appear in the next crisis; the precedent for a bailout is now set.  Reduced incentives for the private sector to hold dry powder.
-see background information here
Not at all obvious at the time decision was made, and I expect many would disagree now.
Moral hazard seems less of a problem with non-financial corporations.

data.question: The U.S government should make further efforts to shrink the size of the country's largest banks — such as by capping the size of their liabilities or penalizing large banks more heavily through taxes or other means — because the existing regulations do not require the biggest banks to internalize enough of the "too-big-to-fail" risks that they pose.

responses.comment: They should pay more for more implicit protection.
I am open minded about a size cap, but before taking this action, I think more research should be done on unintended consequences.
Probably better to stiffen regulations.
it wasn't really size that made them dangerous. it was interconnection. derivatives, resolution, and consolidated supervisor > deposit size
Hard to disagree in principle; we need more information on how to design such rules practically (or at least i need to know more).
Limiting assets is largely ineffective because banks can take similar risks and earn similar returns using swaps rather than holding assets.
Very unclear how far to go. Was too big to fail the problem in Canada? In Europe? Expansion triggered by regulatory change the big problem.
Banks face the same market incentives, and will make similar investments. Penalizing size does not help the solvency of the banking system.
Many ways to use derivatives and other regulatory loopholes to avoid these penalties. So we could make things less safe.  Details matter.
Depends on the capital requirements imposed on them.																						-see background information here
I think my view on this would depend on exactly what steps were being proposed.
I think the dangers of "too big to fail" have been exaggerated. Small banks would have to be bailed too in a financial crash.
Seems right.  Like the tax idea at rate that increases above some threshold.

data.question:
The economic benefits to the U.S. of having a
handful of banks with balance sheets greater than $1 trillion are small.

responses.comment: The costs, such as "too big to fail" are clear, and changing. The benefits, including easier intermediation of large deals, are non trivial.
small relative to the costs anyway
Any returns to scale are likely exhausted at smaller scale. But we should not measure size by assets, but by exposure.
Scope (geographic as well as product) may be the bigger issue. Subsidizing risky investment activities with subsidized deposits problematic
If size helps a bank provide significantly better service to customers then the economy enjoys significant benefits.
US firms are big in all industries and balance sheet size is an imperfect measure.  But evidence on scale and scope efficiences is weak.
Presume there are some economies of scale, but favor higher capital requirements on them.																						-see background information here
Don't feel very informed on this, but not obvious why a few banks going from $500 bn to $1+ tr would create large aggregate benefits.

data.question: The federal government would make the average U.S. citizen better off by using policies that directly focus more on increasing manufacturing employment than employment in other sectors.

responses.comment: Holding wages constant, manufacturing jobs appeal more to non-college males, the group whose employment rate is falling most rapidly.
The counter argument is knowledge or other spillovers in manufacturing.
A caveat -- the auto bailout was manufacturing specific and more valuable than the equivalent policy spread across the economy as a whole
Its not obvious that this policy addresses an important externality and has low unintended consequences.
Most workers don't work in manufacturing, so such policies are apt to redistribute from the average person to manufacturing workers.
It would make average Americans better off by focusing on and helping to finance investments in skills and training useful in manufacturing.
depends what policy it is
Tremendously complicated. Many US manufactured goods have high profit margins, so correcting the distortion would help us and others
The average American benefits from lower prices, not from any preference for manufacturing.
Memo to Romney and Obama: there is nothing per se special about manufacturing (except maybe nostalgia).
Rents, externalities may be higher than in other sectors (evidence is not clear cut).  Higher national saving (needed!) would help U.S. mfg.																						-see background information here
Don't see why gov't as a rule should directly subsidize manufacturing, though education, science, trade policy could indirectly benefit.
This is the argument of the Physiocrats in modern dress.  Picking winners, even broadly defined, is rarely good policy.
Governments are usually poor at "picking winners."
This or any other "industrial policy" is only as good as the implementation.
Manufacturing vs. Others isn't an appropriate classification; instead provide a good overall environment, look for targeted externalities.
I depends what you mean with average citizen. Lower educated people would probably benefit at the expense of others.

data.question: Because firms and inventors do not capture the full returns from research and development, the government would increase the average well-being of Americans (and potentially of others too) by favoring R&D using the tax code.

responses.comment: Unclear if R&D credits induce R&D at the margin or mostly reward inframarginal R&D. I prefer govt fund basic research directly (NIH, NSF).
Same argument suggests role for public support of university research.
If the positive R&D externality seems plausible, it makes sense to subsidize. There are some cases in which this has worked (universities).
More innovation is almost surely good, and more R&D spending may increase innovation.
among many ways
Nordhaus has shown how much leakage of ideas occurs into the worldwide public domain. Of course, the US would capture only a quarter of gain
The relatively small cost of R&D subsidies is an effective way to support continued high American productivity.
Not sure of the magnitudes of the distortions once we account for patents and other R&D policies
Caveat is that there are Type I and Type II errors in identifying research activities to receive special tax treatment.																						-see background information here
I'd be inclined toward policies fostering basic science and innovation that commercial applications can build on.
One would need to be careful to define R&D fairly narrowly.  But it is hard to argue that there are no spillovers from comercial R&D.
Again impossible to say without details.  Would prefer lower tax rate and broader tax.
Not just tax code. Other policies like advance market commitments and (of course) a thorough reform of patent policy.
If you tink of fundamental research is probably true. If you think about research in general, even the premise might be wrong

data.question: Consider one of two proposals for restraining future Medicare spending, each by the same amount: The method that President Obama enacted in the Affordable Care Act — reducing Medicare-related payments to private insurers and altering the payment system for doctors and hospitals — imposes risks on future Medicare patients because over time the supply of doctors, hospitals and insurers willing to offer them health services may decline in response to restrained payments.

responses.comment: There is fat and monopoly markups in the system to be cut. The problem with the ACA is the absence of across the board credible cost cutting
Obamacare is a risky step into the unknown; The alternative of voucher-care is a faith-based exercise, already disproved by the evidence.
Savings could result both from particular therapies being disallowed as well as control over price of a given therapy.
Medicare is such an important market that providers will not be able to turn their backs on these patients.
Every policy has risks, so one can't say no. The evidence suggests this is not major, though.
It is supposed to be compensated by there being fewer uninsured.
The amount of risk depends not just on supply but on the political will to restrain payments if supply shrinks
It seems unlikely that such serious cutbacks would ever occur. The risk is to the government's fiscal position, not to US health.
Implementation details will determine how severe this problem becomes. Not a big problem in many countries with national health insurance.
These payments come from a bargaining process. When too high, Medicare pushes them down. If there is exit, Medicare will allow them to rise.
Assuming that they actually hold the line on payments.
Medicare is not on a sustainable path, so some sacrifice of promised future benefits is inevitable.																						-see background information here
Surely pricing decisions in Medicare have incentive effects but would expect how cuts are made to matter a lot.
If it becomes a serious problem, the reimbursement method or something else) will be modified.
Of course, there is no such thing as a risk free lunch.
There is some probability that complementary policies to contain the growth of medical costs will not be sufficiently effective.

data.question:
Consider the other of two proposals for restraining future Medicare spending, each by the same amount: The method that Governor Romney advocates — giving future seniors a fixed payment for premiums and letting private insurers compete with Medicare — imposes risks on future Medicare patients because competition may not be powerful to enough to offer future seniors the same quality of care that is
currently promised without supplementing their premium support.

responses.comment: the problem isn't lack of power from competition but other parts of the plan which do not make sense and may rely on cutting redistribution
There is no evidence that private sector is more effective at healthcare cost control than public sector. Privatization only shifts costs.
The market for health care is not competitive. Under this proposal prices will increase, leaving seniors unable to afford care.
This depends enormously on how the voucher is set wrt expected costs. The proposals involve enormous risks.
This risk verges on certainty.  The private insurance system has not been very good at restraining costs.
Cherrypicking will occur and the government option gets more adversely selected.
So, of course, premium support in lieu of Medicare would be raised. Again the risk is to fiscal, not medical, health.
I don't see how competition can eliminate serious adverse selection problems
Insurance companies will spend money to attract healthy people and push others to Medicare.
Also risky assuming premium support is limited; some cherry picking could also cause problems for traditional Medicare
Future benefits have to fall, and this is one way.  Massachusetts offers hope that a hybrid plan could reduce non-plan costs too.																						-see background information here
Again seems hard to say - depends on plan requirements and level of premium support.
It is not obvious what the current system "promises" to a fifty- or sixty-year old.
This one is more substantive.  It is like changing from an indexed DB plan to a nominal DC plan.  Worse, adds risks that states default!

data.question: Claims by incumbent presidents and challengers about how many private-sector jobs can be created in a four-year period by sector-level or other targeted policies should be viewed as rough guesses, because overall macroeconomic conditions drive aggregate employment in ways that dominate any net effects of polices that focus on specific industries or households.

responses.comment: Broad macro conditions and macro policy matter most, but targetted policies have a role.
Sometimes sectoral policies turn out to be very large -- as with the auto industry and the health care industry.
A politically unfettered federal government could do a lot, so there are presumably implicit side conditions here?
"Viewed as rough guesses" is a very polite and understated way of putting it, guys.
What does "macroeconomic" mean?  The "macro" economy is an aggregation of micro untis. Of course the effects of any policy are uncertain.
only question is whether 'rough guesses' is too generous
No doubt about this whatsoever!
POTUS macro choices matter somewhat but most sexy attempts to pander to get votes are inconsequental & shocks they can't control are big.

In the short run durability = cyclicality across industries.  In the long run it's technology and preferences (Engel curves).																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
"Rough guesses" misses the point. I would say "large overestimates" as they are usually not effective ways of increasing either AD or AS.
Agree.  More generally too much weight is given to the jobs numbers.  How about if we evaluate a president by the return on the stock market

data.question: One drawback of taxing capital income at a lower rate than labor income is that it gives people incentives to relabel income that policymakers find hard to categorize as "capital" rather than labor".

responses.comment: See work of Diamond and Saez in JEP: The Case for a Progressive Tax: From Basic Research to Policy Recommendations																						-see background information here
The incentive this creates to recategorize is clear. That this results in a drawback seems right, but less clear to me.
yes
Apart from the issue of carried interest, this is not a big issue in taxation.
don't know how successful they are, but the incentives are clear
-see background information here
See Romney, Mitt.

data.question: Despite relabeling concerns, taxing capital income at a permanently lower rate than labor income would result in higher average long-term prosperity, relative to an alternative that generated the same amount of tax revenue by permanently taxing capital and labor income at equal rates instead.

responses.comment: Two things are ott confused. Continuously taxing savings is hugely inefficient. Taxing income at source even if it is capital income isn't.
My fear is that the distortions from relabeling the potential gains from lower capital taxes in the second best world in which we live.
I prefer not to think of all capital as the same.
This seems right on average to me, but does it need to be true under all conditions? Of this I am less confident.
lots of conflicting results in the research in this area
Standard theory is clear that this is good for growth but empirical work is less clear.    Is std theory wrong or is evidence not credible?
Mirrlees-type arguments for taxation of the return to capital involve a sacrifice of the total size of the pot to bring about redistribution
But the levels of rates matter and just getting the rate capital down might have no meaningful effects.
Not what every study finds, but most I have seen.																						-see background information here
this is probably true if "average prosperity" means income per capita
Most evidence points to technical change as the main force behind long run growth.  Capital accumulation plays a role only in the short run.
If you tax investment income what will people do?  Stuff their money in the mattress?

data.question: Although they do not always agree about the precise likely effects of different tax policies, another reason why economists often give disparate advice on tax policy is because they hold differing views about choices between raising average prosperity and redistributing income.

responses.comment: Main reasons: diffs in social prefs and differ in priors about "elasticity" of responses to taxes + regs. Most agree on signs not magnitudes
I don't like the phrasing of 'average' in the question.
My anecdotal experience is that economists differ widely on the relative costs of income heterogeneity (equity versus efficiency).
The key parameter is the elasticity of substitution in the social welfare function across people. We don't agree on that.
This is a powerful factor that is often overlooked: the efficiency vs equity debate is still alive, even if sometimes hidden.
Positive (more agreement) vs. Normative (less agreement).
if "average prosperity" means average income per capita
duh

responses.comment: See the persuasive article by Robert Novy-Marx and Joshua Rauh in the Journal of Economic Perspectives in 2009.																						-see background information here
Not sure why they do that.
The discounting is unrealistically high, so underfunding is understated. Pretty simple. The distortion is large, according to experts.																						-see background information here
This is a big problem with corporate pensions too.
Its outrageous that this is permitted.  See Novy-Marx and Rauh's IGM funded research to see the massive degree of understatement.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Novy-Marx and Rauh peg current state pension assets at $1.94 trillion, and liabilities at $5.17 trillion, a $3.23 trillion shortfall!																						-see background information here

data.question: During the next two decades some U.S. states, unless they substantially increase taxes, cut spending, and/or change public-sector pensions, will require a combination of severe austerity budgets, a federal bailout, and/or default.

responses.comment: This is always and everywhere true.
More so for the ones that are opposed to tax increases.
The estimated shortfall magnitudes are large according to experts like Josh Rauh, and roughly double state indebtedness, adding $3 trillion.																						-see background information here
duh
They can forget federal bailouts!
Where legally possible I expect states will reneg on promised pension amounts
Current path is unsustainable; the longer we wait the worse the eventual adjustment, but for OH and IL at least things already look bad.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Why it is a terrible idea to shift the residual risk of Medicare costs to states, many of which are already in virtual default.

data.question:
Even if the
third round of quantitative easing that the Fed recently
announced increases real GDP growth over the
next two years, the increase will be inconsequential.

responses.comment: My guess is QE3 will have a small positive effect on GDP, but I am not well informed on this issue.
What does inconsequential mean?
The impact might be small, but "inconsequential" , to me, means "of negligible value." The Fed is doing this for a reason, not for fun.
Purchases are open ended so consequences will depend on magnitude which remains uncertain. And does your question encompas forward guidance?
Current activity depends mainly on shorter rates, so lowering long rates has little effect. See my 1977 Brookings paper.																						-see background information here
Too many other negative pressures around the world (europe, fiscal cliff, china) for the Fed's policy to make much difference
-see background information here
Likely to be small, but consequential if it has net job creation.
don't know and will never know.  Economy is likely to start growing at some point and no one will know what caused it.

data.question:
Even if the
third round of quantitative easing that the Fed recently
announced increases annual consumer price inflation over the
next five years, the increase will be inconsequential.

responses.comment: The path of Inflation could be raised moderately over 5 years by this QE. The Fed has said as much, and probably wants a bit more inflation.
Increase is unlikely to exceed 1-2 percentage points per annum. Is this inconsequel? I'm not sure how to interpret the word in this context.
Only way this is incorrect is if the Fed ignores lots of warnings.  Given current FOMC membership that risk is small.
-see background information here
Again, inconsequential is poor word choice. Surely less than 50 basis points per year.
Depends what you mean by 'consequential.' I doubt there is a chance of inflation as high as 5% before the Fed tightens.
Inflation risk still seems low.

data.question:
Even if inflationary
pressures rise substantially as a result of quantitative easing and low
interest rates, the Federal Reserve has ample tools to rein inflation back in
if it chooses to do so.

responses.comment: Yes, it clearly has the tools, but will it use them quickly and aggressively, especially given the short-run cost in jobs? We may find out.
There's no upper bound on the Fed's contractionary power--it can sell bonds and raise the interest rate on reserves, the latter sans limit.
Lots of ways to tighten and failure to do so would have to be an active choice.
e.g., the Fed phased out its liquidity lending facilities when the worst of the crisis passed.																						-see background information here
But recall that inflation is below Fed goal.
Again depends on what 'substantially' means. There is some (uncertain) point at which long-term inflation expectations lose their anchor.
The difference between can do it and will do it is a bit tricky when we are talking about the Fed

data.question: Ethanol content requirements and protectionism against imported ethanol (which includes fuel from sugarcane) raise food prices without significantly reducing carbon-dioxide emissions.

responses.comment: -see background information here
Clearly some link between ethanol production and corn prices, but magnitude not clear.																						-see background information here
The first part is certainly true.
This sounds right, although it relies a bit on some knowledge of the chemistry involved, so I am not completely confident.
I assume there is some reduction in emissions, but I don't know how much.
best evidence is that cost per ton of CO2 abated is very high.
-see background information here
At white house we found that 30% of increases in corn prices, 10% of grain, 2% of food caused by ethanol and biodiesel for 2007-08.
At least some price increase to be expected if policy increases demand for corn. CBO study (link below) provides estimates.																						-see background information here
US provisions expired at the end of 2011, but correct up to then. Best estimates are that these were GHG neutral.
I'm on the board of publily traded Cosan Ltd. It controls 50% of the world's largest sugar & ethanol producer.  This didn't affect my answer
The first half of the statement is surely true.  I have no idea whether emissions are significantly reduced so can't answer the question.
The first half is quite certain, but the net effect on carbon is quite complex, with offsetting effects.

data.question: A direct disincentive to emit carbon-dioxide, for example through a carbon tax or an emissions permit market, is more efficient than requiring the use of corn-based ethanol fuels.

responses.comment: Yes, but most emissions permit schemes do not cover non-stationary sources.
It would be pure coincidence if forced substitution of one input for another is efficient. A permit market can give the correct tradeoff.
Directly taxing pollutants is better than indirect approaches if pollutants can be adequately monitored.
if for goal of reducing carbon emmissions then yes, that statement is true. For other goals, uncertain.

Standard efficiency argument, but the calclulatiions show large taxes would be required to have any effect. Elasticies are low.
Mountain of evidence here. See 2010 RfF study.
One of the true no-brainers.
Of course we should have a carbon tax or the equivalent.  Taxes with negative dead weight loss are good things!

data.question: Even if all the official-sector funding that Greece received from 2010 through August 2012 is written off, propping up Greece to buy time for the rest of Europe to prepare for Greek default has been better for citizens of the Eurozone outside of Greece than a policy that would have cut off funding sooner.

responses.comment: An immediate default would have left some Euro zone banks unprepared, and possibly have generated runs. That risk is now reduced.
Earlier restructuring of Greece's private and official debt would have been better, but IGM's "cutting off funding" language is ambiguous.
Buying time was sensible at least initially. In retrospect it looks like a bad call.
Better to have backstopped all the banks and let Greece default in early 2010 -- contagion was manageable then if the banks were supported
The IMF seems to think so, but it's not clear to me.																						-see background information here
Danger of contagion has been overstated.
I do not think it has been better for Greece either

data.question: A substantial sovereign-debt default by some combination of Greece, Ireland, Italy, Portugal and Spain is a necessary condition for the euro area as a whole to grow at its pre-crisis trend rate over the next three years.

responses.comment: More restructuring might help a lot if managed carefully.  But I don't see that this this a necessary condition for growth.
Without getting into "necessary but not sufficient" quibbles the EZ is not going to grow at its pre-crisis rate in the next 3 years, period.
There are many ways to transfer wealth from the North to the South; default is not the only option.
even that won't work
ECB could inflate things away (and maybe the OMT is the first step) which is another form of default.
Necessary condition is just too strong.  There's a lot of uncertainty in any forecast, including upside as well as downside.																						-see background information here
Greece has already defaulted, and its government debt still looks unsustainable.

data.question: Unless there is a substantial default by some combination of Greece, Ireland, Italy, Portugal and Spain on their sovereign debt and commercial bank debt, plus credible reforms to prevent excessive borrowing in the future, the euro area is headed for a costly financial meltdown and a prolonged recession.

responses.comment: The question leaves no other options for avoiding meltdown. There are other options, including muddling through with ECB support.
More debt restructuring is coming. But I would not unconditionally forecast a "costly financia meltdown" in its absence. It depends on Mario
This question and the other 2 are too broad.  Many other things matter and these are not held constant in the questions.
Structural reforms are essential. But again, default is not the only way to reduce the debt burden of Greece, etc...
misaligned exchange rates mean slow growth. slow growth means no solving the problem, regardless
The timing and character of the default matters a lot for the consequences. EZ needs to be better prepared for it.
Again inflating is the alternative -- a clean restructuring is probably better, but inflation may be the path of least resistance.
I think it's still possible for a virtuous cycle without more defaults.
Too toug to predict business cycle activity let alone the effect of a particular factor on it in this case.

data.question: The current trade barriers in the U.S. sugar industry raise the profits of sugar producers and make the typical U.S. consumer pay more for sugar and goods that use sugar as an input.

responses.comment: FM Scherer did a cogent analysis of the Sugar Quota system as a Harvard Kennedy School case many years ago.
And drives demand for corn sweeteners.
Economics 101. Lowering the supply (from foreign sources), leads the price to go up. At each price, a tariff lowers the foreign supply.
On the other hand sugar has negative health externalities and should probably be heavily taxed.
I wrote a term paper on this topic in the previous century when I was an undergraduate.  Don't know anything else about sugar markets.
This is purely empirical q that depends on degree to which the barrier binds. I've seen evidence for/against so this is a q for area experts
Terrible policy, but at least not as bad as the U.S. Sugar Act which expired in 1974.																						-see background information here
Econ 0.0001
In addition  sugar trade barriers have caused part of the candy industry to move abroad. Life Savers are now made in Canada.
uncle Sam as sugar daddy.
-see background information here

data.question: Loans to students attending for-profit colleges are especially risky because students attending them have had default rates that greatly exceed those for comparable students attending public and non-profit private institutions.

responses.comment: -see background information here
See Deming, Goldin and Katz 2012 in Journal of Economic Perspectives																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Seems misphrased. Surely not "because"?  Rather than both consequences of other factors
Perhaps these students were high default risks no matter what schools they attended. Cannot infer causation from correlation.
-see background information here
Agreeing with some caution: default rates are higher on average (see link), but don't know the evidence on whether students are comparable.																						-see background information here
Depends on whether the characteristics leading a student to default are observable and independent of attendance at a for-profit school.
Haven't seen numbers except in the press; don't understand the nature of "default" here.
Presumes facts that I do not know to be true.
I don't know of work that has been able to compare default for "comparable students"; the pools attending are very different.
If the fact is correct ( I do not know ) I agree

data.question: Rules that tie each college's eligibility for federal student loans to its students' graduation rates and post-schooling employment outcomes would better protect taxpayers from losses on student loans.

responses.comment: A tie to default rates would also help.
The government is now residual claimant for the school's activities.  There may be alternative ways to do this.
Sounds reasonable that loans should not be provided if they are not having a sufficiently good measured impact.
Note though that high graduation rates may be manipulable.
Outcomes need to be measured. But graduation rates can be manipulated. Employment outcomes are a better criterion.
The policies should not be at the college/univ level but should be at the PROGRAM level.  Better than nothing, though.
if done right.
Conclusion is obvious, but does not support the policy. The proper goal is to improve students' lives on average, not avoid loan losses.
Depends on not forbearing, or picking up costs of past bad private loans.  Will the government really put lots of people in debtors prison?
Sounds plausible, but don't know have enough expertise on current program to feel very confident about it.
May just drive students who were likely to default anyway to different colleges
Much could depend on the nature of the "tie."  If this were done well it could also affect competition for students in a positive way.
Hard to know without more details.  The no brainer is to require better disclosure.  You should have asked about that.
Better incentives for colleges seem appropriate here.

data.question: The way in which money market funds normally trade – at one dollar per share, even though the per-share value of the assets backing them varies over time – made them vulnerable to a run in 2008 before they received taxpayer guarantees.

responses.comment: In 2008,  Institutional investors ran, redeeming shares at a dollar each when  a risk arose that this might later become impossible.																						-see background information here

The run on mmmfs was one of the systemic events that nearly blew up the world in 2008
L

The current structure of MMMFs makes them susceptible to runs.  So an ugly blow up in Europe could spread to the US via the MMMFs.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
-see background information here
I'm not expert on the institutional details but seems similar to standard demand deposit arrangement (a la diamond-dybvig).
Haven't read or thought about these issues.

data.question: Taxpayers would be better protected if each money market fund in the U.S. were instead required to trade at its floating net asset value.

responses.comment: The alternative is committing not to rescue them, which is difficult.
This would lower the incentive to be the first to run. These runs are destructive.
Better protected means just that -- smaller chance of a run. Doesn't necessarily mean it is socially desirable.
This is one possible remedy for the problem, but not the only one.  It also has some features incompatible with the intended use of MMFs.
Floating NAV definitely ends the risk of a run.  Only caveat is what happens to the money that MIGHT migrate.  Could be a whack a mole issue
Money market funds are mutual funds. They should not be allowed to pretend otherwise.
Not sure about this policy.  Would be very confusing to investors who (wrongly) think of these as bank accounts rather than investments.

data.question: In the absence of floating net asset values, taxpayers would be better protected if each money market fund in the U.S. were required to set aside capital to protect against losses while holding back a portion of shareholders' cash for a time when they seek to withdraw all of their money.

responses.comment: This would lower run risk, analogous to bank capital requirements as a mitigant of depositor runs.																						-see background information here
This sounds correct but I would need to think about it more to have much certainty about it.
Bigger capital cushions -- relative to the past -- are surely desirable. But the optimal level is unknown.
This is one possible remedy for the problem, but not the only one.  It also has some features incompatible with the intended use of MMFs.
SEC has a chance to require this and it would help.  This probably leads to more migration than floating NAV.
How much capital would be "enough" in case of a run?  When would the waiting period be enforeced?  This is a weak policy alternative.
Seems like this could ENCOURAGE runs.
