data.question: Taxes or bans on large bottles of soft drinks containing sugar are not likely to have a significant effect on obesity rates because people will substitute towards consuming excessive calories in other ways.

responses.comment: Unlikely to have an impact, but worth evaluating!
Also might not reduce obesity for other reasons - but not the only metric on which to evaluate the policy
How much substitution not clear. Closest extant empirical evidence relates to soft drink taxes.																						-see background information here
Sugary drinks are subsidized by U.S. farm policy and are an important factor in overweight among children, leading to overweight adults.
Literature suggests otherwise.
This is surely something that is worth studying empirically. I can think of good arguments on both sides and have no idea what would happen.
I don't have the necessary knowledge to handle this one.
Michael Anderson has done research partially related to this that shows that people are able to substitute across sources of calories easily																						-see background information here
Probably.  Though proximity to fast food restaurants seems to matter, as if substitutability is limited.																						-see background information here
Seems unlikely this one change on its own would *significantly* reduce obesity.
Is there any empirical work on this issue?
Bad question. Taxes unlikely to work if low but big cigarette takes reduce consumption and peoplle don't substitute other smoke!
There will be substitution & I don't like the paternalism, but there is growing evidence that such nudges can be effective.
This is a question a psychologist is better at answering. Are people aware of all the calories they assume? I do not think so.

data.question: Subjecting online sales from out-of-state vendors to the same retail sales taxes imposed on in-state sales would raise more tax revenue in the states making this change while reducing the pro-online bias of current policy.

responses.comment: Papers by Goolsbee, Ellison and Ellison, and Einav and Levin show that this is unambiguously correct.
I don't know whether some states have been consciously  "pro on line."  I don't follow this policy area.
Leveling the playing field & raising money is good policy; rationalizing the many jurisdictions & various tax rates would be good too.
-see background information here
Pretty hard to disagree with the question as phrased.
Seems right to level the playing field.

data.question: Consumers would not necessarily be better off if cable and satellite TV firms were required to offer a la carte pricing for individual channels, because the networks' programming charges and the satellite-and-cable fees could adjust in response to this rule.

responses.comment: Bundling creates opportunities for rent extraction not available if this tool is removed.
I hardly ever watch television, let alone follow the industry. Sorry!
in addition, requirements of a la carte pricing are likely to be ineffective without a ban on bundled pricing.
See: Crawford, G. and Ali Yurukoglu. 2012. "The Welfare Effects of Bundling in Multichannel Television Markets." AER, 102(2):643?85																						-see background information here
Bundling is the natural pricing model with fairly homogeneous preferences. Consumers with low values would gain from unbundling.
This is an analyzable question, I just haven't seen it done. In a non-collusive market (not the reality) requirements would be unnecessary.
The bundling is likely good for some consumers and back for others.  There are few if any models of bundling in which it is bad for all.
A la carte unfortunately is not a panacea.
I can imagine scenarios with small gains to consumers in the short run.  And in the long run programming quality and variety might fall.																						-see background information here
Hard to say b/c offerings, prices might change - see, e.g. Crawford & Yurukoglu's careful AER study that shows uncertain effects.																						-see background information here
Both prix fixe and a la carte have their place. But to paraphrase Mark Knofler, I want my, I want my, I want my Daily Show.

data.question: Long run fiscal sustainability in the U.S. will require cuts in currently promised Medicare and Medicaid benefits and/or tax increases that include higher taxes on households with incomes below $250,000.

responses.comment: Health spending per recipient can rise above current levels.  Reform is needed to make health spending increases affordable given GDP growth
The mixture of rising government spending on healthcare and extremely low U.S. tax-rates is unsustainable.
Social security may be in the menu of and/or solutions as well.
It is not possible to solve U.S. budget problems without addressing the high cost of medical care and increasing taxes.
This seems obvious, but there is so much waste in health care that if we do it right, we'll very significantly reduce the costs of care.
As long as taxes on those with incomes > $250K were already increased and revenues collected were insufficient.
Rationalization is a better term than cuts. Equal health outcomes are possible with much less spending.
Fiscal gap studies (e.g. Auerbach, Kotlikoff) show this is true unless, of course, health care costs fall dramatically--but why should they?
Can't escape doing something about medical spending and even if we do, we will need more taxes on everyone																						-see background information here
The sooner we face up to this the better.																						-see background information here
Cuts or less rapid growth? Keep benefits constant in real terms or relative to wages?  If mean real growth, I agree need more tax on all.
The key is controlling health care costs growth which does not necessarily imply reneging on Medicaid/Medicare benefits promises
Arithmetic.  And too unlikely that Congress will find cuts elsewhere such as farm and oil subsidies and DoD.
The main alternative is a substantial reduction in the growth rate of medical care costs.

data.question: Assuming that Germany eventually agrees to backstop the debt of southern European countries, the eurozone as a whole will be better off if that bailout is unconditional, rather than accompanied by the labor market reforms and future budget controls that Germany is demanding of countries in return.

responses.comment: The trde off has to be help from Gaermany in exchange for reforms and conditionality.
Depends on how we measure "eurozone as a whole"
Too many other contingencies unspecified to be sure. Details matter. As does democracy.
Longer term budget controls would be better than shorter term.
The answer depends, in part, on how that conditionality is designed and implemented, which is not specified in the question, unfortunately.
Structural reforms are needed, but there is a difference between austerity as punishment and well-designed reforms.
Depends how unconditional
Although the ideal regime to bring discipline to economic policies of the southern Euro countries would be self-reliance, conditions are 2nd
Without the structural reforms these countries medium term outlook is grim.

Conditionality could help countries overcome political opposition to painful but necessary policies.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Too many conditionals to give clean answer, particularly fiscal issues.
Without structural reforms in the highly indebted countries, bailouts won't work.  The Germans aren't going to bankroll the south forever.
All these questions require better knowledge of details than I possess.

data.question: If Germany fails to bail out the southern tier of Europe, its own economy will be hurt more — because of output and asset losses — than it would be by an unconditional bailout.

responses.comment: Unfortunately, there exist no models or evidence of the costs of collapse to Germany (economists are supposed to use models and evidence).
Most likely. But Germany might be able to find alterntives in Asia or emerging Europe.
Once again, a lot depends on the level of unconditionality
in te end, Germany is going to subsidize to keep it together or else it's going to come apart.
Seems like Europe and Germany are in for bad times no matter what. There's no way Germany could bail out everything.
Too many factors about the details of a break up and the policies followed under a bailout need to be specified to answer this.

data.question: The main reason other eurozone countries need to worry about Greek banks losing access to ECB support is because the ensuing chaos in Greece could trigger bank runs in peripheral countries.

responses.comment: That is a reason certainly.
Banks runs are often triggered by self fulfulling expectations. A run in Greece could tip expectations toward a run elsewhere.
To bank runs, I would add higher interest rates and general uncertainty.
We should care about Greece and apply tough love for its own sake, not just the stability of other countries.
Greece is doomed absent a complete bailout.  But then how do Port, Italy, Spain not get the same deal?  When Greece collapses watch for runs
They might like the precedent too (if the ECB buys Greek debt, it should buy the debt of Spain, Italy, etc. as well).

data.question:
A cut in federal income tax rates in the US right now would lead to higher GDP within five years than
without the tax cut.

responses.comment: Probably, but the evidence is not as strong as you would think
would lead to higher GDP in short term  at 5 yrs, less clear & depends on whether tax cuts are budget neutral.  see fact 10 in below link.																						-see background information here
The government has to satisfy its budget constraint, so one can't say anything about a tax cut without knowing what else happens.
Results highly dependent on which rates are cut.
Everything depends on which taxes are cut.
Lots of distorting effects of taxes.  Costs of higher deficits probably modest at the 5 year horizon; eventually can't just keep borrowing.
Depends on things such as the Fed's response, how permanent it is, how it is financed, and the change in marginal vs. average tax rates.
Academic evidence supports this.  See Romer and Romer AER 2010; Bergh and Henriksen survey and book.  Ed Prescott Eli Lecture 2002.
To be effective the cut should benefit lower-income consumers. Absent measures to reduce the long-tem deficit, crisis risk could be higher.
Vague question. Whose taxes?  (The median "taxpayer" right now pays zero.)  And where does the revenue come from?
I assume you mean relative to "current law".
If the cut is permanent

data.question: A cut in federal income tax rates in the US right now would raise taxable income enough so that the annual total tax revenue would be higher within five years than without the tax cut.

responses.comment: Not aware of any evidence in recent history where tax cuts actually raise revenue. Sorry, Laffer.
This calls for a  model.  A lower tax rate applied to higher earnings could raise or lower tax revenue, depending on the extent of growth.
Moon landing was real. Evolution exists. Tax cuts lose revenue. The reasearch has shown this a thousand times. Enough already.
All evidence that I'm aware of suggest that cutting tax rates "marginally" from their current levels would DECREASE revenues, even 5 yrs out
See previous question. In addition, few studies suggest we are already at the max of the Laffer curve, though we may be close.
Seems implausible, but not impossible.
That did not happen in the past. No reason to think it would happen now.
May look plausible on a cocktail napkin (or at a cocktail party), but not true empirically in the US.
Not enough time for capital to respond much (physical, human, technology), so it would require implausibly large labor supply elasticities.																						-see background information here
This is the Laffer curve issue.  There is little (if any) evidence that rates exceed revenue-maximizing levels. See  Mankiw, Feldstein.
Are we thinking of Japan as a model for this kind of "fiscal stimulus"?
That's a Laffer!

data.question: Trade with China makes most Americans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

responses.comment: But with lots of caveats. There are many losers; transaction costs of reallocation and technology transfer have significant costs.
Failure to understand this is one of biggest common misperceptions by politicians and the general public
Also expands the pool of talent using and producing ideas.																						-see background information here
Trade with China has lowered prices paid by the average consumer, in some sectors, by significant amounts.

data.question: Some Americans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

responses.comment: Please see my paper with David Dorn and Gordon Hanson, "The China Syndrome: Local Labor Market Impacts of Import Competition in the U.S."																						-see background information here
Someone loses from almost anything.
This may be true but it depends on how much they benefit from cheaper goods and what their costs of adjusting to new jobs is.
While they may lose due to trade with China, the US free trade policies are beneficial to them on average.
Over the medium run there should be some adjustment and if China were not in the picture some other country probably would be.
-see background information here
Although there are overall benefits, some, especially with specific skills, are hurt because they cannot transition costlessly to new jobs.
Both of these are vital truths about trade & illustrate why we need both free trade & public support for those who are hurt.

data.question: An important reason why private college and university tuition has risen faster than the CPI during the past few decades is because competition for faculty members — whose potential earnings in other sectors have steadily improved — has driven up their pay faster than their productivity.

responses.comment: This is not the only reason but one factor. Universities are also spending more on other inputs, including more on administration.
Faculty salary growth relative to instructional productivity matters, but other factors have played a more important role in tuition trends.
Maybe top colleges set a price at whatever insurer (or government lender) will pay then charge a co-pay to extract remaining surplus...
There are other important  reasons too.
Productivity measured as students per professor may have decreased, but research productivity may have increased.
Sounds good for Booth, but implausible for history or English.
Increases in administrative overhead, expansion of facilities and rising health/pension costs have been more important.
I suspect this is true but it is also the case that returns to college attendance are way up, so faculty/university productivity is way up.																						-see background information here
Higher ed is like other human-service-intensive activities, bound to become more expensive relative to goods production.No special force.
This is ONE poss supply explanation.There are many demand and policy explan about which most economists answering this Q know little. Bad Q!
Productivity growth will be slow as long as we use current methods. This could change drastically if we move to online modes of instruction.
too many competing hypotheses  and I don't know enough about the evidence to pick between them
The price of skill has surely risen, so that has to be a contributor.  But colleges probably got better too.  And Bennett's Hypothesis.																						-see background information here
Wages of all educated service workers have risen over time. No evidence and competition does not imply increase greater than productivity.
While some faculty salaries have risen faster than productivity, these make up a small fraction of total university operating costs.
The rising skill premium is probably at work here.
Seems like this would vary a lot among fields.
It's not clear to me that this is an important factor outside a limited number of disciplines.

data.question: If the fiscal changes that are planned under current US law take place next year — including Bush era tax cuts expiring, Medicare payment rates to doctors being cut, the AMT applying to many more taxpayers, and automatic cuts in defense and non-defense discretionary spending kicking in — then US real GDP growth in 2013 will be lower than it would be under the CBO's alternative fiscal scenario, in which the above changes do not occur.

responses.comment: Nevertheless, I'd rather go over the 'fiscal cliff' than renew our irresponsible and unsustainable spend-don't-tax policies.
This is the debate. On net, I am still on the Keynesian side.
These measures could lower growth in 2013; the alternative has projected deficits of 5.3% (vs 1.4%) for many years; that's not good either!
Lower spending and higher taxes imply slower growth. But alternative scenario would lead to higher deficit.
you've got to be kidding me. of course it would be lower.
All macro models agree that lower product demand and higher taxes reduce current output and employment.
Some of the policies listed are anti-growth, some pro-growth, so it's hard to evaluate them succinctly as a package.
Short run contraction for sure.  But long run costs of NOT acting are growing; entitlement reform and some revenue increases are needed.
Presuming it does not have a big effect on either (1) expected fiscal policy in future years, or (2) unconventional monetary policy.																						-see background information here
Most of the action is on the tax side as CBO documents.  See my WSJ op-ed on May 18, 2012 about this.																						-see background information here
If all these changes do kick in at the end of 2012, it is hard to imagine they would be left in place for all of 2013.  So then what?
No brainer.
The worst aspect is the perduring uncertainty on what will happen

data.question:
New technology for fracking natural gas, by lowering energy costs in the United States, will make US industrial firms more cost competitive and thus significantly stimulate the growth of US merchandise
exports.

responses.comment: Natural gas prices will fall, but this may affect world price as much as U.S. price. Not sure whether U.S. production affects U.S. price.
Energy costs are set largely in the world market.  Moreover, environmental degradation could make areas less competitive in the long run.
Isn't this what the Dutch disease is about?
The question did not ask whether the associated envirnomental costs are large. I do not know the answer to that question.
Substantially lowering energy costs would make U.S. firms more competitive, but at a potentially veyr high environmental price.
But I don't know how much it would stimulate economic growth and, thus, I could not claim that it would be "substantial."
lower prices help w exports of manufacturing but i bet "significantly" is too strong.  better ? is should we export nat gas & answer is yes
More important, it raises real income and thus consumption. We don't really care about exports, only consumer well-being.
A silly gotcha q! Fracking may lower gas price but it's traded on world mkt so it won't make any country's exports more cost competitive.Duh
3 uncertain steps.  Natural gas prices might fall, but cost savings might be minimal, & share of energy costs may be too small to matter.
My colleague Frank Wolak says the cost of oil is about $16/MMBTU vs. about $2.50/MMBTU for natural gas.
Qualifications that clearly correct but unclear about how large.
In a global market, natural gas prices would fall worldwide helping foreign economies too. US-specific effects depend on market barriers.
Energy costs are too small a share of total mfg costs to have a big impact.  Labor costs are the lion's share of the total.
US energy prices are driven by world supply and demand, so the effect on US growth is realized only if global prices are moderated.
In the answer I am ignoring any potential environemtal impact

data.question: Cuba’s low per-capita income growth — 1.2 percent per year since 1960 —has more to do with Cuba’s own economic policies than with the U.S. embargo on trade and tourism.

responses.comment: Cuba is stuck in the 1950s primarily due to its internal policies not external constraints.
Of course, lost tourism opportnties, etc. might also be important.  Parsing it out an empirical question.
Sanctions are not perfectly binding, and other countries subject to U.S.sanctions have continued to grow.
Seems likely, but I know nothing concrete about the Cuban economy.
The embargo is also likely to have been an important factor, and may be partly responsible for sustaining Cuba's internal economic policies.
Trade certainly matters for growth.  Many countries though would trade with Cuba, so probably its own policies were more important.
Cuba's economic policies were flawed, but cutting off a small country from the rest of the world has detrimental effects on its growth.
communist dictatorship not exactly a growth strategy. I bet that stated growth rate even overstates reality
That is, with free-market policies and honest competent government, a Caribbean country could prosper without US trade or tourists.
If Cuba allocated labor & capital to the most productive uses, growth would be higher. The US is too small as % of world trade to prevent it
Gravity model suggests adverse effects from the embargo, but destroying the price system and using command and control instead hurts more.
The embargo was mitigated by Cuban trade with other countries (trade diversion).																						-see background information here
See Jamaica v. Barbados and other Caribb. nations that are not embargoed.  Their growth depends on local policy.  Other evidence as well.
Seems right but I cannot think of any good reason to maintain this boycot.  Hurts US biz interests and Cuban people.

data.question: Reducing the minimum retirement age in France from 62 back to age 60, permanently, would reduce long-term French economic growth and substantially raise French debt relative to GDP over time.

responses.comment: Lifespans are getting substantially longer. Working lives must get somewhat longer too to cover the cost of decades-long retirements.
Retirement comes with a substantial state pension.
People are living longer healthier lives, which means that retirement ages should be going up not down.
It will lower output and raise debt, but I don't think it will lower growth.
This would lower tax revenues, increase retirement benefits, and lower output.
It seems very likely it would increase debt relative to GDP, I don't know about GDP growth.
The word "substantially" threw me off a bit and perhaps a better answer would be "uncertain."
Solow explained why a level effect does not affect growth. We don't really know much about debt determination in the longer run.
Generational accts show that lowering the retirement age would increase future liabilities and thus future tax rates, reducing productivity
Reducing labor supply surely reduces production and tax revenues.
Lower labor supply  reduces growth. Increasing life expectancy makes this expensive, if anything retirement age should be hiked further.
The long term *level* of GDP and employment would go down in France as a result, I think.																						-see background information here
France is not in terrible budgetary shape, but this won't help.  Whether they finance spending through debt or taxes is a second-order issue
Not sure about "substantial" but otherwise clear.
Bad GDP effects if across the board reduction from 62 to 60, but if only for a small group which started work at 16, as proposed by Holland
Cutting real pension levels or providing serious incentives to delay retirement beyond 60 could mitigate the adverse impact.
It would presumbly raise debt/GDP, as pension costs would be higher and tax revenues lower.  The effect on LR growth is not at all clear.

data.question: France’s overall employment is higher today because of the 35 hour work week than it would be without a limit on weekly hours.

responses.comment: Raising employer costs does not create more employment.
There are many ways for employers and employees to evade these types of regulations, so the net effect is uncertain.
There are competing effects on the supply and demand for jobs. Lacking knowledge of the availanble research I can't estimate the net effect.
It depends on so many things, it is impossible to predict.
Labor demand determines total hours, so as long as the legal constraint binds, tightening it raises employment.Does not make it a good idea.
Hard to evaluate this policy empirically because of gen eqm effects. It's based on wrong-headed thinking, though: a fixed employment pie.
Sold on these grounds, but evidence suggested it backfired.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Research suggests that this cost-increasing restriction has not cost France much employment, but not that  it is helpful to employment.
Hours and output effects are clear, but employment effect ambiguous.
I'm not sure why this policy has ceased to be a joke.

data.question: Connecticut should pass its Senate Bill 60,  which states that during a “severe weather event emergency, no person within the chain of distribution of consumer goods and services shall sell or offer to sell consumer goods or services for a price that is unconscionably excessive.”

responses.comment: It's generally efficient to use the price mechanism to allocate scarce goods, e.g., umbrellas on a rainy day. Banning this is unwise.
Need to stimulate supply
Without defining "unconscionably," I don't know what to think about this.
Efficiency is less important than distribution under such transitory conditions.
I'm unsure how the courts will define "unconscionably excessive." Efficient allocation by market prices is good, absent monopoly effects.
statute is vague. also statute could put goods in hands of those with limited need who hoard them.
Alas, I live in this state.
Torn about this. The term "unconscionably" seems too loose - is it a 20% or 500% markup? But the goods need to be allocated somehow.
unconscionably excessive is VERY imprecise.  extreme weather can disproportionately hurt poor and this could be efficient redistribution.
Goal is to allocate suddenly scarce goods optimally. Prices are only a tool, but often the right tool. Law doesn't have a good alternative.
I sympathize w the intention but goods must be allocated in some way & prices are better than first come or fights breaking out among people
The vagueness of the law means more businesses will  shut down, which is the same as setting price to infinity, a legal price.
Seems like pandering, "post-storm cleanup or repair services" are included. It seems like those prices could reasonably soar after a storm.
Would presumably lead to misallocation and lower supply than optimal.  There are better ways to redistribute.																						-see background information here
Inefficiency from short term monopoly that results in "gouging" is secondary to losses in efficiency from a getting items to right users.
At best, symbolic. At worst, would return to price controls of the 1970s.
Seeks to prevent prices from clearing markets; never a good thing.  Standard is hopelessly vague so increases risk for affected businesses.
State legislatures should focus on more important questions.
Not needed. Big firms hold prices firm. "Entrepreneurs" with trucks help meet supply. Are the latter covered? If so, bad.
The "unconscionably excessive" language may be a way to rescue this - maybe any price at which S=D is ok. Then sb60 is just a waste of time.

data.question: The former head of the Transportation Security Administration is correct in arguing that randomizing airport “security procedures encountered by passengers (additional upper-torso pat-downs, a thorough bag search, a swab test of carry-ons, etc.), while not subjecting everyone to the full gamut" would make it "much harder for terrorists to learn how to evade security procedures."

responses.comment: Giving TSA officers discretion is a good idea; simply randomizing some procedures does not prevent terrorists learning
I am not sure that this is an economics question! I can't quantify the speed of terrorist learning....
Would like to see some evidence.  Theory is not clear on rules vs. discretion.
"Randomization" is rarely random in practice, often for good reasons. If the search intensity is the same, how is it safer to search fewer?
Then why not send mutliple terrorists to a flight? A subset would make it randomly through. Profiling is more effective than randomization.
It would probably make it harder for a terrorist to learn the procedure being used but it would make getting through the system easier.
so long as terrorists aren't too nuts to be deterred
would full set of potential procedures be public?  frequency of testing matters too.  would reduce travel hassle but could increase risks
I don't think economists have any professional expertise in this area. Anti-terrorist policy should be evidence-based, not Aristotelian.
Unconditional randomization is dumb.  Randomization CONDITIONAL on a person's characteristics w enormous penalties for dangerous items: yes.
This won't stop terrorists who are both intelligent and suicidal, as were the 9/11 guys.
Predictability does seem unwise, but I am uncertain about the most efficient ways to deliver safety.
Too complex an issue to speak to without having researched it more thoroughly.  I don't feel that I know the data or arguments.

Seems consistent with many studies that emphasize random audits as a valuable way to catch or deter bad behavior.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
While this sounds plausible, I don't feel I know enough to have an opinion.
This depends on the details.  If the methods are secret then using them rarely will make them harder to discern in which case, yes.
Is there any theory or evidence on this point?  Is it an issue about which economists have any special insight?
Of course mixed strategy is better. Most of what TSA does is just barn door closing or for show. Reinforcing the cockpit door did a lot.

data.question: Prior to the crisis, the benefits from the funding advantage that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac had by virtue of perceived government support mostly went to their shareholders, rather than into substantially lower interest rates on residential mortgages.

responses.comment: Difficult to know how gains from subsidies were distributed between shareholders and mortgage-holders pre-crisis given implicit risks.
Lower rates were also a likely outcome.
Hard to be certain.  F and F used cheap funding to massively expand mortgage financing, so may also caused a large impact on mortgage rates.
While shareholders certainly benefited, borrowers faced lower interest rates too.
research shows only small % went to borrowers. But not all went to shareholders--can't forget the rent-seeking or the emp.  compensation
there is evidence of a small impact on interest rates on loans. i suspect that shareholders AND managers captured some of the rents.
According to a leading expert, the estimates of the pass-through to borrowers vary between 1/3 and 2/3.
The fact that investment firms held onto some loans, competing with Fannie and Freddie, suggests consumers didn't capture all of subsidy.
Well documented by Greenspan in 2004!  Sadly the F & F losses was one part of the crisis that was foreseen and Congress refused to act.																						-see background information here
At least judging from mortgage rates in the U.S. vs. other OECD countries without GSEs.																						-see background information here
Private issuers could have achieved the same effect absent F/F's govt granted advantage. Shareholders' benefits were arbitraged away, though
I don't know enough about this issue to express a public opinion.
Sounds reasonable but I don't know enough to have a real opinion.

data.question: If public school students had the option of taking the government money (local, state, federal) currently being spent on their own education and turning that money into vouchers that they could use towards covering the costs of any private school or public school of their choice (e.g. charter schools), most would be better off.

responses.comment: Too much uncertainty about equilibrium effects, though it is clear that public schools are failing and alternatives are necessary.
The evidence on whether private schools and public schools outperform public schools is mixed. Students could avoid the worst schools.
Worry: only families willing to supplement the public subsidy would get excellent education for their kids. This is what happens in Chile.
Not clear what the general eq. effects might be, especially if parents have difficulty assessing the quality of new schools.
For me, this is a complex subject, ripe with costs and benefits. I hope others have done the research necessary to be confident!
For profit schools do not appear to be serving students that well. Some regulation of who can accept vouchers is desirable.
MANY would be better off; but I don't know if "most" would be better off.
But see next Q for downside for some of the most disadvantaged students
Competitive pressure on bad schools to improve and the ability for some students to escape them would be valuable.
-see background information here
The main disadvantage to vouchers is potential weakening of public schools. But those that would lose students are terrible already.

data.question:
The main drawback to allowing all public school students to take the government money (local, state, federal) currently being spent on their own education and turning that money into vouchers that they
could use towards covering the costs of any private school or public school of their choice (e.g. charter schools) would be that some students would not make an active choice and would be left with much worse peers and a weaker school.

responses.comment: Evidence for charter schools and for private schools in the U.S.suggests that the cream skimming problem is manageable.																						-see background information here
That's one drawback but not necessarily the main one. I'm worried about equilibrium quality of schools that don't charge top-ups.
There are other possible drawbacks, but this is a large one.
There is the stated cost, and there is the risk of poor active choices, as well as a risk of loss of social cohesion.
Lots of parents would also make bad choices.
more problematic are FCs @ pub schools they can't cover when cream skimming by start ups and the potential for good ones to be only for rich
Also, as in some vocational schools now, fraudulent schools might return cash under the table to parents not concerned about their kids
The effect on mid and lower tail is hard to predict. Raising the level of the lower half is very important. Upper tail overemphasized in US.
I see this as the main cost; it is not clear how long people would be trapped, but initially at least some undoubtedly would be worse off.
-see background information here
Those most likely to be hurt are already in terrible schools.  There are some others who might also be hurt, but probably not by much.
This is one major cost but others are possible and it is unclear how to quantify them.
I am sure that is a drawback, but am less sure that it is the main one.
This problem is made worse if schools can be selective
Problem can be solved with vouchers that incentivate good schools to  search and enroll underpivileged kids																						-see background information here

data.question: The average size of the 19 financial firms that just completed the Federal Reserve stress tests (i.e. the CCAR) would be substantially smaller if they did not have implicit government support.

responses.comment: Tbtf implies cheap debt financing of assets.  There are other reasons to be big.  Big clients often want large deals or one-stop shopping.
not really about size, it's about interconnection
Bailouts seem to increase skew in all countries, but I don't know of counterfactual evidence to answer question
There are efficiency reasons for size & there is the implicit support. Regulatory burden is now higher.  No telling how much they'd shrink.
Some might not have survived 2008-2009, so pretty clearly correct.
Certainly smaller, but "substantrially" smaller is unclear and subjective.
Presumably they are all competing to be in the TBTF group.

data.question: The 19 financial firms that just completed the Federal Reserve stress tests (i.e. the CCAR) are big primarily because of economies of scale and scope, rather than because of implicit government support.

responses.comment: They are larger than they should be because of bailout guarantees and subsidies to leverage. There may also be economies of scale and scope.
Both factors are likely to be present, but we lack sufficient research on magnitudes.
explicit support like FDIC much more important than implict supports
This is not my area of expertise, so I would rather defer to the experts on this.
Very uncertain about the size of either the efficiency advantages or the net subsidy.  US firms usually are large relative global peers.
-see background information here
Both are important but don't know of persuasive studies on relative importance of these two factors.
Clearly there is a government subsidy element, but its size is hard to quantify, and therefore compare to other factors.
Difficult to know how to interpret "big" and "primarily."

data.question: Changes in U.S. gasoline prices over the past 10 years have predominantly been due to market factors rather than U.S. federal economic or energy policies.

responses.comment: Supply and demand for oil are relatively global. US regulation does, however, have an influence on domestic supplies of some products.
US domestic policy has only tiny effects on the world price of oil. US foreign policy is probably more relevant than energy policy.
Policy has basically permitted free trade in oil and oil products.
Direct effect (e.g.via oil reserve) of Fed energy policy on short term prices=negligible. Effect on long-run prices could be considerable.
-see background information here
Govt policy that affects supply feeds into market prices over the long run.  Short run variations are almost completely unrelated to govt.
US energy policy (about where drilling is permitted, energy taxes) affects market outcomes, so an either-or question is a little off base.

data.question: Freer trade improves productive efficiency and offers consumers better choices, and in the long run these gains are much larger than any effects on employment.

responses.comment: Economists often understate short-term employment costs, which are significant and unequally distributed, but probably less than benefits.
Gains and losses are not spread evenly. Retraining programs are an important part of trade policy.
Not sure how to compare the gains to consumers with long run effects on employment. They might both be positive!
Note that not everyone is better off.
The "gains" are positive a general additive sense, but that does not avoid costs to some.
Consider any tribe or group that was isolated from trade for centuries to see the long run results of autarky
General message of trade theory. But the question is how long the "long run" is.
Trade creates tremendous benefits but causes substantial job losses  Do current policies fully compensate displaced workers?  Probably not
liberalization has such large long-run benefits that it can fund short-run dislocation assistance
The world's endowment is allocated more efficiently under free trade, making the avg person better off. Individuals may face adjustmt costs.
Description of the gains is right, and long run employment might be higher too.  We can try to compensate short run job losers.
Jim Feyrer has some ingenious papers finding evidence of income gains from trade.																						-see background information here
Estimates used by CEA of the effect of complete free trade are as large as $500 billion per year - enormous even if off by a scalar.
I agree with the statement as worded.  There could be other, less desirable, impacts as well.
Gains are sufficiently large to finance the compensation of workers in loosing sectors.
If that's not right, almost all of economics is wrong.
Nevertheless, there are winners and losers.  Trade does not make everybody better off, and a good policy should take this into account.
This needs more nuance: most people win, and the winners gain a lot.  But there are losers from trade who have not in fact been compensated.

data.question: On average, citizens of the U.S. have been better off with the North American Free Trade Agreement than they would have been if the trade rules for the U.S., Canada and Mexico prior to NAFTA had remained in place.

responses.comment: NAFTA was small potatoes relative to rising China trade. My hunch is that both costs and benefits were modest.
On "average" is an important qualifier.
See my answer to question A.  However, short- and medium-run effects of NAFTA, especially on employment and wages in the US, unclear.
True for the average but complicated issues of social welfare functions here. better compensation for folks who do not gain might help
Not to mention benefits to Canadians and Mexicans! We should take a global perspective.
The question is about averages. Distributional income and employment effects hard to measure, but probably significant.
-see background information here
Although difficult to estimate, there is little evidence of negative effects of NAFTA and the positives are obvious.
Such is the result of much of the empirical literature.
This is true about the average.
But the gains have probably been very small.
The key word is on average: there are large distributional effects.

data.question: Because the U.S. Treasury bailed out and backstopped banks (by injecting equity into them in late 2008, and later committing to provide public capital to any banks that failed the stress tests and could not raise private capital), the U.S. unemployment rate was lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without these measures.

responses.comment: Macro performance depends partly on credit from banks, which would have otherwise been impaired. Europe has a related growth issue now,
If the banking system had collapsed, unemployment would certainly have been higher in 2010.
the fact it was necessary doesn't mean we should be happy about it
There is some strong evidence that the lending channel is real.  See the below link.																						-see background information here
There were much better policies, but what was done was better than nothing, give the bad policies that preceded.
Without Fed intervention the banking system would have collapsed.
They could have been tougher on pay and dividends, but just look across the pond to see a much worse alternative way of proceeding.
The Fed would have purchased more private assets without TARP, and  who knows what the Fed/Congress would have tried instead.																						-see background information here
This statement reflects my best judgment, based on a  range of macroeconomic literature, but it would be difficult to prove beyond a doubt.
It is hard to imagine the mess we would still be in if most of our large banks had failed.
See Ch 7 of Friedman & Schwartz's Monetary History.  It's fortunate we had a Central Banker who'd read it and had the courage to act on it.
Not my area but it seems like it had to have helped.
The question presumes Paulson?s forced alternative. If the only choice is between evil and Armageddon, evil might look ok.

data.question: Loosening current licensing restrictions on the range of services that nurses, physician assistants, dental hygienists and pharmacists are permitted to perform would help patients on balance, because the additional safety risks would be small compared to the decreased costs in waiting time and fees.

responses.comment: Lots of evidence that occupational licensing is excessive. But I cannot speak specifically about the medical profession.																						-see background information here
There is some evidence on these issues; there is less study of this than one might hope.
The IOM has summarized all the evidence, and it shows this.
Tort law is a plenty good safeguard for our safety.
If licensing restrictions reflect training requirements, it is not clear that lowering training standards would be beneficial.
there seems little doubt that licensing restrictions raise costs but there is only a little evidence on the safety risks.
Economic logic suggests too tight licensing because of lobbying by affected professionals.
This is a question to which only an economist in the field would know the best answer.  Knowing what one knows is the essence of expertise.
Everywhere else in the world people without the title "doctor" seem to be able to do more, seems like we should move in this way too.
-see background information here
Finding the right balance is difficult, but a wholesale ban on licensing would on net confuse patients are probably be a net loss.
This is surely true for a small relaxation; for a very large relaxation risks would surely outweigh benefits.
There are surely some restrictions that could be loosened.  Agreeing on which ones they are might be harder.
Pharmacists must be the most underemployed professionals. Lots of schooling to count pills. In France they actually do stuff.
A sensible approach in many cases is certification, which provides information, increases choice, and reduces costs.																						-see background information here

data.question:
Bans on the short selling of financial securities, such as stocks and government bonds, lead
to prices that are further, on average, from their fundamental values.

responses.comment: I think this would depend on the type of mispricing. E.g., heterogeneous priors with shortselling can lead to wide swings in prices.
I would have said strongly, but there may be instances  where one could use other securities to synthesize or mimic the short.
Restricted trade on one side of the market, if binding, by definition prevents matching supply with demand, and thus  "fundamental" prices.																						-see background information here
Even with short selling, it can be hard to stop a bubble. Without it, well...
more impt question is whether shorts produce info that improve firm governance.  mandatory disclosure rules raise firm profits & stock price																						-see background information here
If short selling is lawful and fraud is not prosecuted, there is a big opportunity to spread fraudulent rumors and gain by shorting.
On average definitely. By the nature of learning processes, not always.
This desperate policy does not work.  See Geanakoplos for the dangers of leverage and the inability to short in producing instability.
-see background information here
Most studies that I have seen indicate that banning short selling has no effect on average price, but does lead to higher variance
Seems logical as a matter of economic theory. As a matter of practice, I don't know the relevant evidence.
Subject to the qualification of market corners.
I can imagine different scenarios, and I don't believe there is clear-cut empirical evidence.
If they have any effect, it's got to be in that direction.
I've never seen any evidence on this point.
If Bob Shiller had succeeded in making it possible to short real estate markets, some of the bubbles might have been abated.

data.question:
Because of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, the U.S. unemployment rate was
lower at the end of 2010 than it would have been without the stimulus bill.

responses.comment: Subsidizing employment leads employment to go up, other things equal. Adverse impacts through growth incentives might take time.
quit with the politics and just go read the official ARRA reports for a review of the evidence
All reasonable models have this implication, but there's enough the models are missing...
High confidence on an issue like this would be foolish.That being said, the depressing effect of future liabilities likely exceeded benefits
There has been no serious study of this. Most analyses that try to analyze 2008-2011 are too simple and/or plagued with mathematical errors.
But this is an incredibly low bar.
Caveat: how much was it offset by less agressive (than otherwise) unconventional monetary policy?																						-see background information here
The estimates are varied and the highest are based on ex ante models, not experienced-based data.  The upper bound estimate is low.
See the various CBO studies on the subject.
With the caveat that there is no perfect experiment, the evidence suggests it boosted the economy.
-see background information here
Block grants to the states allowed them to cut education, health, and other services by less as state tax revenues fell.
Even clearer by 2011.  Why ask about 2010 when much of the stimulus is slow acting?  The stimulus project on my way to work just finishing.
At the very minimum the transfer to the states prevented them from firing state employees. But I do not know how big the overall effect was

data.question: Taking into account all of the ARRA’s economic consequences — including the economic costs of raising taxes to pay for the spending, its effects on future spending, and any other likely future effects — the benefits of the stimulus will end up exceeding its costs.

responses.comment: This is in part an empirical question and I think it would be difficult to answer this with any certainty.
I am working on this question now using my macro model.  Any thoughts on what discount rate to use for increased future unemployment?
This all depends on how much you value avoiding short-run collapse versus the costs long-term.  But it?s not free.
U.S. was losing 700K jobs per month & K markets were not functioning.  economy was in crisis & ARRA helped, along with K markt interventions
I'd agree that the results are likely to be on the positive side, but I can think of future crashes caused by the accumulation of debt
Feedback effects too complicated to calculate. My best guess is that the program was marginally beneficial, but monetary easing helped more.
same as above
Same as response to previous question.
Payoffs to special interests (& associated political costs that paralyzed other efforts) made it far less effective than it could have been
Depends critically on how permanent and useful the stimulus to government spending.
The cost is the enormous and tough-to-reverse growth of government. This swamps even high estimates of benefits. See my op-eds. that explain																						-see background information here
Hard to know how the increased debt will be paid (Congress could make a mess of it), so some uncertainty here.
Not sure how to interpret "effects on future spending" but I'm persuaded the alternative (without the ARRA) would have put us on a bad path.
This will depend on future tax and spending policies.
How can anyone imagine this question is answerable, given the current state of economic science?
The part of the economy where we are still losing jobs is gov employment.  Gov can create its own recession by being short sighted.

data.question: Local ordinances that limit rent increases for some rental housing units, such as in New York and San Francisco, have had a positive impact over the past three decades on the amount and quality of broadly affordable rental housing in cities that have used them.

responses.comment: Rent control discourages supply of rental units. Incumbent renters benefit from capped prices. New renters face reduced rental options.
Rent control will have similar effects to any price control.
I suspect zoning and building limits have been more important.
Rent control lowers incentives to invest and increases incentives to hold underoccupied rentals
Price controls create disincentives to increase supply. But without rent control, no one outside the top 1% would be left in Manhattan.
Great if you are lucky enough to get one of those apartments!  Bad for all others The worst policies apply to new construction.
Rent controlled units do not end up in the hands of low income people. Rent control discourages landlords from creating modest priced units.

Land use regulations restricted supply as well.  Plus, rent controls lead to misallocation of housing units.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Even in the short run, rent control induces owners to move property to other uses, misallocate the property, and substitute non-price alloc.
I'm skeptical - but don't know enough about the programs to have a very informed view.
While well intended, theoretically they also likely limit expansions in supply and improvements in quality.
Unless al the textbooks are wrong, this is wrong.
The planets are lined up here: theory and evidence point in the same direction.
Next questions: does the sun revolve around the earth.

data.question:
The
typical chief executive officer of a publicly traded corporation in the
U.S. is paid more than his or her marginal contribution
to the firm's value.

responses.comment: CEOs received substantial rents, partly because pay is set by negotiation and with weak oversight. But bad CEO can do huge damage to a firm.
I am fairly confident that the literature is not conclusive on this for the "typical" CEO.
Hard to test this.
Big discrepancy between  CEO compensation and long-term shareholder returns.
There are reasons to believe CEO wages = marginal product & to think they are paid more, but I'm unaware of any credible empirical evidence
Very hard to measure MP of CEO. Harder still to assess MP of alternatives to CEO. So CEO mkt not competitive in normal sense.
This depends on how the CEO adds value--as a % increase on the firm's profit base or as an absolute amt.  If the former, no is more likely.																						-see background information here
Commonly asserted but it is very hard to tell.  The fact that CEO pay fell during the 2000s is not widely known.																						-see background information here
-see background information here
Obviously, there are abuses, but the exec. market is reasonably competitive.  Some contribute far more to shareholder value than their pay.
I do not know enough about the empirical evidence to weigh in.
US CEO current pay much higher than in other countries and than in the past suggesting over-pricing
While trends in CEO pay may suggest this, I know of no hard evidence, particularly none that bears on the "typical" US corporation.
2 Reasons: 1. Winner's curse. 2 asymetric payoffs (CEO wins when things go well and does not suffer when things go sour. Combo = overpay.
If you had asked the question the other way (we know that they are paid their marginal valuation) I would have strongly diagreed.

data.question:
Mandating that U.S. publicly listed corporations must allow
shareholders to cast a non-binding vote on executive compensation was a good
idea.

responses.comment: Yes, but not sufficient given that disperse shareholders may not have sufficient incentives to monitor performance.
I weakly disagree. I suspect that this requirement is ineffective -- so it silences some critics without solving any agency problems.
I don't think this policy will do much though their have been a few high profile institution-led No votes on these resolutions.
I don't know if it affected pay, but shareholders should have the right to express some view on this.
Seems to have had little effect so far.  Gives stockholders potentially more power at probably low costs of administering it.
"Non-binding" means the mandate has no teeth
Difficult to see harm but there is plenty of evidence that more sunshine can improve firm performance.  See below link for an example																						-see background information here
Ex ante, giving management a significant stake in a company has its logic, so cutting the payoff ex post may be a problem.
Direct shareholder intervention has benefits as well as costs. Costs much underappreciated in current climate. Still, some oversight needed.
The vote is good for governance, but mandating it is not. If you don't like how executives are paid, sell the shares.
We know that it does not seemed to have changed outcomes much so far.  Does take up some resources, but the threat might wind up being ok.
Mandates are not necessary.  Potential shareholders do not have to own shares in companies whose corp gov is not to their liking.
Sounds like a good idea in theory, but I do not know enough about implementation to weigh in.
Unlikely to have a strong impact
It is hard to see how a non-binding vote by generally uninformed shareholders is likely to have benefits exceeding its coss.
More transparency is good.  Better would be to require disclosure of the process consultants use to set pay. Benchmarking is anit market.
The cost is minimal, while the benefit of transparency and societal pressure against excesses high.

data.question:
One of the leading
reasons for rising U.S. income inequality over the past three decades is that
technological change has affected workers with some skill sets differently than
others.

responses.comment: But, importantly, it is not the only factor. The other three are: slower growth in the supply of skills; institutional changes; and trade.
There is a lot of evidence that technical change has favored more skilled workers over the past 3 decades																						-see background information here
It's not the only factor. Two others: slowing supply of skilled workers, and (probably) distorted pay-setting at the very top.
There are certainly many other factors, such as the tax code, etc.
Increasing demand for skill is an underlying factor driving increased inequality though institutional changes are also important.
I think there is excellent evidence on this, though it is also clear that much else is going on. Nor does the tech story imply benignity.
This partial explanation does not lessen the policy importance of addressing the downside effects, including loss of social cohesion.
But that is only the demand side.  The slowdown in the supply of these skill sets is just as important (or more).  You need the SS side too.
The data are pretty obvious that this is a key factor.  Not the only one, but a very significant one.
Seems self-evident but technological change cannot be measured directly; is this a falsifiable hypothesis?  what would Karl Popper say?
Managers and financial salesmen account for most of the earnings growth at the top end. Not clear that tech change is responsible.
It's likely that technological progress has favored high aptitude people. The evidence is only indirect,however: it's a residual explanation
Hard to quantify the exact contribution, but it is undoubtedly big.  Also tricky in that it partially interacts with education and trade.
-see background information here
The distribution has spread out at all relevant deciles.  The question that remains is why the skill gap is not closing.
Although this is a common view, the causal factors are too complex to untangle unambiguously.
Although there is some evidence to the contrary, the nature of occupational change and returns to schooling suggest it's important.
Big debate on institutions vs. technology in labor economics. Technology is too narrow an explanation as it interacts with institutions.
-see background information here
Investment-specific technical change together with capital-skill complementarity explains much of the increase in the skill premium.
Compared to what?  More than 1% have good tech skills. Education disparities and tax policies surely more important.
This is hard to quantify, but the limited evidence is supportive.
The statement is likely to be true but it does not address why the technology moved that way.

data.question:
If the US replaced
its discretionary monetary policy regime with a gold standard,
defining a "dollar" as a specific number of ounces of gold, the
price-stability and employment outcomes would be better for the average
American.

responses.comment: A gold standard would have avoided the policy mistakes of the 2000s, but still likely that discretionary policy is  useful during recessions
A time series plot of the price of consumption in ounces of gold, and then in US dollars, clarifies that gold is not a stable standard.
eesh.  Has it come to this?
Modern interest-rate feedback rules (Taylor rules) do a vastly better job. The instability of the relative price of gold is way too high.
All insights from the past and current crises go against a gold standard.
Since gold has supply and demand dynamics of its own, for reasons unrelated to its use as a store of value, Americans would exposed to risk.
The relative price of gold can be very volatile.
A   gold standard regime would be a disaster for any large advanced economy.  Love of the G.S. implies macroeconomic illiteracy.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
The gold standard adds credibility when a country lacks discipline.The cost is monetary polic flexibility. The tradeoff is unclear in US.
This proposal makes no sense in the modern world. Just look at the Eurozone to see the consequences.
There are much better ways to avoid excessive inflation, while maintaining the flexibility of a fiat currency.
Why tie to gold?  why not 1982 Bordeaux?

data.question:
There are many factors
besides US inflation risk that influence the current dollar price of gold.

responses.comment: Gold is intrinsically close to useless, so its price is determined as a "bubble".
new gold reserve discoveries and changes in the technology of extraction, to name two simple examples
So many that they would never fit in 140 characters...
Gold is used as a safe haven in financial crisis. That has little to do with US inflation.
Go see a dentist.
This is a market like any other.  The supply of gold and other sources of demand affect its price in real terms relative to other goods.
There is no discernible connection between gold price and CPI movements in the period since the demonetization of gold in 1971.
Demand for gold seems to come from concern about the entire financial system.  There are better ways to hedge inflation risk.

data.question:
In general,
using more congestion charges in crowded transportation
networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak
fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds
to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

responses.comment: See "The High Cost of Free Parking" by Donald Shoup																						-see background information here
In general, the theory for pricing of  congestion externalities would be analogous to pricing other externalities.
Congestion creates many externalities, including the health costs of pollution.
Not all citizens ate better off. Huge geographic disparities.
Pricing at marginal value  has  benefits.  A simple version of this is known as the first welfare theorem. The proposal goes toward this.
Prices allocate goods more efficiently to consumers.
but be careful about things with large compliance costs as a share of revenue.  Waiting 15 mins to pay 20 cent toll is very dumb
Congestion is a pure waste of resources, so eliminating it leaves lots of scope for improving standards of living
Empirical evidence supports it. And theoretically it also makes sense.
Yes, so long as congestion taxes are based on the TRUE social costs of congestion and really reduce other taxes.  Let prices allocate demand

-see background information here
															-see background information here
The failure to price things like time results in overuse. Pricing has already proven to be effective in applicable situations, revenue aside
There is a strong efficiency case but there still could be distributional consequences for some.
Potentially but it would depend on the magnitude of the disutility associated with congestion for those with lower elasticities of demand.
The only hard part is using the revenue in a reasonable way.
Of course the use of the tax revenue is key.  Question: why do no GOP candidates favor such policies?  Answer: more anti tax than pro market
Congestion fees can serve well to match private costs with social costs, as long as they are implemented with minimal transaction costs.

data.question: A tax on the carbon content of fuels would be a less expensive way to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions than would a collection of policies such as “corporate average fuel economy” requirements for automobiles.

responses.comment: See Chris Knittel's forthcoming paper in Journal of Economic Perspectives on this topic: Reducing Petroleum Consumption from Transportation
Taxing the externality would be much more efficient than CAFE - but the challenge is getting the tax rate right
That is not to suggest that a carbon cap and trade program is necessarily worse than a tax.  But CAFE worse.
The indirect route of fleet fuel standards causes distortions in the auto industry and fails to capture other sources of C02 emissions.
Always better to be direct. So long as administration of a fuel tax is as easy as other indirect regulation it is better.
Too vague... It is not clear how this tax would be implemented.
the one is specifically aimed at carbon so seems almost tautological.  not necess true for other considerations like natl security etc
totally basic economics!
If social cost sensitive to total emissions or hard to measure, quantity controls may be better than tax.
If the objective is to reduce GHGs then the best policy is to tax GHG emissions. CAFE standards will initially do little.
Would help equalize marginal cost across sources.  Revenue can keep marginal tax rates on work, saving lower than otherwise.																						-see background information here
This compares two ineffective approaches.  The magnitude of this problem is so great that no sufficient carbon tax is feasible worldwide.
In principle, yes. In practice, would depend a huge amount on the design of the tax vs other policies, so hard to give a blanket answer.
Many studies on this, see RfF on national energy policies, Dec 2010 as example.
I believe this to be the case in theory although in practice may be a more effective way to achieve environmental objectives.
Since a carbon tax is politically infeasible how about hiking the gas tax by a dollar and then index it. We now have a negative carbon tax.
This is as clear as economics gets; provides incentives to find minimally costly ways to reduce emissions.																						-see background information here

data.question:
All
else equal, making drugs illegal raises street prices for those drugs because
suppliers require extra compensation for the risk of incarceration and other
punishments.

responses.comment: Only caveat (more drugs today increase addiction, demand and prices in the future) seems insufficient to reverse basic supply-demand result.
See AER paper by Carlos Dobkin and Nancy Nicosi on price effects of the U.S. government's disruption of the methamphetamine market																						-see background information here
Also depends on demand response - may be more consumers if legal, expanding demand - but that seems likely to be smaller than supply effect
Price increase isn't only due to risk-- constraints on production, costs of avoiding authority all raise MC.
"All else equal" seems to imply something about taxation if legal.
Not sure what is "all things equal," such as demand being constant, taxation of legal drugs, etc.
Illegality leads to high prices and crime.
Supply shifts to the left b/c of a host of factors including paying off authorities and related drug supply restrictions (plus added costs).
I claim no expertise on this subject but the proposition is basic economics
Basic micro economics
-see background information here
Quantities also adjust because of the effect on demand but the supply price is higher when drugs are illegal.
Or reduces quality. Presumably illegality also reduces demand, but assuming cost increase is the more relevant & applying Econ 1.
Consumers also face risk of punishment, but the evidence is that the effect on suppliers dominates - substantially raising street prices.
Basic micro.  Illegality also rules out some efficient forms of production & distribution.
A test of whether the panel is awake.

data.question:
The Netherlands restrictions on “soft drugs” combined with a moderate tax
aimed at deterring their consumption would have lower social costs than
continuing to prohibit use of those drugs as in the US.  (Click here for a
summary of the Netherlands restrictions.)

responses.comment: The US war on drugs appears to be a total and very costly failure, so alternatives have to be tried and this one seems to have worked well.
Marijuana is less dangerous than alcohol. Criminal enforcement for minor marijuana infractions is a waste of societal resources.
Depends on "social costs" and how harms of drug use, effect on crime, policing efforts, tax revenue enter social welfare function.
Too many poorly measured factors to have real certainty about this.
This is an empirical question.  Depends ion how the law affects social acceptance of drugs, whether soft drugs are gateway drugs, etc.
The current regime of drug enforcement has unacceptably high cost in crime and prison
yes, especially if combined with an anti-drug campaign similar to the campaign against smoking in the U.S.
Depends on how "moderate" the tax is.
very difficult to judge.  presumably, usage would be higher.  does reduced productivity of users count as a social cost?
My limited understanding is that there is evidence of harm from cannabis.

The evidence on this is very unclear because many of the consequences are not only hard to estimate, but hard to value.  See Pudney papers..																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Have to trade off the costs of the likely extra usage against savings from wasted resources trying to stop the inevitable.
-see background information here
Two issues confound this. The effect of lower prices and more availability on the young and drug tourism.
Must be better approaches to drug policy, but don't have an informed view on this one.
Although drug use would increase, the diminished use of violence should yield a net gain.
Not at all simple: evidence weak, hard to weight various kinds of costs.
War on drugs dumber than invading Iraq in search of WMDs. Treat pot like booze. Would also lower prison population.
-see background information here

data.question:
Credible assumptions for
inflation, GDP growth and primary budget deficits in Italy imply that either
the Debt-to-GDP ratio in Italy would increase sharply if Italian
interest rates on 10-year government debt remained at the November 30
level of around 7 percent or Italy would lose access to the bond
market.

responses.comment: The question presumes that there is no possibility of debt restructuring that could keep debt to GDP stable and grant access to bond markets
these rates are unsutainable but a program of deep structural reforms and budget tightening could reestablish credibilty of reduce spreads
This is not really my area, though I nonetheless understand the question to be roughly true.
Not necessarily "sharply" in time, but significantly over time, yes, absent some other big structural shift.
Italy as a problem likely to get worse before it gets better.
This question is too confusing to answer.
not good. not good.
Zero real GDP growth and huge outstanding debt make the deficit growth high even though Italy has a small primary surplus.
At those interest rates, Italy's interest payments will become an ever increasing share of its govt budget, under any plausible tax scenario
Basic arithmetic of debt dynamics shows that this constellation cannot persist.

Debt 120%, deficit 4%, growth 4% (nominal) --> ratio falling.  Higher rates (say pushing the deficit on a path toward 8%) --> ratio rising.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
															-see background information here
															-see background information here
															-see background information here
Not sure about "sharply" but seems hard to lower debt-to-GDP at those interest rates without better growth prospects.
Hard to imagine any feasible austerity plan that would work at 7% or more, given the negative effect on real GDP growth and inflation.
Simply have not done the necessary quantitative work.

data.question:
Absent outside help to deal
with runs, such as a pledge of fiscal support from Germany or an unlimited
commitment by the ECB to buy bonds, there is no spending-and-tax plan
Italy can announce that would be credible enough
to hold its interest rates low enough to stabilize its
Debt-to-GDP ratio.

responses.comment: This question again rules out the possibility of debt restructuring. Also not clear that effective ECB commitments must be unlimited.
italy needs deep domestic refroms and a solution of the eurpoean French-German impasse on the role of the ECB
Again, this is definitely not my area, and I might have preferred the question to include a "likely", but I believe it is likely to be true.
I am pessimistic, absent outside help, but this is a strong statement that Italy has no way at all to do it on its own. I'm uncertain.
Something big by way of a guarantee is the surest way to stability of italian bonds.
Hard to know what others would take as credible.  Really a psychological question.
without growth, all the austerity you can muster will not solve the problem
This is a question about Italian politics where I'm no expert, but progress so far in lowering real wages and improving TFP has been small.
Stabilization requires short-term outside liquidity support, a credible long-term fiscal plan along with lower interest rates. Go together.
A political economy question on the spending side!  (The tax side is fairly clear.)  It fits my knowledge of Italy's ability to cut spending
Hard call, you can't say the country is insolvent  -- but how will Italy roll all of its debt if there is no outside support?
Credibility is the key, so "outside help" to keep borrowing cost down would be a critical element in success of any austerity plan.
Simply have not done the necessary quantitative work.
Modest spending cuts, together with substantial regulatory reform, would probably solve the problem.
Above my pay grade.

data.question:
There are no consequential distortions created
by the tax preference that favors obtaining health insurance through employers.

responses.comment: Linking health insurance to (current) employment distorts both labor market choices and health care decisions.
We need consumers of healthcare to be *less* insulated from the price system, not more. The tax credit provides insulation and subsidy!
Creates distortion in both health and labor markets.
There are giant distortions.
Subsidizing health insurance through the tax system causes people to be "over-insured," and causes the system to cater to the over-insured.
Note that this is not a welfare statement.  Many of the distortions are good (eg pooling benefits).  And welfare requires a counterfactual.
This seems an indirect approach.
just to name one distortion, dental insurance is often bought when few employees would pay that much with their own money.
Lowers the price of health insurance encouraging excessive health care spending. Contributes to rising h.c.costs. Benefits higher incomes.
There are many distortions of great consequence created by the policy.
Pretty clear directionally but question as to how impactful is the distortion in magnitude.
likely increases labor supply and causes "too much" health care consumption for insured.  i THINK the "job lock" literature didn't find much
Financing health care through employers is crazy. It's essential to move to a system where people pay for health, with some gov help.
All selective subsidies create distortions.
Tax prefs create job lock, prevent formation of a more competitive health insurance mkt, & discourage insurance coverage among young workers
One significant possible distortion is a reduction in labor mobility.
Lock in is inefficient and there is no good reason to use the tax code to subsidize health insurance purchases.

1. Subsidizes health spending. 2. Increases other marginal tax  rates. 3. Reduces job mobility.																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
The is much evidence on this point and alternative proposals that could remove distortions and provide better health care incentives.
Many well documented distortions, including differential treatment of people, and not available when people most need it.
It likely distorts both health care decisions and the composition of total compensation.
Job lock distortion but not certain that tax preference is key factor making employers provide health care
This is pretty basic, as is the fact that the distortions (econ speak for costs to society) are huge.
Yes the tax causes distortions but without Obamacare or some equivalent, we need health insurance provided by employers.
It is apparent that linking insurance to employment is distortionary.  Measuring the magnitude of these distortions is a challenge.

data.question:
Federal mandates that
government purchases should be “buy American” unless there are exceptional
circumstances,
such as in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, have a significant positive impact on U.S. manufacturing employment.

responses.comment: 4 years ago I would have disagreed. Recent evidence (Autor Dorn Hanson) suggests yes.Caveat: costs from higher prices & other inefficiencies																						-see background information here
The policies will boost demand for U.S. manufacturing, at least in short run. But other countries may retaliate.
Hard to believe this does much at all. But I'm speaking based on my prior. I've not seen any rigorous analysis.
This is an empirical statement, tough to evaluate thoroughly.
If the "buy American" clause raises the price of public works, then fewer of them will be undertaken, which will undercut the mandate.
Seems wildly unlikely that the magnitude would be significant, even without retaliatory or GE effects,
Seems to hard disagree with the statement as posed. But that does not  at all mean that this is a good idea!
Question is too vague.
Highly unlikely. Strict enforcement would lead to retaliation and trade wars, hurting US employment. Lax enforcement would have small effect
The impact is quite uncertain, depends on elasticities (degree of substitutability, price differences, impact on input prices, etc.).
These campaigns may be able to tilt employment so that there is more manufacuting employment, but I suspect that the impact is not great.
