While it is possible to write a model in which the intended effect would occur, govt purchases are too small a share to make a model work.
It raises costs which increases taxation. No net gain to anyone in the long run.
Less than 0.1% according to one plausible calculation -- even ignoring possible retaliation (not to mention being a WTO violation).																						-see background information here
Not aware of much evidence on this, but government purchases are substantial, so expect at least some effects.
Too confusing.
I don't think such mandates ever have much impact. In theory they lead the dollar to appreciate, crowding out any positive effect.
Given vagueness in the definition of whether a product is "American" I suspect this provision may be more symbolic than not.
There will surely be some positive effect, but I would be surprised if it were non-trivial.
The exception in which "buy American" makes a difference is in military production for which the government is the main market.
Likely increases employment in specific firms, but at relatively high cost.  Effect on aggregate employment unclear to me.

data.question:
Eliminating tax
deductions for non-investment personal interest expenses (e.g., on mortgages),
with reductions in personal tax rates that are both budget neutral and keep the
burden of taxes by income group the same, would lead to more efficient
financing decisions by individuals.

responses.comment: There is no reasonable Pigovian justification for mortgage deductions, which are not only distortionary but also generally regressive.
The interest deduction distorts consumption decisions in favor of housing and narrows the income tax base, requiring higher tax rates.
A caveat is that moving from the current system to one without interest deductions could be disruptive.
Primary impact is likely to be on house prices.
Hard to do the distributional effects in my head, let alone do the full second best calculation.
Trick question. i object. financing could be less efficient-- it would bias to pay cash instead of borrowing. housing choice would be better
The mortgage interest rate deduction is only for housing and distorts household decisions relative to other goods and services.
there is some question in the data about how large these effects are, in practice, but the economic idea is straightforward
The interest deduction offsets the wedge of high property taxes. We really need a comprehensive consumption tax, not little changes.
In theory, of course, but unclear how to measure it in practice. Note: tax subsidies for debt may serve other social purposes.
There is no good reason for using the tax system to subsidize home purchases.  Lower rates and a broader tax base are the way to go.

-see background information here
															-see background information here
More important than financing choice is likely the excess of housing investment relative to other investment that would be reduced.
This is well studied. Perhaps some reservations for externalities of home ownership, but that has proven elusive.
Better to level the playing field in terms of investments.
Ideal solution is to tax imputed rent. As this is difficult in practice, it's better to not allow interest deductions
Unclear what is meant by the "efficiency" of financing decisions by individuals.
Can't just drop this suddenly given the state of the housing market so best to phase it out very gradually.

data.question:
Reducing the
deductibility of interest expenses for non-financial businesses to
equalize the overall tax cost of debt and equity financing, while using
the extra revenue to reduce personal and corporate tax rates in a budget
neutral fashion that also keeps the burden of taxes the same, would lead to
more efficient financing decisions by firms.

responses.comment: Caveat: the appropriate corporate tax reduction is important here, since many firms do not have access to equity financing.
Corporate finance is not my area.
Not sure I can characterize all of what would happen if we had debt-equity switch.
Subsidizing debt increases expected financial distress costs, only some of which are internalized by firms' managers and shareholders.
sounds like introducing a level playing field for debt and equity...what am I missing..different tax rates at individual level i suppose.
same rationale as on the personal side.  Clearly there would be transition issues for existing capital but the basic idea is straightforward
Can't even think about removing interest deduction while retaining taxation of interest receipts. Again, we need cons tax, not little fixes.																						-see background information here
Equity financing plays small role for mature firms, Leveling the playing field may not matter that much.
-see background information here
This is the standard issue of subsidizing debt financing over equity financing and the proposal moves in the right direction.
Complicated b/c financing structures are currently tangled, so it will be impossible to achieve assumptions. Unclear about financial firms.
I do not like the distinction between financial and other firms proposed here. An allowance for corporate equity seems preferable.
Case for "yes" is stronger for financial firms.

data.question:
Unless
they have inside information, very few investors, if any, can consistently make
accurate predictions about whether the price of an individual stock will rise
or fall on a given day.

responses.comment: Experts are generally no better than the rest of us -- often worse.
There is short run predictability but consistently on a given day is a high standard.
I suspect 'very few' is an important qualifier.
Provided "very few" includes the minority of hedge fund traders who clearly can.
Despite attempts, there is no solid empirical evidence or convincing theoretical support for the contrary view.
Randomness is the best ex ante explanation of a given stock's movement on a given day.																						-see background information here
If even a few could predict that well then there would be little volatility and these "geniuses" would be very rich.
We have at least 10,000 research papers establishing this one as a fact
Answer assumes that no public information is unaccounted for, because stock market is closed.
This is the conclusion of the empirical evidence I have seen.
Everyone should have to read Ken French's Presidential Address to the American Finance Association on the perils of active investing.																						-see background information here
Predictable anomalies are surely a small part of daily variance.  Long term predictability seems greater (Campbell-Shiller).																						-see background information here
Markets may be far from perfect, but the literature supports that the current price is the best predictor of tomorrow's price.
Hard one to answer - probably depends on interpretation of "very few" and "consistently".
Tough question because of details. But yes. This is well studied and subject to small, low-yield, and transient anomalies.
The evidence supports this claim, though one can't infer that stock prices always equal reasonable forecasts of discounted future dividends.
The informational requirements are too high given the many factors and random shocks that can occur on any given day.
The evidence on this one seems overwhelming.
There may be rare moments when movements of specific stocks are predictable, but these are fleeting and will yield profit to only a few.

data.question:
Plausible
expectations of future dividends, discounted using a plausible risk-adjusted
interest rate, explain well the level of stock prices for recently
listed internet businesses in 1999.

responses.comment: We were in a bubble. There were not enough future profits in the world to justify those prices.
The definition of plausibly is part of the issue---
This is not my area of expertise.
Ex post events suggest otherwise.
You mean there was no bubble?
Expected cash flows were hard to estimate. See Pastor and Veronesi. An ex ante (1999) poll would be very interesting!																						-see background information here
Are we still arguing over whether the internet bubble was a bubble?  I thought it was at the time and have never thought otherwise.
The Q is still oddly worded, but appears to ask whether the dot.com bubble was a bubble.  I guess I think it was.

? 
We know that there was a bubble and most of them went out of business.
It is always easiest to make these judgments ex post, which of course, undermines their meaning.
Turns on the interpretation of "plausible." My Ely Lecture made the case that eBay's valuation satisfied a plausible discounted div model.																						-see background information here
"Plausible" is a fuzzy term. Asset pricing theories concern averages, not events. If a 10-1 horse wins, does that mean the odds were wrong?
Never could figure out how pets.com, webvan and various other dotcoms could have ever made money.
-see background information here
In cases where ex post, something turns out to be a bubble, it is tough to say that ex ante expectations were plausible.
Even at the time, it was clear that these firms would have to earn most of GDP to rationalize their stock prices.
This episode was a classic case of contagious overoptimism.
This is but one interpretation; a bubble would be another....
I haven't seen an analysis of this for dot.coms in aggregate, but many of their valuations were truly nutty.
Asset prices are extremely volatile, and "explaining" this fact as variations in the price of risk seems close to tautological.
The key is to define "plausible expectations".  It is likely that widespread overconfidence contributed to the price rise.

data.question:
The Chinese government
pursues policies that keep the renminbi's exchange rate vis à vis the dollar
lower than it would be if the currency floated without those policies.

responses.comment: That is my understanding, but this is second-hand information, not my area of expertise.
Not my field.
Yes, but the situation is not as extreme as was the case a few years ago.
Everyone thinks so.  Can everyone be wrong?  Yes.  But not every time, and not most of the time.
Seems uncontroversial.
The undervaluation of the currency is part of their growth strategy.  Higher prices for consumers; more demand for products from abroad.
multiple trillions of foreign reserves, giant trade surpluses, fighting to contain domestic inflation.  Smells a whole like undervaluation.
China has many policies; some raise and some lower the value of the yuan. Absent the ones that lower its value, it would rise.
The same policies are creating big imbalances in China by thwarting price signals. The eventual adjustment for China could be ugly.																						-see background information here
They use the exchange rate for monetary policy, but some knowledgeable economist believe that the rate would be higher with float.
Would expect that China amassing $3 trillion in dollar reserves has an effect on the exchange rate.
I don't know enough about what China may or may not be doing to state an informed opinion.
Although these policies also increase inflation, what erodes a portion of the impact on the real exchange rate.
Not my terrain.  I know little more than what I read in the unreliable press.
Not my area.

data.question:
Public school students would receive
a higher quality education if they all had the option of taking the government
money (local, state, federal) currently being spent on their own
education and turning that money into vouchers that they
could use towards covering the costs of any private school or public school of
their choice (e.g. charter schools).

responses.comment: Vouchers likely to improve things in short run given the awful state of US public schools. But we know little about their long run effects.
The evidence is mixed on the benefits of school choice.
Maddeningly sweeping! Some students would benefit and the average effect might indeed be positive. But some students would surely be harmed.
Those using vouchers would likely be better off, but others might be worse - need to consider system-level and distributional effects.
The kids whose parents don't pay attention or are poorly informed can be worse off.  Otherwise agree.
More motivated and able students would take advantage of the vouchers, but the students left behind would likely be worse off.
The existing alternatives to public schools are not all of uniformly higher quality; adverse selection is a big deal too.
And what about the kids that don't take up the vouchers?
Maybe yes. And maybe those left behind would do worse. The equilibrium could be tough.
On the plus side, incentives are better under vouchers.  On the negative side, decision making might be in the hands of those with less info
I think the majority of public school students would be better off, but certainly not all.  The question is ambiguous about the percent.
Treating students as clients does not improve education. Evidence on voucher programs very mixed - no robust evidence of positive effects.
Many public school students would benefit but some with little choice might not.  On net it would be beneficial and increase competition.
Competition is likely beneficial on average. Less clear that all students would benefit leading to tough ?s about social welfare functions
The problem with cashing out public support of education is that parents are the agents of children and some parents are poor agents.
There is enough in avg student's per-pupil budget for a solid supply-side response-i.e. what's needed for widespread benefits of competition
I do not believe that all students would be better off.
Hard to know what the equilibrium will be, but so many kids are trapped now eventually most of them would have better choices.
If peer effects are important, could have most gain but some lose.																						-see background information here
The main disadvantage to vouchers is potential weakening of public schools.  But those that would lose students are terrible already.
Hard to give a blanket answer to this question
Hard to predict what a privatized school system would look like.
The issues and caveats strike me as far too complex for 140 characters.
Many would of course benefit, but those in rural areas or with irresponsible parents wouldn't.  Charters aren't magic.
School choice has merits but the system is complex and long-term effects on both private and public education is unclear.
It's the only way to break the unions.  Why do that?  Fran Tarkenton said it all in his recent WSJ op ed piece.																						-see background information here
Hurray for charter schools but to go to full vouchers it is necessary to deal with possible unraveling if no schools want the bottom kids.

data.question: All else equal, permanently raising the federal marginal tax rate on ordinary income by 1 percentage point for those in the top (i.e., currently 35%) tax bracket would increase federal tax revenue over the next 10 years.

responses.comment: Disincentive effects on labor supply and entrepreneurship, and tax avoidance are likely, but not large enough to reduce revenues.
The labor supply literature strongly suggests that the revenue gain from a higher rate will outweigh a small reduction in labor supply.
We are nowhere near the downward sloping side of the Laffer curve.
Bigger question is what the economic cost would be, but unlikely to be so large that revenues would actually decline.
The behavioral response cannot possibly be big enough to wipe out the revenue gains.
There are many people in the top bracket, and while some would be able to change their behavior to offset the increased tax, not all would.
The elasticities are not that high.
This seems quite clear.
Is the net effect on revenues negative because of the impacts on avoidance and earning efforts? That's not clear, but probably not.
Labor elasticity should be less than 1 and might in fact go either way. Federal Revenue could be used in helpful ways.
This would not put us on the bad part of the Laffer curve.
A 1% increase seens too small to impact hours worked, productivity or consumption in the top bracket.
There are some good estimates showing that higher taxes at the top nets more income.  Labor SS response is low as is falsification of income
CBO's analysis indicates that the Bush tax cuts reduced revenue so presumably undoing part of this decrease in rates would increase revenue.																						-see background information here
Close call. Depends on enforcement efforts. Prior to 1986, taxpayers in the high bracket seemed to be willing to buy inefficient shelters.
Some activities will change little, such as labor supply, but some will increase tax avoidance efforts. My guess is a weak revenue increase.
Forecasting the forecast of others (Chetty, Saez, ...).																						-see background information here
Revenue would rise, but the important question is what happens to growth, not revenue. The goal is not to maximize the size of government.
Saez puts top of the Laffer curve above 60%, suggesting we're well to the left.
Weight of evidence on personal tax rate with some reservations about other (state and local) taxes and other interactions.
It is doubtful such a small tax increase would materially affect behavior.
Based on best estimates and even with current tax code, US top rate is still significantly below revenue maximizing tax rate
There is a Laffer Curve, but 35% is to the left of the peak.
The Laffer curve should have stayed on the napkin.
The negative effect on growth would have to be huge to offset the tax revenues raised.

data.question: The cumulative budget shortfalls in the US over the next 10 years can be reduced by half (or more) purely by increasing the federal marginal tax rate on ordinary income for those in the top tax bracket.

responses.comment: More comprehensive increases in taxes and reduction in tax expenditures, or preferably systematic means testing of SS-Medicare are necessary
Broad based tax reform and reductions in projected expenditures, particularly on health, will be required.
Unfortunately, not enough income there to do it (I think)
I think depends on how shortfall defined (current law vs. current policy, etc.) - but not a good idea in either case, esp. in longer run.
My back of the envelope suggests no, but I think a PF person would have more of the numbers at their disposal.
Medicare (and to a lesser extent Social Security) are big drivers of the deficit, so changes are necessary to bring it under control.
I don't know offhand what the estimates are at different elasticities.
I don't know the magnitudes well enough to know whether or not this is likely to be the case.
It is a difficult question (for me at least).
According to CBO estimates, maybe if rates go sky high.  According to Gale and Auerbach, deficit far too big. links on my webpage.																						-see background information here
I don't know the tax distribution data well enough.
Tremendous uncertainty around these projections. Also, given the complexity of the tax code,  taxpayers find ways around specific rate hikes
Don't have any idea if it would be one-half.  That seems rather large.  But if it were true -- let's do it.
Unknown elasticities and unclear baseline (do other Bush tax cuts expire?  future of Medicaid/Medicaid?) make it very  difficult to evaluate
There's a CBO-style "current law" assumption here that is hard to deal with--does the AMT come back in its old form or continue to be cut?
The rich don't have that much money, and would respond with substantial increases in tax avoidance activities.
Too many ways to shift income. If the rate becomes very high labor supply will probably fall.  Everyone will have to pay to cut the deficits

Doesn't look close according to these calculations (see link).																						-see background information here
															-see background information here
Using the President's numbers, the gaps are too big, more so if we go beyond 10 years. Scoring of tax increase do not show big deficit cuts.
How could this be? CBO projects $1tr annual deficits. Annual income tax revenues from $500+k earners are now $350bn. We're going to 3x this?
Close call. With 10 yr CBO baseline def of $6 tr, indiv inc taxes of $19 tr, top 1% pays 40% of that, 50% rate. If really "purely," then no.																						-see background information here
The budget shortfalls are too large to be covered on this income tax base. Both tax and entitlement reform will be needed.
Enough income at top to cut deficit by 50%+ but need to go after it after base broadening not solely by increasing current ordinary top rate
The top bracket is a very small group.  Maybe with the top 10% of the income distribution.  But how are we defining "budget shortfalls"?
Only a small part of the puzzle.  Tax reform anyone?
cumulative deficit is 10 trillion.  taxable  income at the 35%   600 billions. to halve the deficit you will need 100% tax rate. Impossible

data.question:
All else equal, the Fed's
new plan to increase the maturity of its Treasury holdings will boost expected
real GDP growth for calendar year 2012 by at least one percentage point.

responses.comment: Expansionary policy, aimed at reducing long-term interest rates. Should be successful but no idea about whether it gets 1% growth for 2012.
1pct increase in real GDP growth is a huge effect! If only it were that easy...
Such a big effect seems unlikely.
This isn't an area where I know the most recent literature.
Hard to imagine that high long term interests are the problem, or that we know enough to be so sure.
It is will probably have a positive effect, but 1% of GDP is a lot to expect from a moderate twist.
One percent is a lot.  Any effects will be smaller.
Way too large an effect.
The decrease in long term rates is likely to promote growth, but a one percentage boost for 2012 seems excessively optimistic / unfounded.
Making more funds available for long-term borrowing need not raise investment with so much uncertainty.  Also one %age point is too precise
even if it works to lower long term rates, they are already so low it's hard to see how more reduction will induce much more investment etc
I am unaware of convincing empirical evidence.
Need to be sure the Treasury does not offset the twist. Also most likely that lowering the long Treasury rate has little effect on other rts
The gains will be tiny.  Monetary policy is a poor tool for what ails the economy.  The mandate says try it, but political risks are real.
